claim: 你妈妈的说法有一定事实依据：不少上市公司选择不发放股息，因为管理层认为把利润再投入业务、推动增长与公司价值提升，比立即分红更能回报股东
question_src: 我妈妈刚刚告诉我，大多数股票都不付钱。是这样吗？如果是这样，为什么股票市场甚至存在，我们都同意做一个赌博领域，我们押注其他人押注我们的赌注？如果是这样，为什么公司对股东有多重要？
all_claims: 你妈妈的说法有一定事实依据：不少上市公司选择不发放股息，因为管理层认为把利润再投入业务、推动增长与公司价值提升，比立即分红更能回报股东[2]。
即便没有股息，投资者仍可通过公司盈利扩张带来的股价上涨获利，因此股票市场并非纯粹“押注别人押注”——它让企业获得长期资本，投资人获得分享企业成果与资产增值的权利。
赌博和投资都冒风险，但赌场游戏从长期看预期回报为负，而股票市场历史平均预期收益率则为正[5]；投资者还能通过研究、分散化等方式识别并管理风险[4]。
公司之所以重视股东，是因为股东提供的资金支持研发、扩产及并购；作为所有者，股东可凭投票权影响董事会、在公司分红或清算时分配剩余资产，这套产权与治理机制正是现代经济持续扩张的基础。
claims_retained: 你妈妈的说法有一定事实依据：不少上市公司选择不发放股息，因为管理层认为把利润再投入业务、推动增长与公司价值提升，比立即分红更能回报股东[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How and When Are Stock Dividends Paid Out? (www.investopedia.com)
Content: A dividend is the distribution of some of a company's earnings to a class of its shareholders. Dividends are usually paid in the form of a dividend check. However, they may also be paid in additional shares of stock. The standard practice for the payment of dividends is a check that is mailed to stockholders a few days after the ex-dividend date, which is the date on which the stock starts trading without the previously declared dividend.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 所有股票都有股息吗？ （为什么有些股票不支付股息？）（therobusttrader.com）
Content: 所有股票都不支付股息。有利可图的公司的经理可以选择直接（通过股息）补偿股东，或者投资回到公司以促进增长并增加公司的价值。因此，投资者可以选择购买股息股票或强调股东薪酬增长的股票。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Content: Gambling, trading, speculation, and investment are perceived in very different ways but they have two core similarities. First, they all involve risking money in hopes of a positive return. Second, the results are dependent in part on luck.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Content: A number of distinctions between the various endeavors are usually drawn. Gambling is typically viewed as a form of entertainment that carries a higher level of risk and has a less certain outcome. Speculation and investment are generally viewed as business enterprises in which risk is understood and steps are taking to mitigate and manage it.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: Going All-In: Investing vs. Gambling (www.investopedia.com)
Content: True, investing and gambling both involve risk and choice—specifically, the risk of capital with hopes of future profit. But gambling is typically a short-lived activity, while equities investing can last a lifetime. Also, there is a negative expected return to gamblers, on average and over the long run. On the other hand, investing in the stock market typically carries with it a positive expected return on average over the long run.
---

Title: Snapchat隐私友好吗？ [分析]  - 选择加密（choosetoencrypt.com）
Content: Snapchat在其用户之间共享的照片上使用端到端加密。 Snapchat上发送的短信和其他消息不受相同的加密保护。 Snapchat并未透露有关其使用的加密类型的太多信息，因此一旦他们到达Snap的服务器，很难真正理解您的消息会发生什么。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: Don’t Let People Find You with Your Mobile Number: Snapchat settings allow you to toggle whether or not other users can find your Snapchat account using your mobile number. If you are concerned about privacy, you should turn this feature off. If you use your personal cell phone number for work purposes, or have your phone number published anywhere online, turning this off can protect you from an unwanted flood of unknown people adding you as a friend.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Content: The truth is, however, that whenever a user opens the Snapchat app, their location is shared on the Snap Map. Verge reporter Dani Deahl explained that she was able to pinpoint one of her friend’s locations down to the exact street address. Since the address was in a residential area, she determined that was where her friend lived.


Snapchat users may assume that sharing their location is harmless, but it could allow for someone to find you or track your frequent locations. In Snapchat’s settings you can select which friends you share your location with, if any at all.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How To Fix ‘Random People Adding Me On Snapchat’ Problem (nerdschalk.com)
Content: When you create an account on Snapchat, you give Snapchat the permission to display your profile to users that look you up. In this case, if a user knows your Snapchat ID, they can search for you and then add you from the search results.


If you have added your phone number on the app, you may show up on the accounts of people who have your number saved on their phones under ‘People you may know’. This is because Snapchat lets you sync your phone contacts to help you add your friends easily.


Users can also scan your Snapcode to be redirected to your Snapchat profile. If you posted your Snapcode in a public forum, anyone could scan it and add you using that code.


Related: What Happens When You Block Someone On TikTok?


## Who are the random people on my Snapchat?


Recently, a number of users have complained about getting an influx of ‘Adds’ on Snapchat. While this should not raise any red flags if it was organic growth, the users adding have no mutual friends. So the question arises, where did they get your profile info from?


Well, it seems a number of users have resorted to using bots to gain followers on the app. These bot accounts add you and wait for you to add them back. Once you do, they remove you as a friend. This allows users to reach a larger audience.


So if you are wondering why you have a bunch of strangers trying to add you on Snapchat, they could just be bot accounts.
---

Content: 当您在Snapchat上创建一个帐户时，您将授予Snapchat的权限，向查找您的用户显示您的个人资料。在这种情况下，如果用户知道您的Snapchat ID，则可以搜索您，然后从搜索结果中添加您。

用户还可以扫描您的快照以重定向到Snapchat配置文件。如果您在公共论坛中发布了快照，任何人都可以扫描并使用该代码添加您。


相关：当您在Tiktok上阻止某人时会发生什么？


##我的snapchat上谁是随机的人？


最近，许多用户抱怨在Snapchat上涌入“添加”。虽然如果这是有机增长，则不应引起任何危险信号，但添加的用户没有共同的朋友。因此，问题出现了，他们从哪里获得您的个人资料信息？


好吧，似乎许多用户都求助于使用机器人在应用程序上获得关注者。这些机器人帐户添加了您，并等待您添加它们。一旦您这样做，他们就将您删除为朋友。这使用户可以吸引更多的受众。


因此，如果您想知道为什么您有很多陌生人试图在Snapchat上添加您，那么他们可能只是机器人帐户。

Verge reporter Dani Deahl explained that she was able to pinpoint one of her friend’s locations down to the exact street address. Since the address was in a residential area, she determined that was where her friend lived.


Snapchat users may assume that sharing their location is harmless, but it could allow for someone to find you or track your frequent locations. In Snapchat’s settings you can select which friends you share your location with, if any at all.

Title: How To Fix ‘Random People Adding Me On Snapchat’ Problem (nerdschalk.com)
Content: When you create an account on Snapchat, you give Snapchat the permission to display your profile to users that look you up. In this case, if a user knows your Snapchat ID, they can search for you and then add you from the search results.


If you have added your phone number on the app, you may show up on the accounts of people who have your number saved on their phones under ‘People you may know’. This is because Snapchat lets you sync your phone contacts to help you add your friends easily.


Users can also scan your Snapcode to be redirected to your Snapchat profile. If you posted your Snapcode in a public forum, anyone could scan it and add you using that code.


Related: What Happens When You Block Someone On TikTok?


## Who are the random people on my Snapchat?


Recently, a number of users have complained about getting an influx of ‘Adds’ on Snapchat. While this should not raise any red flags if it was organic growth, the users adding have no mutual friends. So the question arises, where did they get your profile info from?


Well, it seems a number of users have resorted to using bots to gain followers on the app. These bot accounts add you and wait for you to add them back. Once you do, they remove you as a friend. This allows users to reach a larger audience.


So if you are wondering why you have a bunch of strangers trying to add you on Snapchat, they could just be bot accounts.

question_src: 美国总统选举制度。我不明白这一点。
all_claims: 美国总统选举采用选举人团制度，这是建国先贤在由国会选总统与全民直选之间折衷的产物[2]。
全国共有538名选举人，每州人数等于其众议员席位数加两名参议员，哥伦比亚特区另得3名选举人，赢得过半即270票即可当选总统[4]。
选民在11月大选日投出的其实是各州承诺支持某候选人的选举人名单，而非直接投给候选人本人[3]。
48个州与华盛顿特区实行“胜者全得”，普选领先者获得该州全部选举人票；缅因州和内布拉斯加州则按比例分配选举人票[1]。
选举夜通常依据统计宣布“预计获胜者”，真正的选举人团投票要到12月中旬各州选举人集会时进行[1]。
宪法虽未强制选举人遵守州内普选结果，一些州法律却要求如此，违者可能被罚款、撤换甚至起诉，因此所谓“失信选举人”极为罕见[1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Presidential Election Process | USAGov (www.usa.gov)
Content: After you cast your ballot for president, your vote goes to a statewide tally. In 48 states and Washington, D.C., the winner gets all the electoral votes for that state. Maine and Nebraska assign their electors using a proportional system.


A candidate needs the vote of at least 270 electors—more than half of all electors—to win the presidential election.


In most cases, a projected winner is announced on election night in November after you vote. But the actual Electoral College vote takes place in mid-December when the electors meet in their states. See the Electoral College timeline of events for the 2020 election.


While the Constitution doesn’t require electors to vote for the candidate chosen by their state's popular vote, some states do. The rare elector who votes for someone else may be fined, disqualified and replaced by a substitute elector, or potentially even prosecuted.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 美国选举学院系统如何运作（www.thoughtco.com）
Content: 开国元勋们创建了选举学院制度，这是由国会选出的总统和由合格公民的普选选举的总统之间的妥协。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: When you vote for a presidential candidate, you are in fact voting to instruct the electors from your state to cast their votes for the same candidate.


For example, if you vote for the Republican candidate in the November election, you are really just picking an elector who will be pledged to vote for the Republican candidate when the Electoral College votes in December. The candidate who wins the popular vote in a state wins all the pledged votes of the state's electors in the 48 winner-take-all states and District of Columbia.﻿﻿ Nebraska and Maine award electors proportionally.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: Each state gets a number of electors equal to its number of members in the U.S. House of Representatives plus one for each of its two U.S. senators. The District of Columbia gets three electors.﻿﻿ State laws determine how electors are chosen, but they are generally selected by the political party committees within the states.


Each elector gets one vote. Thus, a state with eight electors would cast eight votes. As of the 1964 election, there are 538 electors, and the votes of a majority of them—270—are required to be elected.﻿﻿ Because Electoral College representation is based on congressional representation, states with larger populations get more Electoral College votes.
---

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Presidential Election Process | USAGov (www.usa.gov)
Content: After you cast your ballot for president, your vote goes to a statewide tally. In 48 states and Washington, D.C., the winner gets all the electoral votes for that state. Maine and Nebraska assign their electors using a proportional system.


A candidate needs the vote of at least 270 electors—more than half of all electors—to win the presidential election.


In most cases, a projected winner is announced on election night in November after you vote. But the actual Electoral College vote takes place in mid-December when the electors meet in their states. See the Electoral College timeline of events for the 2020 election.


While the Constitution doesn’t require electors to vote for the candidate chosen by their state's popular vote, some states do. The rare elector who votes for someone else may be fined, disqualified and replaced by a substitute elector, or potentially even prosecuted.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: The Founding Fathers created the Electoral College system as a compromise between having the president elected by Congress and having the president elected by the popular vote of qualified citizens.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: When you vote for a presidential candidate, you are in fact voting to instruct the electors from your state to cast their votes for the same candidate.


For example, if you vote for the Republican candidate in the November election, you are really just picking an elector who will be pledged to vote for the Republican candidate when the Electoral College votes in December. The candidate who wins the popular vote in a state wins all the pledged votes of the state's electors in the 48 winner-take-all states and District of Columbia.﻿﻿ Nebraska and Maine award electors proportionally.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: 美国选举学院系统如何运作（www.thoughtco.com）
Content: 每个州的选民在美国众议院的成员人数等于其两位美国参议员的成员人数。哥伦比亚特区获得了三名选民。州法律决定了选举人的选择方式，但通常由各州的政党委员会选择。


每个选举人都有一票。因此，一个拥有八名选民的州将投票八票。截至1964年大选，有538名选举人，其中大多数人（270）的选票必须当选。由于选举学院的代表是基于国会代表，因此人口较大的州获得了更多的选举学院投票。

question_src: 如果我被可靠的供水被困在某个地方，但没有食物，我的身体会发生什么
all_claims: 当你有充足饮水却完全没有食物时，身体首先会在24小时内耗尽肝糖原并开始分解脂肪以产生能量，几天后进入酮症状态以维持大脑运作；此时基础代谢率下降，你会感觉虚弱、畏冷、注意力难以集中，免疫力和伤口愈合速度也会显著减弱。
随着脂肪储备被耗尽，机体会分解肌肉和内脏蛋白，心肌收缩力下降，电解质紊乱可能引发心律失常或猝死。
一般而言，在确保水分供应的情况下，人类通常能够生存大约8-21天，极少数情况下可延长至近两个月 [1]。
若持续饥饿，器官功能衰竭最终导致死亡，因此一旦被困应尽快设法获得食物或寻求救援。
claims_retained: 一般而言，在确保水分供应的情况下，人类通常能够生存大约8-21天，极少数情况下可延长至近两个月 [1]。

claim: 手机之所以“知道”你在睡觉，主要依赖机身内置的高灵敏度加速度计：当你把手机放在枕头附近的床垫上时，应用会实时记录床垫的微小晃动并形成整夜的运动曲线[1]
question_src: 我的手机睡觉时怎么知道？
all_claims: 手机之所以“知道”你在睡觉，主要依赖机身内置的高灵敏度加速度计：当你把手机放在枕头附近的床垫上时，应用会实时记录床垫的微小晃动并形成整夜的运动曲线[1][2]。
进入深度睡眠后，人体肌肉活动被抑制，身体几乎不动，曲线因此趋于平坦，系统就把这一段识别为深睡或熟睡[1]；若检测到连续较大的翻身或起床动作，则会被标记为浅睡、清醒或中断[3]。
应用通过整夜各时间段的“运动强度—持续时间”模式来估算你入睡、浅睡、深睡和醒来的时间，从而判断“你什么时候在睡觉”。
需要注意的是，任何非睡眠的剧烈动作（例如拿手机、起身喝水）都可能被记录成睡眠不安或中断，因而仍存在一定误差[3]。
claims_retained: 手机之所以“知道”你在睡觉，主要依赖机身内置的高灵敏度加速度计：当你把手机放在枕头附近的床垫上时，应用会实时记录床垫的微小晃动并形成整夜的运动曲线[1][2]。

question_src: 作为一个有散光的人，为什么当我有点斜视我的眼睛时，我会看到更清晰的东西呢？
all_claims: 散光时角膜弯曲不均，光线无法在视网膜形成单一点成像而出现重影和模糊。
眯眼会收窄眼裂、缩小瞳孔，只让靠近光轴的少量中央光线进入，相当于在眼前加了“针孔”，屏蔽了原本偏离焦点的周边光线，于是视野变得锐利，这就是针孔效应[2]。
同时，眼睑压力与眼肌紧张使晶状体曲率略增，相当于微调镜头焦距，使光线更好地汇聚于视网膜[1]。
两种机制叠加，可让散光者暂时看得更清晰，但并不能替代专业验光与矫正。
claims_retained: 眯眼会收窄眼裂、缩小瞳孔，只让靠近光轴的少量中央光线进入，相当于在眼前加了“针孔”，屏蔽了原本偏离焦点的周边光线，于是视野变得锐利，这就是针孔效应[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Can I See Better When I Squint My Eyes? - Grosinger, Spigelman & Grey (www.eyemichigan.com)
Content: What Does Squinting Do to Your Eye?


Even though it doesn’t feel much different, squinting does three things to our eyes that lead to slightly clearer vision.


* Our Eye Lens Changes Shape – The lens of the eye is flexible and changes shape when we squint.
* The Eye Lens Adjusts – Small adjustments in the lens allow us to focus better, much like a camera.
* Less Light Enters the Eye – Less light enters, reducing the impact on the retina and allowing the object we view to look sharper.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 为什么当我斜视时会更好？ （www.invision2020.com）
Content: 少量的视力清晰度增加是由于斜视时会改变眼睛的形状。但是，工作中的主要光学原理和非常有趣的光学原理称为“针孔效应”。清晰的视力是光线射线的结果，该光线适当地集中在眼睛背面的视网膜上。通常，这是用眼镜或隐形眼镜完成的；两者都将光线弯曲为焦点，因此正确视力。


当我们斜视时，它会产生与透过针孔相同的效果。基本上，只允许少量聚焦的中央光线进入眼睛。这样可以防止外围未关注的光线到达视网膜。结果是更好的视野。摄影师将其理解为“景深”。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Vision Hack: How to See Clearly Without Your Glasses or Contacts (vision-and-hearing.wonderhowto.com)
Content: The reason that squinting helps you see is because it changes the shape of your eye, making the pupil smaller, thus letting less light in and making an image clear. This is similar to the way a larger aperture works; a smaller hole in your camera lets less light in, with better focus.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Cornell Center for Materials Research (www.ccmr.cornell.edu)
Content: By limiting the rays of light that come in through the bottom and top of the pupil, squinting allows rays to pass closer to the center of the lens, thereby creating a more focused image. So, that means that squinting works by two mechanisms – by both changing the shape of the eye and by letting in light that can be focused more precisely by the lens.
---

claim: 每天约有48吨太空碎屑坠入大气，其中绝大多数在高空就以尘埃或微小流星体的形式烧毁，对大气和地表几乎无害
question_src: 流星（或其他空间碎片）会损害或对大气层造成风险吗？如果是这样，对我们有多危险？如果不是，为什么不呢？
all_claims: 每天约有48吨太空碎屑坠入大气，其中绝大多数在高空就以尘埃或微小流星体的形式烧毁，对大气和地表几乎无害[1]。
当较小流星进入大气时，高温和动压常使其瓦解，甚至因空气渗入多孔内部而“从内而外”爆炸成碎片，进一步降低落地危害[4]。
然而若撞击体直径达到约1–2公里，就足以抛射大量蒸发尘土遮蔽阳光，在全球范围内引发多年“撞击冬天”并扰乱气候[2]。
待尘埃沉降，大量温室气体与撞击火灾产生的气溶胶又会导致显著增温，形成长期气候变暖[2]。
此外，撞击输入的巨大能量能破坏平流层臭氧层，使地表紫外线强度大增，持续约两年，危及人类健康与生态[3]。
因此，日常流星对大气几乎无风险，但极少数大型小行星若撞击则可能带来灾难性全球环境变化。

Title: 小行星对地球影响的长期影响（Education.seattlepi.com）
Content: 坠落到地球的流星似乎很少见，但是每天有48吨以上的碎屑落入地球大气中。其中大多数以灰尘和微型通灵物的形式立即燃烧，但是在极少数情况下，较大的岩石可能会很好地落入地球的重力中。根据物体的大小，影响会导致许多不同的影响，而足够大的小行星可以大大改变地球上的生命。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Long Term Effects of an Asteroid Impact on Earth (education.seattlepi.com)
Content: A massive asteroid impact would create long-term changes in the atmosphere and climate of the planet. Upon impact, vaporized dirt and rock would fill the atmosphere, blocking sunlight and creating a state of near-permanent darkness and winter-like conditions. After the particles in the atmosphere settle, an increase in greenhouse gases from impact fires and released stores in the crater area could actually increase temperatures substantially due to an increased greenhouse effect. The severity and length of each of these phases would depend on the size of the impact, with a one or two kilometer-wide asteroid causing enough damage to trigger worldwide disturbances for years.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Long Term Effects of an Asteroid Impact on Earth (education.seattlepi.com)
Content: Another dangerous effect of an asteroid strike would be damage to the ozone layer. The energy imparted to the atmosphere by the incoming object would be enough to disrupt the protective layer of ozone high in the stratosphere, drastically increasing the amount of ultraviolet light that made it to the surface. This would increase global cancer rates, affect the growth of plants and animals and possibly lead to genetic mutations over the period of increased exposure. Depending on the size of the asteroid, this could last for as much as two years.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: In Earth's Atmosphere, Meteors May Explode from the Inside Out (www.space.com)
Content: Earth's atmosphere may infiltrate the interior of porous meteors as they hurtle toward the planet, creating pockets of high-pressure air inside the rocky space debris. These pockets can then cause the space rocks to explode, breaking into smaller pieces.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: In Earth's Atmosphere, Meteors May Explode from the Inside Out (www.space.com)
Content: When meteors enter the planet's atmosphere, they heat up, and ultimately disintegrate. (This is either because of something -called ram pressure or friction.). However, the new research highlights a new way in which the atmosphere may break up meteors and protect Earth, the researchers said.

After the particles in the atmosphere settle, an increase in greenhouse gases from impact fires and released stores in the crater area could actually increase temperatures substantially due to an increased greenhouse effect. The severity and length of each of these phases would depend on the size of the impact, with a one or two kilometer-wide asteroid causing enough damage to trigger worldwide disturbances for years.

question_src: 关于加密，“位”是什么意思？即4096位加密
all_claims: 在加密领域，“位”(bit)是构成密钥的二进制数字；每个位只能取 0 或 1，是计算与通信中最基本的数据单位[1]。
密钥长度用位数表示，n 位密钥拥有 2ⁿ 种可能组合，位数越多，穷举破解的难度呈指数级增加，因此“4096 位加密”通常指采用 4096 位长的 RSA 密钥，其长度比常见的 2048 位密钥更大，安全性也更高[5]。
一张常用对照表表明，大约 2048 位 RSA 提供约 112 位对称安全强度，3072 位约 128 位，7680 位约 192 位[4]；4096 位处于 3072 与 7680 之间，通常被视为满足长期高安全需求的选项，但其运算成本也相应上升——在 RSA 中密钥长度每翻倍，解密速度大约变慢 5 倍[5]。

密钥长度用位数表示，n 位密钥拥有 2ⁿ 种可能组合，位数越多，穷举破解的难度呈指数级增加，因此“4096 位加密”通常指采用 4096 位长的 RSA 密钥，其长度比常见的 2048 位密钥更大，安全性也更高[5]。

---
Document ID: 2
Title: Bit (www.techopedia.com)
Content: A computer not only initiates multiple instructions that can manipulate and test bits, but it also performs these instructions and stores accumulated data in eight-bit parcels called bytes
---

Title: What does BIT mean? (www.definitions.net)
Content: The length of a binary number may be referred to as its bit-length. In information theory, one bit is typically defined as the uncertainty of a binary random variable that is 0 or 1 with equal probability
---

Title: Should We Start Using 4096 bit RSA keys? (www.jscape.com)
Content: Security Strength RSA key length
<= 80 1024
112 2048
128 3072
192 7680
256 15360
---
Document ID: 5
Title: RSA key lengths (www.javamex.com)
Content: * unless you can accept a relatively low level of security and are running on modest hardware, you should generally choose an RSA key length of at least 2048 bits (current NIST recommendation);
* if you are running on recent dedicated hardware and/or require good security, then consider a key size of 4096 bits;
* you could consider higher key lengths, but the performance overhead increase almost exponentially with key length, meaning in practice a doubling of key length makes decryption some 5 times slower

claim: S 等级之所以在大多数场合被视为最高级，主要源于日本学术评分体系的做法：传统 A-F 制无法进一步区分顶尖成绩，于是日本高校在 A 之上再加一档 “S”，其日语写作 “秀”(Shū)，对应 90–100 分，含义是 “出类拔萃”，且“极少给予”，以凸显其稀有与卓越
question_src: 为什么在大多数情况下，S等级高？
all_claims: S 等级之所以在大多数场合被视为最高级，主要源于日本学术评分体系的做法：传统 A-F 制无法进一步区分顶尖成绩，于是日本高校在 A 之上再加一档 “S”，其日语写作 “秀”(Shū)，对应 90–100 分，含义是 “出类拔萃”，且“极少给予”，以凸显其稀有与卓越 [2]。
由于这一做法明确传达了 “比 A 还好” 的概念，S 很快被游戏、动漫、武术排行等流行文化借用，作为超越常规等级的象征，在排名表或关卡评价中代表“最高”“最强” [1]。
因此，人们习惯把 S 视为顶点，不论是在学术、竞技还是娱乐评分里，都用它来标榜极少数达到“特别（Special/Super）”或“优胜（Superior）”标准的对象。
claims_retained: S 等级之所以在大多数场合被视为最高级，主要源于日本学术评分体系的做法：传统 A-F 制无法进一步区分顶尖成绩，于是日本高校在 A 之上再加一档 “S”，其日语写作 “秀”(Shū)，对应 90–100 分，含义是 “出类拔萃”，且“极少给予”，以凸显其稀有与卓越 [2]。

claim: 过去50年来，数字技术以指数速度演进，其核心动力是摩尔定律：集成电路上的晶体管数量大约每两年翻倍
question_src: 在过去的50年中，技术增长如何呈指数增长？
all_claims: 过去50年来，数字技术以指数速度演进，其核心动力是摩尔定律：集成电路上的晶体管数量大约每两年翻倍[1]。
1965年戈登·摩尔基于这一观察预测，计算性能将指数式提升、成本则同步下降[2]。
实际发展证明，晶体管尺寸不断缩小，使得在相同面积内可容纳的晶体管数量急剧增加，带来处理速度提升和能效改善，同时终端价格持续走低[2]。
这种指数增长不仅让电脑、手机等既有产品性能飞跃，还催生云计算、社交媒体和现代数据分析等全新产业[2]。
在硬件层面，存储容量、相机像素等指标也遵循类似翻倍轨迹，显示技术各方面都在指数扩张[1]。
粗略估算，自1965年至今经历约25次翻倍，计算能力提升超过千万倍，促成计算从稀缺昂贵的资源演变为普及且廉价的社会基础设施，从而深刻改变了工作、娱乐与交流方式。

Document ID: 2
Title: Over 50 Years of Moore's Law (www.intel.com)
Content: In 1965, Gordon Moore made a prediction that would set the pace for our modern digital revolution. From careful observation of an emerging trend, Moore extrapolated that computing would dramatically increase in power, and decrease in relative cost, at an exponential pace. The insight, known as Moore’s Law, became the golden rule for the electronics industry, and a springboard for innovation. As a co-founder, Gordon paved the path for Intel to make the ever faster, smaller, more affordable transistors that drive our modern tools and toys. Even over 50 years later, the lasting impact and benefits are felt in many ways.


### Economic Impact


### Economic Impact


Performance—aka power—and cost are two key drivers of technological development. As more transistors fit into smaller spaces, processing power increased and energy efficiency improved, all at a lower cost for the end user. This development not only enhanced existing industries and increased productivity, but it has spawned whole new industries empowered by cheap and powerful computing.


### Technological Impact


### Technological Impact


Moore’s observation transformed computing from a rare and expensive venture into a pervasive and affordable necessity. All of the modern computing technology we know and enjoy sprang from the foundation laid by Moore’s Law. From the Internet itself, to social media and modern data analytics, all these innovations stem directly from Moore and his findings.


### Societal Impact


### Societal Impact


The inexpensive, ubiquitous computing rapidly expanding all around us is fundamentally changing the way we work, play and communicate. The foundational force of Moore’s Law has driven breakthroughs in modern cities, transportation, healthcare, education, and energy production.
---

Document ID: 2
Title: 超过50年的摩尔法律（www.intel.com）
Content: 1965年，戈登·摩尔（Gordon Moore）做出了一个预测，将为我们的现代数字革命树立步伐。从仔细观察新兴趋势的情况下，摩尔推断出计算将在指数速度下显着增加功率和相对成本的降低。洞察力被称为摩尔法，成为电子行业的黄金法则，也是创新的跳板。作为一个联合创始人，戈登为英特尔铺平了道路，使英特尔使越来越快，更小，更实惠的晶体管驱动我们的现代工具和玩具。即使在50多年后，在许多方面都感受到了持久的影响和好处。


###经济影响


###经济影响


绩效 -  AKA力量 - 成本是技术发展的两个关键驱动力。随着越来越多的晶体管适合较小的空间，加工功率提高并提高了能源效率，最终用户的成本都较低。这一发展不仅增强了现有行业并提高了生产率，而且还产生了全新的行业，以廉价和强大的计算为基础。


###技术影响


###技术影响


摩尔的观察将计算从稀有且昂贵的冒险转变为普遍且负担得起的必要性。我们知道并享受的所有现代计算技术都源于摩尔定律的基础。从互联网本身到社交媒体和现代数据分析，所有这些创新直接源于摩尔及其发现。


###社会影响


###社会影响


廉价，无处不在的计算在我们周围迅速扩展，这从根本上改变了我们的工作，玩耍和交流方式。摩尔法律的基础力量在现代城市，运输，医疗保健，教育和能源生产方面取得了突破。

Title: 超过50年的摩尔法律（www.intel.com）
Content: 1965年，戈登·摩尔（Gordon Moore）做出了一个预测，将为我们的现代数字革命树立步伐。从仔细观察新兴趋势的情况下，摩尔推断出计算将在指数速度下显着增加功率和相对成本的降低。洞察力被称为摩尔法，成为电子行业的黄金法则，也是创新的跳板。作为一个联合创始人，戈登为英特尔铺平了道路，使英特尔使越来越快，更小，更实惠的晶体管驱动我们的现代工具和玩具。即使在50多年后，在许多方面都感受到了持久的影响和好处。


###经济影响


###经济影响


绩效 -  AKA力量 - 成本是技术发展的两个关键驱动力。随着越来越多的晶体管适合较小的空间，加工功率提高并提高了能源效率，最终用户的成本都较低。这一发展不仅增强了现有行业并提高了生产率，而且还产生了全新的行业，以廉价和强大的计算为基础。


###技术影响


###技术影响


摩尔的观察将计算从稀有且昂贵的冒险转变为普遍且负担得起的必要性。我们知道并享受的所有现代计算技术都源于摩尔定律的基础。从互联网本身到社交媒体和现代数据分析，所有这些创新直接源于摩尔及其发现。


###社会影响


###社会影响


廉价，无处不在的计算在我们周围迅速扩展，这从根本上改变了我们的工作，玩耍和交流方式。摩尔法律的基础力量在现代城市，运输，医疗保健，教育和能源生产方面取得了突破。

Document ID: 2
Title: Over 50 Years of Moore's Law (www.intel.com)
Content: In 1965, Gordon Moore made a prediction that would set the pace for our modern digital revolution. From careful observation of an emerging trend, Moore extrapolated that computing would dramatically increase in power, and decrease in relative cost, at an exponential pace. The insight, known as Moore’s Law, became the golden rule for the electronics industry, and a springboard for innovation. As a co-founder, Gordon paved the path for Intel to make the ever faster, smaller, more affordable transistors that drive our modern tools and toys. Even over 50 years later, the lasting impact and benefits are felt in many ways.


### Economic Impact


### Economic Impact


Performance—aka power—and cost are two key drivers of technological development. As more transistors fit into smaller spaces, processing power increased and energy efficiency improved, all at a lower cost for the end user. This development not only enhanced existing industries and increased productivity, but it has spawned whole new industries empowered by cheap and powerful computing.


### Technological Impact


### Technological Impact


Moore’s observation transformed computing from a rare and expensive venture into a pervasive and affordable necessity. All of the modern computing technology we know and enjoy sprang from the foundation laid by Moore’s Law. From the Internet itself, to social media and modern data analytics, all these innovations stem directly from Moore and his findings.


### Societal Impact


### Societal Impact


The inexpensive, ubiquitous computing rapidly expanding all around us is fundamentally changing the way we work, play and communicate. The foundational force of Moore’s Law has driven breakthroughs in modern cities, transportation, healthcare, education, and energy production.
---

claim: 若碎片轨道稍远，重力凝聚可形成一颗或多颗卫星
question_src: 为什么有些行星形成环而其他行星则形成卫星？
all_claims: 行星周围的物质命运取决于距离、温度和行星质量：若碎片位于行星罗什极限附近，强潮汐力阻止其聚成大块，只能维持为颗粒轨道结构，即环系[2]。
若碎片轨道稍远，重力凝聚可形成一颗或多颗卫星[2]。
环多由冰尘组成，靠近太阳的内行星环境过热，冰无法长期存在，因而难保留大环，而远离太阳的巨行星低温使冰尘稳定[1]。
巨行星质量大，早期吸积了丰富的气体、尘埃和冰，不仅为规则卫星提供“建材”，也能捕获过境小天体成为不规则卫星，而内侧岩质行星周围材料稀少，往往只能在偶发碰撞后抛射物质形成单一大月，如地月系[3]。
因此，环或卫星的出现，是行星引力、轨道位置、成分与形成史共同作用的结果。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: UCSB Science Line (scienceline.ucsb.edu)
Content: There's actually still scientific dispute about the exact answer to this question. The solar system formed from a giant cloud of gas and particles (literally stardust--the remains of a star that had exploded) billions of years ago. The "dust" clumped together to form the planets. Some of the leftover dust formed the moons of the planets (although the origin of Earth's moon is still up for debate). Some of this dust was too close to the planet to form stable moons, and instead formed rings. It is likely that large rings couldn't form on inner planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars) because the rings are made of frozen icy dust, and the sun is too hot this close to it for the rings to form.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 好奇心：为什么某些行星有戒指？ （news.wisc.edu）
Content: Lattis解释说：“关于行星环的理论有多种理论，例如土星周围的奇妙环，但我们不能确定它们是如何形成的。”


一种理论是，与行星及其主要卫星同时形成的环。在这种情况下，如果材料靠近行星，则行星的引力拉力太强，无法将其合并到月亮中，而粒子否则会形成月亮以环为环。


另一个想法是，月球或彗星的近距离呼叫导致地球的引力潮汐力破坏了这些尸体，然后碎屑变成了环形系统。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Deanna Rostic, St. Catharines, Ontario, Canada (astronomy.com)
Content: The larger volume of space and lower gravity of the Sun in the giant-planet region allowed Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune to form like solar systems in miniature. We think each of them pulled in lots of material and had a disk of gas, dust, and ice surrounding it during formation. Any dust and ice not incorporated into the planet itself would have coalesced into the regular moons we see today around the giant planets. These satellites are in nearly circular orbits near the equators of their host planets, such as the four Galilean satellites around Jupiter and Titan around Saturn, which are all composed of large fractions of ice.


Because the giant planets gravitationally dominate a very large area, they also can efficiently capture passing objects as moons, which we call irregular satellites. These irregular moons are relatively small and have orbits with large inclinations, eccentricities, and semimajor axes.


In contrast, the terrestrial planets formed much closer to the Sun with much less material around them. They grew slowly by accreting many small rocky planetesimals and never grew massive enough to capture a disk of gas and dust. Earth’s Moon probably formed through a direct collision. Any large object striking a planet would have thrown material off the world into orbit, allowing it to coalesce into a moon.
---

Document ID: 2
Title: Curiosities: Why do some planets have rings? (news.wisc.edu)
Content: “There are various theories about planetary rings, like the fantastic rings around Saturn, but we cannot say for sure how they are formed,” explains Lattis.


One theory is that the rings formed at the same time as the planet and its major moons. In this case, if material is close to the planet, the planet’s gravitational pull is too strong to coalesce into a moon and the particles that would otherwise form a moon spread out in orbit around the planet as a ring.


Another idea is that a close call by a moon or comet results in the planet’s gravitational tidal force breaking up those bodies, the debris of which then becomes a ring system.

In this case, if material is close to the planet, the planet’s gravitational pull is too strong to coalesce into a moon and the particles that would otherwise form a moon spread out in orbit around the planet as a ring.


Another idea is that a close call by a moon or comet results in the planet’s gravitational tidal force breaking up those bodies, the debris of which then becomes a ring system.

Content: 巨型星空区域中太大的太空和较低的太阳重力使木星，土星，天王星和海王星在微型中形成了太阳系。我们认为他们中的每个人都插入了很多材料，并在编队期间有一块气体，灰尘和冰。任何未纳入地球本身的灰尘和冰块都将合并为我们今天在巨型行星周围看到的常规卫星。这些卫星在其宿主行星的赤道附近几乎是圆形轨道，例如木星周围的四个伽利略卫星和土星周围的泰坦，这些卫星都由大量的冰组成。


由于巨型行星在重力上占据了很大的区域，因此它们也可以有效地捕获经过的物体作为月亮，我们称之为不规则的卫星。这些不规则的月亮相对较小，并且具有较大倾斜，偏心率和半轴轴的轨道。


相比之下，陆地行星靠近太阳，周围的材料要少得多。它们通过积聚许多岩石的小行星而缓慢地生长，从不足够大的巨大捕获气体和灰尘。地球的月亮可能是通过直接碰撞形成的。撞击星球的任何大物体都会将材料从世界上扔到轨道上，从而使其合并为月球。

question_src: 为什么太阳能系统看起来主要是“平坦”？
all_claims: 太阳系呈现主要位于同一平面内的“扁盘”结构，关键原因在于角动量守恒：处于相对孤立状态的原始星云在演化过程中，其总旋转量必须保持恒定[1]。
当云中的尘埃和气体不断相互碰撞时，粒子虽可向任意方向移动，但垂直于旋转平面的上行与下行运动相互抵消，使系统逐渐失去高度[1]。
随着这些“上下”动量的消散而角动量仍需维持，物质只能在旋转平面内重新分布，于是云体被“压扁”成近似二维的圆盘[2]。
这种几何趋平的过程持续数百万年，最终让行星、公转轨道以及大多数小体都落在同一平面附近，形成我们今天看到的平坦太阳系[3]。

Title: Why is the Solar System flat? – How It Works (www.howitworksdaily.com)
Content: This is due to a rule known as the conservation of angular momentum – the total amount of spinning in any isolated system, such as the Solar System, will always remain constant. This allowed the cloud to flatten over time, losing its height and becoming the roughly two-dimensional disc we see today.

Title: Discover how the solar system, which started as a shapeless spherical blob ended up being flat (www.britannica.com)
Content: As the particles bump into each other, all the up and down motion tends to cancel out, it's energy lost in crashing and clumping. Yet, the whole mass must continue spinning, inexorably, because in our universe, the total amount of spinning in any isolated system always stays the same. So over time, through collisions and crashes, the cloud loses its loft and flattens into a spinning, roughly two dimensional, disk shape, like a solar system or spiral galaxy.

question_src: 为什么太阳能系统看起来主要是“平坦”？
all_claims: 太阳系呈现主要位于同一平面内的“扁盘”结构，关键原因在于角动量守恒：处于相对孤立状态的原始星云在演化过程中，其总旋转量必须保持恒定[1]。
当云中的尘埃和气体不断相互碰撞时，粒子虽可向任意方向移动，但垂直于旋转平面的上行与下行运动相互抵消，使系统逐渐失去高度[1]。
随着这些“上下”动量的消散而角动量仍需维持，物质只能在旋转平面内重新分布，于是云体被“压扁”成近似二维的圆盘[2]。
这种几何趋平的过程持续数百万年，最终让行星、公转轨道以及大多数小体都落在同一平面附近，形成我们今天看到的平坦太阳系[3]。

Document ID: 2
Title: Why is the Solar System flat? – How It Works (www.howitworksdaily.com)
Content: This is due to a rule known as the conservation of angular momentum – the total amount of spinning in any isolated system, such as the Solar System, will always remain constant. This allowed the cloud to flatten over time, losing its height and becoming the roughly two-dimensional disc we see today.

Title: Discover how the solar system, which started as a shapeless spherical blob ended up being flat (www.britannica.com)
Content: As the particles bump into each other, all the up and down motion tends to cancel out, it's energy lost in crashing and clumping. Yet, the whole mass must continue spinning, inexorably, because in our universe, the total amount of spinning in any isolated system always stays the same. So over time, through collisions and crashes, the cloud loses its loft and flattens into a spinning, roughly two dimensional, disk shape, like a solar system or spiral galaxy.

claim: 大多数量产汽油车把红线设在约6,250-6,500 rpm，主要因为这是制造商验证后的“最大安全转速”，再高零件可靠性和成本都会急剧恶化；红线的本质就是在此转速之前持续运转不会损坏发动机
question_src: 为什么大多数汽车在6,250-6,500 rpm范围内都红线：永远不会降低，很少更高？
all_claims: 大多数量产汽油车把红线设在约6,250-6,500 rpm，主要因为这是制造商验证后的“最大安全转速”，再高零件可靠性和成本都会急剧恶化；红线的本质就是在此转速之前持续运转不会损坏发动机[1]。
现代内燃机的技术与材料使其极限通常落在4,000-7,000 rpm 区间[3]，而6,000 rpm 上下既能充分利用气门机构、活塞平均速度与润滑系统的安全裕度，又不必采用赛车级轻量活瓣、钛连杆等昂贵部件。
另一方面，普通道路驾驶的功率需求在2,000-3,000 rpm 即可满足[2]，因此继续提高红线对用户体验的收益有限，却会带来更高油耗、排放与噪声，同时需要更短的变速比，牺牲巡航经济性。
综合耐久、成本、法规与实用性能，6,250-6,500 rpm 成为绝大多数乘用车最经济也最安全的红线区间。

Today electric motors for series production vehicles reach a maximum rotational speed of more than 20,000 rpm.

现代内燃机的技术与材料使其极限通常落在4,000-7,000 rpm 区间[3]，而6,000 rpm 上下既能充分利用气门机构、活塞平均速度与润滑系统的安全裕度，又不必采用赛车级轻量活瓣、钛连杆等昂贵部件。
另一方面，普通道路驾驶的功率需求在2,000-3,000 rpm 即可满足[2]，因此继续提高红线对用户体验的收益有限，却会带来更高油耗、排放与噪声，同时需要更短的变速比，牺牲巡航经济性。
综合耐久、成本、法规与实用性能，6,250-6,500 rpm 成为绝大多数乘用车最经济也最安全的红线区间。
claims_retained: 大多数量产汽油车把红线设在约6,250-6,500 rpm，主要因为这是制造商验证后的“最大安全转速”，再高零件可靠性和成本都会急剧恶化；红线的本质就是在此转速之前持续运转不会损坏发动机[1]。
现代内燃机的技术与材料使其极限通常落在4,000-7,000 rpm 区间[3]，而6,000 rpm 上下既能充分利用气门机构、活塞平均速度与润滑系统的安全裕度，又不必采用赛车级轻量活瓣、钛连杆等昂贵部件。
另一方面，普通道路驾驶的功率需求在2,000-3,000 rpm 即可满足[2]，因此继续提高红线对用户体验的收益有限，却会带来更高油耗、排放与噪声，同时需要更短的变速比，牺牲巡航经济性。

Title: Laser Pointer Safety - Laser effects on cameras, camcorders and DLPs (www.laserpointersafety.com)
Content: Lasers emit concentrated beams of light, which can heat up sensitive surfaces (like the eye's retina) and cause damage. Camera sensors are, in general, more susceptible to damage than the human eye.


For large scale shows such as televised concerts, laser show producers work with clients to avoid TV camera locations and video projectors (ILDA Members, see this page for details; login required). However, it is not possible for laser show producers to be responsible for all cameras, smartphones and camcorders which might be used at a show.


Tips for audience members with cameras when lasers are in use




If you attend a laser show as an audience member, you should take reasonable precautions not to let a laser beam DIRECTLY enter your camera lens.


* You can photograph the beams in midair, or doing graphics on a screen. If you can't see the laser source (projector output aperture or bounce mirror) in your viewfinder, this means you're not getting the full beam power into your lens. Indirect viewing like this should not cause damage.




* Avoid beams which are coming straight into your lens (or bounced off a mirror or other reflective surface and then into your lens). The damage potential is much greater when the entire beam power enters the camera lens.


Degree of camera damage




The degree of damage can vary widely.


* We have seen cases of minor damage, such as small areas of a few pixels which no longer work. The pixels are not noticeable unless in an area of uniform color such as a blue sky.




* In more extreme cases, there may be larger or more extensive dead-pixel areas. Or there may be "burn in" of a laser image. The damage is readily noticeable in most photos or videos. In this case, the camera is ruined for quality use. The image below shows numerous laser-

question_src: 开尔文量表如何可能进行负温度？
all_claims: 在热力学中温度定义为 T = (∂S/∂E)⁻¹，当能量增加反而使熵减少时 ∂S/∂E 为负，T 就成为负值；这只有在能级数目有限、存在能量上限的系统里才可能发生[1]。
通过外部“抽运”制造占据反转，使高能级原子的数目多于低能级，把这种异常分布代入玻尔兹曼公式即可算出负温度[2]。
负开尔文并不“更冷”，相反它比任何正温度都“更热”，若与普通物体相接触会把热量传给后者[1]。
实验上，科研人员在光学晶格中突然把“山谷”变为“山丘”，令原子整体跃迁到能带上缘，从而制备出负温度的超冷气体，验证了这一概念[3]。
因此，开尔文量表出现负温度并非违背绝对零度定义，而是源于特定有限能级系统中的熵-能量关系反转。

question_src: 流感病毒为什么突变？
all_claims: 流感病毒之所以不断突变，首先是因为在复制过程中会出现小规模基因改变，即“抗原漂移”，这些突变可导致其表面蛋白血凝素（HA）和神经氨酸酶（NA）发生变化[1]；随着病毒持续复制，这些微小改变会逐渐累积，最终形成在抗原性质上有所差异的新病毒株[3]。
其次，流感 A 病毒还可能经历一次性的大幅度基因重排或“抗原转移”，从而突然产生全新的 HA 和/或 NA 蛋白，使病毒特性发生质变[4]。
这种重大突变的一种情形是动物中的流感病毒获得感染人类的能力，与人类或其他动物病毒交换基因片段后产生新型病毒[5]。
从分子机制看，病毒突变与其复制并复制自身遗传物质的方式紧密相关，这一过程本身易于出错，因此不断孕育新的变体[6]。

question_src: 如果鼻子被炎症引起，那么阻塞开关侧如何自由？
all_claims: 即使感冒等炎症让下鼻甲（下涡轮增压）黏膜总体肿胀，鼻腔仍会接受自主神经系统驱动的“鼻周期”管理：血流被周期性地重新分配，使一个鼻孔血管扩张、充血，约 3–6 小时后再把血液抽回并转向另一侧[1]；当血液撤离时，原先肿胀的黏膜迅速瘪下，腾出更多空气通道，因此“堵”侧就感觉突然畅通，而新充血的一侧则变得相对拥塞。
炎症会放大每侧的肿胀程度，但不会停止这一血流开关，所以人们在生病期间依然会体验到两侧交替的“忽堵忽通”。
此外，因下鼻甲负责加湿与加温空气，它们在炎症时更易因工作量大而肿胀，但随着血流重新分配、炎性反应逐步减轻，阻塞侧也会随之自由[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 这是令人沮丧的原因一次，鼻子的一侧一次被阻塞（www.sciencealert.com）
Content: 白天，侧面切换，另一个鼻孔进入“工作模式”，但是为什么呢？


这个过程是由恰当命名的自主神经系统自动化的，该系统是控制人体本身所做的许多事情的同一系统，例如消化和心率。


对于您的鼻子，该系统控制您的“鼻周期”，因此每个鼻孔都可以有效运行。


根据美国国家医学图书馆的说法，鼻周期发生在白天几次，只有在您的鼻子比平时堵塞更多的情况下，才会引起您的注意。


为了打开鼻子的一侧并关闭另一侧，您的身体用血液充气，就像一个人在鼻子中勃起一样。


詹妮弗·舒（Jennifer Shu）报告说：“血流增加会导致一个鼻孔的拥塞约3至6个小时，然后再转向另一侧。当一个人躺下时，充血也会增加，当头部转向一侧时，这可能是特别明显的。”
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The Science Behind Why Only One Nostril Clogs When You’re Sick (www.menshealth.com)
Content: Structures in both sides of your nose called inferior turbinates are responsible for warming and humidifying air before it reaches your lungs, says Dr. Roditi. This protects your lungs by reducing dryness and irritation.


That process is a lot of work. So your nose funnels its resources more to one side than the other to make the process more efficient.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Here's The Frustrating Reason Only One Side of Your Nose Gets Blocked at a Time (www.sciencealert.com)
Content: During the day, the sides switch and the other nostril goes into 'work mode', but why?


This process is automated by the aptly named autonomic nervous system, which is the same system that controls many things your body does all by itself such as digestion and heart rate.


For your nose, this system controls your 'nasal cycle', so that each nostril operates effectively.


The nasal cycle happens, according to the US National Library of Medicine, several times during the day, and is only brought to your attention if your nose is clogged up more than usual.


In order to open one side of your nose and close the other, your body inflates tissue with blood in the same way that a man gets an erection, except, you know, in your nose.


"Increased blood flow causes congestion in one nostril for about 3 to 6 hours before switching to the other side. There is also increased congestion when one is lying down, which can be especially noticeable when the head is turned to one side," Jennifer Shu reports for CNN.
---

这个过程是很多工作。因此，您的鼻子比另一侧更能使其资源更加高效。

all_claims: 涂抹润滑物（如凡士林、唾液、Crisco）可显著削弱球的转速，使其在飞行中失去升力并突然下沉，形同速度更快的分裂球，击球手难以及时判断落点[1]。
而把松焦油等黏性物质抹在手指或球缝上，则能增强抓地力，投手可施加更高后旋，令直球停空更久、曲球折弯更大，从而扩大好球区边缘的可利用空间[1]。

all_claims: 涂抹润滑物（如凡士林、唾液、Crisco）可显著削弱球的转速，使其在飞行中失去升力并突然下沉，形同速度更快的分裂球，击球手难以及时判断落点[1]。
而把松焦油等黏性物质抹在手指或球缝上，则能增强抓地力，投手可施加更高后旋，令直球停空更久、曲球折弯更大，从而扩大好球区边缘的可利用空间[1]。
松焦油或防晒霜还会让断球“咬”得更紧，使滑球、曲线球晃动幅度扩大[2]。
更牢的握球同样降低失控球率，一些击球手甚至支持这种做法，因为球不易失投砸人[3]。

question_src: 四大会做什么？
all_claims: “四大”指德勤、普华永道、毕马威和安永，是全球规模最大的专业服务网络[1]。
它们为标准普尔500指数绝大多数公司审核财报[2]，核心业务是审计，并可提供交易咨询，如业务建模、并购及估值等服务，帮助企业评估和推动各类交易[1]。
此外，四大还提供广泛的咨询、税务、风险咨询与精算服务，满足企业治理与合规需要[1]；亦能提供估值、市场研究、保证及法律咨询等专业支持[2]。
当遇到潜在法律纠纷时，四大可进行法医式审核，对公司记录进行深入检查以备法院使用[1]。
claims_retained: 它们为标准普尔500指数绝大多数公司审核财报[2]，核心业务是审计，并可提供交易咨询，如业务建模、并购及估值等服务，帮助企业评估和推动各类交易[1]。

Title: What Are the Big Four? (www.investopedia.com)
Content: * The "Big Four" refers to the four largest accounting firms in the United States.
* These four firms audit the financial statements for the vast majority of companies in the S&P 500.
* In addition to their auditing services, the Big Four also provides consulting, valuation, market research, assurance, and legal advisory services.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What Are the Big Four? (www.investopedia.com)
Content: With 360-degree views of companies and industries, the Big Four are authorities in the business. They have extensive recruiting and training programs for fresh graduates and sought-after passageways for tax and consulting professionals to and from many industrial sectors.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Reforming the Big Four (www.economist.com)
Content: Past reforms banned them from providing both an audit and certain consulting services to the same client, but conflicts of interest remain.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: Reforming the Big Four (www.economist.com)
Content: Many countries tightened the rules after a scandal in 2001 sank Enron, an energy-trading firm, and its auditor, Arthur Andersen. In America the number of accounts that are restated because of a material error has fallen sharply over the past decade.
---
Document ID: 6
Title: Reforming the Big Four (www.economist.com)
Content: Instead regulators should sharpen tools that are already available in Europe. They could lower the cap on non-audit fees charged to an audit client from today’s generous level of 70% of the audit fee. Under rules introduced in 2016, British companies with the same auditor for ten years must re-tender; they are forced to rotate after 20. Such rules look draconian to American eyes, where the average auditor tenure for the first 21 companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average to have made disclosures this year is a cosy 66 years. New research finds that auditors are most likely to find misstatements early in their tenure; by the tenth year, the benefits of a fresh pair of eyes are lost. Academics also find that the Big Four’s fees rise with tenure. Even Britain’s 20-year limit is too long.


Auditors in many countries are already required to add flesh to the bare bones of the audit opinion. That is to be encouraged. Transparency over the main points of contention with management, and the size of revisions made to the accounts as a result of scrutiny, would cast light on auditors’ successes, not just their failures. And that in turn would help investors to assess auditors’ performance.

question_src: 当您感到肠胃疼痛（例如胃痉挛？）时，为什么它会倾向于弯曲到球中并保持脚的温暖，为什么以及如何缓解疼痛？
all_claims: 当腹部平滑肌不受意志控制地强烈收缩引发胃痉挛时，人会本能地蜷成胎儿姿势；此时腹壁放松、背部支撑增强，肠管受到的牵拉与压迫随之减少，膝盖贴近胸部还可为缺乏骨骼保护的腹部提供“护甲”，令大脑获得温暖与安全的讯号，降低因压力激活的交感神经反应，从而缓解疼痛[1]。
把脚收拢和双臂环抱也能减少散热、微升体温，进一步促进副交感神经活动，抑制平滑肌痉挛与炎症。
由于胃肠道属于无法由意志直接调控的平滑肌，人们在胃流感或食物中毒时无法主动减慢其过快蠕动[2]，因此只能借助上述姿势，并配合热敷腹部、少量多次补水、电解质、避免油腻刺激等方法，促使神经系统转入“休息与消化”模式，间接减弱痉挛；若剧痛持续或伴高热、呕血，应及时就医。
claims_retained: 由于胃肠道属于无法由意志直接调控的平滑肌，人们在胃流感或食物中毒时无法主动减慢其过快蠕动[2]，因此只能借助上述姿势，并配合热敷腹部、少量多次补水、电解质、避免油腻刺激等方法，促使神经系统转入“休息与消化”模式，间接减弱痉挛；若剧痛持续或伴高热、呕血，应及时就医。

question_src: 我们都知道光线每秒行驶186,282英里。但是它如何旅行。是什么为这种速度提供了推力？为什么它会旅行而不是坐在那里呢？
all_claims: 光不是被某种“推力”推动的粒子流，而是一对相互交替的电场与磁场组成的电磁波：当带电粒子在光源处振动时，它产生的电振动会自动诱导垂直的磁振动，这对振荡从源头不断向外扩散，无需任何物质介质；光因此能够在真空传播 [1]。
在真空中，这种电磁波总以每秒约186,282英里（约3×10⁸ m/s）的固定速度传播，无论场强变化得多快或多慢，速度都保持不变 [2]。
这一速度由真空本身的电、磁性质决定，而非由外力驱动，因此“推进”这个概念并不适用；光之所以持续前进，是因为电场变化必然产生磁场变化，磁场变化又必然产生电场变化，它们彼此“自我维持”成连续的波动。
没有介质的阻尼，波不会衰减，因而能从遥远恒星穿行数十亿光年仍抵达地球 [3]。

Title: 轻型旅行如何？ （sciencing.com）
Content: 在1800年代中期，苏格兰物理学家James Clerk Maxwell确立了光线是一种电磁能，在波浪中行进。电磁振动的性质解释了它在没有介质的情况下如何设法这样做的问题。当带电的粒子振动时，它会产生一种自动诱导磁性的电振动 - 物理学家经常可视化发生在垂直平面中的这些振动。配对的振荡从来源向外传播；除了渗透到宇宙的电磁场外，没有介质需要进行它们。
---

Title: UCSB Science Line (scienceline.ucsb.edu)
Content: When I say "waves of electric and magnetic fields," I'm talking about something similar to the waves in the rope. Similar to wiggling the end of the rope, we can change the electric or magnetic field at one point, and that disturbance travels away from us. (One way to change the magnetic field at a point is to hold a magnet there, then wiggle it back and forth.) Unlike the wave in the rope, these waves actually travel away from us in all directions. It turns out that in a vacuum, for example in outer space, these waves travel at exactly the speed of light! It doesn't matter how rapidly the fields wiggle back and forth, they will always travel at the same speed. (In air, the waves go ever so slightly slower than in vacuum, and in glass, they can go only about two-thirds as fast as they would in vacuum, but this is not important right now. From now on, when I talk about the speed of light, I mean the speed of light in a vacuum, and I'm talking about waves traveling in a vacuum.) The conclusion that physicists have drawn from this result is that light consists of waves of electric and magnetic fields. This is a fascinating result: that we learn something about light by studying magnets and electrical currents.

Title: Q & A: Does light travel forever? | Department of Physics (van.physics.illinois.edu)
Content: In contrast, light waves can travel through a vacuum, and do not require a medium. In empty space, the wave does not dissipate (grow smaller) no matter how far it travels, because the wave is not interacting with anything else. This is why light from distant stars can travel through space for billions of light-years and still reach us on earth. However, light can also travel within some materials, like glass and water. In this case, some light is absorbed and lost as heat, just like sound. So, underwater, or in our atmosphere, light will only travel some finite range (which is different depending on the properties of the material it travels through).

Title: How Does Light Travel? (sciencing.com)
Content: In the mid 1800s, Scottish physicist James Clerk Maxwell established that light is a form of electromagnetic energy that travels in waves. The question of how it manages to do so in the absence of a medium is explained by the nature of electromagnetic vibrations. When a charged particle vibrates, it produces an electrical vibration that automatically induces a magnetic one -- physicists often visualize these vibrations occurring in perpendicular planes. The paired oscillations propagate outward from the source; no medium, except for the electromagnetic field that permeates the universe, is required to conduct them.

claim: 当狗等哺乳动物踩到刺或木屑时，常见的处理是立即清创并拔除：兽医建议先以温暖肥皂水冲洗伤口、再用消毒镊子夹出刺片，随后再次冲洗以降低感染风险
question_src: 动物如何处理脚上的刺/荆棘/碎片等？
all_claims: 当狗等哺乳动物踩到刺或木屑时，常见的处理是立即清创并拔除：兽医建议先以温暖肥皂水冲洗伤口、再用消毒镊子夹出刺片，随后再次冲洗以降低感染风险[3]。
若异物留在体内且无法及时取出，机体往往无法完全吸收或分解它，免疫系统会在刺片周围形成炎性组织并随着皮肤更新逐渐把异物向外顶出，最终将其排出体表[4]。
某些动物还通过“预防”减少足部受伤；例如刺龙虾壳上向前排列的坚硬棘刺在移动时可挡开尖锐物或掠食者，降低异物刺入脚部的概率[2]。
综上，动物应对脚上刺/荆棘/碎片的方式大致分为：主动拔除、免疫排异及结构性防护三种机制。

claim: Microsoft Internet Explorer 存在编号为 CVE-2018-0954 的远程代码执行漏洞，其根本原因是脚本引擎在处理内存中对象时可能发生损坏，从而允许注入并执行任意代码
question_src: MS Internet Explorer脆弱性以及为什么Chrome和Firefox不会受到影响？
all_claims: Microsoft Internet Explorer 存在编号为 CVE-2018-0954 的远程代码执行漏洞，其根本原因是脚本引擎在处理内存中对象时可能发生损坏，从而允许注入并执行任意代码 [1]。
攻击者只需诱导受害者访问专门制作的网页，即可在计算机上安装程序、查看、修改或删除数据，甚至完全接管系统 [4]。
这一高风险与 IE 的架构密切相关：它依赖深度集成于 Windows 的 Trident 引擎和 ActiveX 技术，浏览器进程一旦失守，恶意代码即可继承较高系统权限 [2]。
相较之下，Chrome 与 Firefox 采用多进程“沙箱”模型，将网页渲染、脚本执行等高危操作隔离在受限进程中，即使发生内存破坏也难以逃离沙箱、影响整机 [3]。
因此，同样的攻击手法在 Chrome 或 Firefox 上通常只能导致受限进程崩溃，而无法取得系统控制权，使其不受上述 IE 脆弱性的影响。

question_src: 那么，宇宙“宇宙热死亡”会发生什么？
all_claims: 宇宙“热死亡”是指宇宙熵增加到最大可达值时的终极状态，此时无法再从任何过程中获得有用功[2]。
在这一阶段，所有温度差或其他可被利用来做功的差异都消失，宇宙各处温度趋于均一，因而不再存在热力学自由能[1]。
热量停止流动，机械、电气等能量形式也随之达到平衡，使得通过任何方式提取功都变得不可能[3]。
结果是能量在整个宇宙中极度均匀分布，没有可重复利用的能量或“热裂缝”，宇宙就像被彻底“冷冻”一般，进入一种对人类而言形同死亡的静态[4]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Heat death of the universe (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The heat death of the universe (also known as the Big Chill or Big Freeze)[1] is a theory on the ultimate fate of the universe, which suggests the universe would evolve to a state of no thermodynamic free energy and would therefore be unable to sustain processes that increase entropy. Heat death does not imply any particular absolute temperature; it only requires that temperature differences or other processes may no longer be exploited to perform work. In the language of physics, this is when the universe reaches thermodynamic equilibrium

Title: What exactly is the heat death of the universe and where can I find out more? (www.physlink.com)
Content: Since heat ceases to flow, no more work can be acquired from heat transfer. question_src: 电话如何工作？
all_claims: 当你说话时，手机内的微型麦克风把声波振动转换成对应的电信号[1]；这些信号被微芯片数字化成数字串并封装进无线电波，经天线发射[1]。
无线电波以接近光速（约30 万公里/秒）飞向最近的基站[1]。
运营商核心网随后对信号进行路由，将其送往对方手机所在区域的基站[2]；在长距离传输中，信号通常沿光纤，也可能通过卫星或微波塔跨越海陆[3]。
到达目标基站后，信号再以无线形式发射至对方手机，该手机把数字数据还原为电信号，并由扬声器重新转换成声音，让对方听见[4]。
整个过程中，模拟声波→电信号→数字信息→无线电波→数字信息→电信号→声音的多次转换，确保了语音清晰、实时地在全球范围传递。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 手机如何工作？ （www.explainthatstuff.com）
Content: 当您说话到手机时，手机中的一个微小麦克风会将您的声音上下声音转换为相应的上下电信号模式。手机中的微芯片将这些信号变成数字字符串。这些数字被打包到无线电波中，并从手机的天线中射出（在某些国家，天线称为空中）。无线电波以光速在空中竞争，直到到达最近的手机桅杆。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: How do cellphones work? (www.explainthatstuff.com)
Content: Calls made from a cellphone to another cellphone on the same network travel to their destination by being routed to the base station nearest to the destination phone, and finally to that phone itself.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How Telephones Work (electronics.howstuffworks.com)
Content: Your voice normally travels over a fiber-optic line to the office of the receiving party, but it may also be transmitted by satellite or by microwave towers.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: How Do Cell Phones Work? – Pong Pulse (pongcase.com)
Content: When you chat with your friend on your cell phone, your phone converts your voice into an electrical signal, which is then transmitted via radio waves to the nearest cell tower. The network of cell towers then relays the radio wave to your friend’s cell phone, which converts it to an electrical signal and then back to sound again
---

Document ID: 2
Title: How Do Gas Pumps “Know” When Your Car’s Tank Is Full? (www.rd.com)
Content: And pressure has built up in the tank; that pressure is released as the air escapes. McKenzie compares it to holding your thumb over a garden hose: “Blocking part of the hose [increases] the pressure of the water inside, [causing] the water leaving to spray out at an even greater velocity.” When you start to pump gas, the pipe, which has been “blocked” like the hose, releases the air quickly. “This expelled air brings with it a pressure that’s strong enough to hold the valve in the open position,” McKenzie says.


So that’s what happens while you’re filling up your tank. And once it’s full of gas, gasoline, not air, now reaches the pipe inside the nozzle, which evens out the pressure. As McKenzie explains, this creates “a small suctioning force (known as the Venturi effect) that switches the valve to the off position.”

为捕捉细小波动，这些交易往往使用衍生品和高杠杆，使油价对新闻、利率、冲突等极度敏感，波动剧烈，令企业难以制定预算，增加宏观经济不确定性。
价格过度受情绪驱动而偏离供需基本面，还可能误导产油国投资决策和消费者行为，形成资源错配。

question_src: 保险中的子摄取和豁免
all_claims: 在保险实践中，“代位求偿”（subrogation）指保险人向被保险人理赔后，继承其对造成损失的第三方行使追偿权，以收回赔款并防止责任方逃避责任；而“放弃代位求偿”（waiver of subrogation）则是在保单或相关合同中约定，保险公司自愿放弃上述追偿权[1]。
这样做的直接好处是避免冗长的诉讼及其费用，并减少房东与租户、承包方之间等合同当事人的冲突[2]。
此类条款最常见于商业综合责任、建筑或租赁合同的保险中，被视为风险由一方转移至另一方的重要机制[3]。
然而，一旦放弃追偿，保险人失去通过诉讼收回损失的途径，可能以提高保费或限制承保范围来弥补风险；因此企业或个人在同意放弃代位求偿之前，应权衡保费变化、合同要求及自身潜在责任，确保整体风险处于可控水平。

all_claims: 当我们专注于电脑或手机上不断移动的画面时，眼睛向大脑传递“正在发生运动”的视觉信号，而身体却保持静止，这种视觉与身体感受的不一致被称为感觉冲突[5]；与此同时，内耳等平衡受体并未检测到相应的位移，进一步加大了大脑接收的矛盾信息，导致中枢神经系统将之误判为潜在威胁并触发恶心反射[6]。
对于偏头痛易感者，屏幕的强光还可能诱发或加重光敏感，进而放大恶心感，因此在恢复时应减少强光和屏幕暴露[1]。
claims_retained: 当我们专注于电脑或手机上不断移动的画面时，眼睛向大脑传递“正在发生运动”的视觉信号，而身体却保持静止，这种视觉与身体感受的不一致被称为感觉冲突[5]；与此同时，内耳等平衡受体并未检测到相应的位移，进一步加大了大脑接收的矛盾信息，导致中枢神经系统将之误判为潜在威胁并触发恶心反射[6]。

Content: Alcohol is a diuretic, which causes us to urinate more and, consequently, expel more electrolytes (essential salts and minerals) than the body needs. This makes us dehydrated and not quite on top form: we may be tired, listless, lacking mental acuity and even dizzy.

Increased acid production, inflammation of the stomach lining and delayed stomach emptying all go hand in hand to leave you feeling queasy.

Content: With motion sickness or cyber sickness, your eyes see moving images and signal to the brain that movement is happening.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Perfume Poisoning: Symptoms, Dangers, and What to Do (www.healthline.com)
Content: The scented ingredients in perfume are infused into these alcohols as a way of preserving and stabilizing the product’s desired scent. These alcohols are toxic, and may cause symptoms if swallowed in amounts greater than 30 milliliters.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Taste and Smell (www.brainfacts.org)
Content: Taste and smell are separate senses with their own receptor organs, yet they are intimately entwined. Tastants, chemicals in foods, are detected by taste buds, which consist of special sensory cells. When stimulated, these cells send signals to specific areas of the brain, which make us conscious of the perception of taste. Similarly, specialized cells in the nose pick up odorants, airborne odor molecules. Odorants stimulate receptor proteins found on hairlike cilia at the tips of the sensory cells, a process that initiates a neural response. Ultimately, messages about taste and smell converge, allowing us to detect the flavors of food.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Taste and Smell (www.brainfacts.org)
Content: Airborne odor molecules, called odorants, are detected by specialized sensory neurons located in a small patch of mucus membrane lining the roof of the nose. Axons of these sensory cells pass through perforations in the overlying bone and enter two elongated olfactory bulbs lying against the underside of the frontal lobe of the brain.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: 味道和气味|无限生物学（courses.lumenlearning.com）
Content: 气味和味道的感觉在喉咙的后部结合在一起。当您在闻到的东西之前品尝某种东西时，气味在内部徘徊在鼻子上，使您闻到它的味道。气味和味道都使用化学感受器，这实际上意味着它们都在感知化学环境。这种在味道方面的化学感受是通过口腔内的特殊味觉受体的存在，被称为味道细胞，并捆绑在一起形成味蕾。这些味蕾，位于舌头上发现的乳头状，是针对五种方式的五种方式：盐，甜，酸，苦和鲜味。当存在这些受体（即甜或盐分子）并向大脑信号时，这些受体会激活。

Title: Taste and Smell | Boundless Biology (courses.lumenlearning.com)
Content: The senses of smell and taste combine at the back of the throat. When you taste something before you smell it, the smell lingers internally up to the nose causing you to smell it. Both smell and taste use chemoreceptors, which essentially means they are both sensing the chemical environment. This chemoreception in regards to taste, occurs via the presence of specialized taste receptors within the mouth that are referred to as taste cells and are bundled together to form taste buds. These taste buds, located in papillae which are found across the tongue, are specific for the five modalities: salt, sweet, sour, bitter and umami. These receptors are activated when their specific stimulus (i.e. sweet or salt molecules) is present and signals to the brain.

claim: 磁矩（又称磁偶极矩）是衡量物体在磁场中对齐或产生磁场能力的物理量，其大小和方向共同刻画“磁力或产生磁场的其他物体的磁强度和方向”；它本质上是一个矢量量
question_src: 什么是“磁矩”
all_claims: 磁矩（又称磁偶极矩）是衡量物体在磁场中对齐或产生磁场能力的物理量，其大小和方向共同刻画“磁力或产生磁场的其他物体的磁强度和方向”[1]；它本质上是一个矢量量[1]。
磁矩与外磁场相互作用时会产生取向扭矩，这一特性解释了磁针能自动指向磁场方向[2]。
对于载流圆环，磁矩方向垂直于环面，可用右手定则确定[3]。
在原子层面，多数电子自旋磁矩相互抵消，但若某些自旋未被完全抵消，残余自旋磁矩便叠加形成原子的净磁矩，从而赋予材料宏观磁性[4]。
行星亦可表现出磁偶极矩，例如地球与木星的磁偶极矩相对自转轴倾角约10°，而土星的几乎与自转轴重合[5]。
claims_retained: 磁矩（又称磁偶极矩）是衡量物体在磁场中对齐或产生磁场能力的物理量，其大小和方向共同刻画“磁力或产生磁场的其他物体的磁强度和方向”[1]；它本质上是一个矢量量[1]。
磁矩与外磁场相互作用时会产生取向扭矩，这一特性解释了磁针能自动指向磁场方向[2]。
对于载流圆环，磁矩方向垂直于环面，可用右手定则确定[3]。

Title: What's Magnetic Moment? | Stanford Magnets (www.stanfordmagnets.com)
Content: In most matter, there are as many electrons with upward and downward spins, and the magnetic moments they produce will cancel each other out, and the entire atom is not magnetic to the outside. Only the atoms of a few matters have different numbers of electrons in different spin directions. In this way, after the magnetic moments of electrons with opposite spins cancel each other out, the spin magnetic moments of some of the electrons are not canceled, so the atom has a magnetic moment.

claims_retained: 磁矩（又称磁偶极矩）是衡量物体在磁场中对齐或产生磁场能力的物理量，其大小和方向共同刻画“磁力或产生磁场的其他物体的磁强度和方向”[1]；它本质上是一个矢量量[1]。
磁矩与外磁场相互作用时会产生取向扭矩，这一特性解释了磁针能自动指向磁场方向[2]。
对于载流圆环，磁矩方向垂直于环面，可用右手定则确定[3]。

question_src: 即使美国经济的表现与2007年以来一样出色，而我们没有在战争中继续增加？
all_claims: 美国国债持续增加的核心原因是联邦政府几乎年年支出高于收入，形成经常性赤字，因此债务无论战事如何都会累积[1]。
经济自2007年以来表现强劲仅提高了国家的借款能力：经济规模扩大意味着更大的资本市场和更高的税收潜力，政府可以更轻松地发行新债，使得衡量负担的重点转向债务占国内生产总值的比例，而非债务的绝对金额[2]。

---
Document ID: 2
Title: National Debt (www.investopedia.com)
Content: While the debt can be measured in trillions of dollars, it is usually measured as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), the debt-to-GDP ratio. That's because as a country's economy grows, the amount of revenue a government can use to pay its debts grows as well.

In addition, a larger economy generally means the country's capital markets will grow and the government can tap them to issue more debt. This means that a country's ability to pay off debt, and the effect that debt might have on the country's economy, is dependent on how large the debt is as a proportion of the overall economy, not the dollar amount
---

claim: 释放磁盘空间并手动执行“驱动器优化”可以让磁头连续写入、减少等待，从而解除 99% 卡顿
question_src: 为什么将文件加载到99％的情况下，没有问题，然后悬挂着永远的状态？
all_claims: 文件复制显示 99% 时，数据主体几乎已写完，剩余的 1% 通常包含文件系统元数据更新、缓存刷新和碎片整理等收尾操作；如果目标磁盘空间紧张、碎片度高或存在错误，系统为了保证数据完整性会反复寻址与重写，从而让进度条长时间停留在 99% 看似“永远不动”。
Windows 10 会在后台尝试自动优化磁盘，但当驱动器过度碎片化或可用空间不足时，这一步骤会被拉长或暂停，使复制过程被迫等待。
释放磁盘空间并手动执行“驱动器优化”可以让磁头连续写入、减少等待，从而解除 99% 卡顿[1]。
此外，实时杀毒、USB 接口带宽不足或硬盘出现坏道也会使这最后的同步阶段耗时倍增。
简言之，99% 卡顿多半是磁盘端瓶颈而非复制功能故障，通过检查磁盘健康、关闭占用高的后台任务并定期优化驱动器，能显著缩短该阶段耗时并避免“挂着永远”的现象。
claims_retained: 释放磁盘空间并手动执行“驱动器优化”可以让磁头连续写入、减少等待，从而解除 99% 卡顿[1]。

question_src: 如果我及时回去几天，然后有人给我的手机打电话会怎样？
all_claims: 根据目前的物理学理解，人类既没有找到安全“将一个人送入大量时间的方法”，也从未观察到像科幻作品那样来回的时光旅行；霍金甚至以“我们没有被成群的游客入侵未来”来强调此事几乎不可能发生[1]。
因此，现实层面上你无法先“回到几天前”再接电话。
不过，若纯作思想实验：你的手机和 SIM 若随你一起穿越到过去，它将脱离原先蜂窝网络的基站时空坐标；当友人在“原来的”时间点拨号时，网络只会在当下寻找该设备，却发现它不在信号覆盖范围，于是呼叫会直接失败或进入语音信箱。
如果你的手机未随身穿越，则它仍留在原时间线，照常响铃，而你身处过去自然听不到。
总之，无论哪种假设，呼叫者都无法在那一刻通过常规移动通信接通你，因为移动网络的时空定位与设备的物理位置不再匹配，而真实世界又缺乏允许信号逆向穿越时间的机制。

Content: 尽管许多人对改变过去或在到期之前看到未来的想法感到着迷，但没有人表现出在科幻小说中看到的那种来回旅行，或者提出了一种将一个人送入大量时间的方法，不会在途中摧毁它们。而且，正如物理学家史蒂芬·霍金（Stephen Hawking）在他的书《黑洞和婴儿宇宙》（Bantam，1994）中指出的那样，“我们拥有的最好的证据是不可能的旅行，也永远不会是，这是我们没有被成群的游客入侵未来。”

question_src: ;古老的文明如何被污垢，沙子等覆盖？
all_claims: 古城并非瞬间沉没，而是在自然作用与人类活动双重影响下逐层被埋。
居民迁徙后，无人维护的建筑风化崩塌；植物在废墟上生长、死亡、腐烂，数百年间逐渐堆出新的土壤层[1]。
尘土与沙粒被风带来覆盖地面，暴雨触发的泥石流和洪水把沉积物倾泻其上；地震和风暴进一步摧毁墙体并改变地形，使碎片更易被沉积物填平[1]。
与此同时，定居点不断输入粮食、木材和砖石，却少有系统清理垃圾和建筑残渣，这些人工堆积使地面缓慢抬高，把早期街道与房屋压入地下，形成典型的“土丘城市”(tell)现象[2]。
最终，历经数百至上千年的自然沉积、植被腐殖与人类堆弃，古代文明便被多至数米乃至数十米厚的土、沙、灰尘封存。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 古代文明是如何被掩埋的？ （parade.com）
Content: 除某些明显的例外，例如庞贝，只有自然力量将过去文明的碎片埋葬。人们迁移和传播，抛弃了不需要的结构。荒芜的建筑因缺乏维护而退化；植物超越了空间，死亡并腐烂，几个世纪以来建造土壤层。来自邻近地区的尘埃和碎屑在陆地上吹过，降雨引起泥石流，暴风雨，地震倒塌，地震随时间变化了当地的地形，等等。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why do we have to dig so deep to uncover ancient ruins? (www.sciencefocus.com)
Content: There is a survivorship bias at work here: buildings and monuments left exposed on the surface don’t last very long. Humans steal the best bits to reuse in other buildings, and erosion wears everything else to dust. So the only ancient ruins we find are the ones that were buried.


But they got buried in the first place because the ground level of ancient cities tended to steadily rise. Settlements constantly imported food and building materials for the population, but getting rid of waste and rubbish was a much lower priority
---

Title: 古代文明是如何被掩埋的？ （parade.com）
Content: 除某些明显的例外，例如庞贝，只有自然力量将过去文明的碎片埋葬。人们迁移和传播，抛弃了不需要的结构。荒芜的建筑因缺乏维护而退化；植物超越了空间，死亡并腐烂，几个世纪以来建造土壤层。来自邻近地区的尘埃和碎屑在陆地上吹过，降雨引起泥石流，暴风雨，地震倒塌，地震随时间变化了当地的地形，等等。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why do we have to dig so deep to uncover ancient ruins? (www.sciencefocus.com)
Content: There is a survivorship bias at work here: buildings and monuments left exposed on the surface don’t last very long. Humans steal the best bits to reuse in other buildings, and erosion wears everything else to dust. So the only ancient ruins we find are the ones that were buried.


But they got buried in the first place because the ground level of ancient cities tended to steadily rise. Settlements constantly imported food and building materials for the population, but getting rid of waste and rubbish was a much lower priority
---

Title: How Did Ancient Civilizations Get Buried? (parade.com)
Content: With certain notable exceptions, such as Pompeii, only abandoned fragments of past civilizations were buried by natural forces. People migrated and disseminated, leaving unwanted structures behind. Deserted buildings degraded from a lack of maintenance; plants overtook the space, died and decayed, building layers of soil over the centuries. Dust and debris from neighboring areas blew over the land, rains caused mudslides, storms toppled walls, earthquakes reshaped the local topography over time, and more.

但是他们首先被埋葬了，因为古老城市的地面往往会稳步上升。定居点不断为人口进口食品和建筑材料，但是摆脱废物和垃圾是优先级要低得多的

question_src: 是什么使我们想象看到蚂蚁/昆虫在看到一只蚂蚁/昆虫爬行？
all_claims: 当我们目睹一只蚂蚁或小虫爬行时，大脑中的感觉与视觉系统会迅速联想并激活“皮肤有东西爬”的记忆模板；若随后皮肤受压、出汗或神经末梢自发放电，就可能出现“有虫在身上爬”的错觉，这种现象医学上称为形成（formication），属于感觉异常和触觉幻觉[2]。
形成常见于焦虑、激素变化（如更年期）、神经系统疾病（帕金森病、糖尿病神经病）或酒精、药物戒断等情境，此时外部并无真正的昆虫，但大脑错误地解释了来自皮肤或神经的微弱刺激[2]。
视觉提示（看到蚂蚁）与内部不适信号结合，放大了这种错觉，使人“想象”自己也被蚂蚁爬过，从而出现观察—联想—体感的连锁反应[1]。

Title: Feeling of Something Crawling on Head | 3 Formication Causes | Buoy (www.buoyhealth.com)
Content: Formication is the medical term for a sensation of something (usually small insects) crawling on or under the skin. Often formication is associated with no obvious physical cause or external trigger. It is a fairly common occurrence many people can remember a time where they swatted or scratched at such a sensation only to find no bug, insect or bite in sight.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 形成：焦虑，更年期，治疗，原因，晚上（www.healthline.com）
Content: 形成是昆虫在皮肤上爬行或下方的感觉。该名称来自拉丁单词“ formica”，意为蚂蚁。


形成被称为一种感觉异常。当您在皮肤上感受到没有身体原因的感觉时，就会发生异常。感觉异常可以采取多种形式。这些可能包括燃烧，刺痛或麻木。通过形成，您可能还可以将“爬行”的感觉描述为“销钉和针头”。形成也称为触觉幻觉。这意味着您会感到一种没有身体原因的感觉。


形成可以是几种情况的症状。这些疾病包括纤维肌痛和帕金森氏病。退出酒精或吸毒也可能触发形成。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Formication (www.psychologytoday.com)
Content: Formication is a specific form of the general set of abnormal skin sensations known as paresthesias and tactile hallucinations. It is associated with several disorders: a physical or psychological side effect of substance abuse, diabetic neuropathy, diseases of the spinal cord and peripheral nerves, and extreme alcohol withdrawal with delirium tremens.


This illusion or hallucination that ants or other insects are creeping on or under the skin is a common side effect of large-scale use of cocaine, amphetamines ("amphetamites"), or crystal meth (also known by street names such as "ice," "glass," "chalk," "crank," "meth mites," or "coke bugs.")
---

Title: Difference Between Sigma and pi Bonds | Compare the Difference Between Similar Terms (www.differencebetween.com)
Content: • Sigma bonds are formed by head to head overlapping of orbitals, whereas pi bonds are formed by the lateral overlapping.


• Sigma bonds are stronger than pi bonds.


• Sigma bonds can be formed between both s and p orbitals whereas pi bonds are mostly formed between p and d orbitals. 


• The single covalent bonds between atoms are sigma bonds. When there are multiple bonds between atoms, pi bonds can be seen.


• pi bonds result in unsaturated molecules.


• Sigma bonds allow free rotation of atoms whereas pi bonds restrict the free rotation.

claim: 当你在首次公开募股（IPO）阶段买入一家公司的股票时，支付的资金直接流入公司账上，成为其扩张或日常运营的资本来源；而在IPO之后的大多数交易中，你通过交易所向其他投资者购买同一股票，资金只是从你的口袋转到卖出者口袋，交易所负责撮合并记录这种供求
question_src: 钱如何从我的口袋里，通过股票市场，以支持我从股票购买的业务？
all_claims: 当你在首次公开募股（IPO）阶段买入一家公司的股票时，支付的资金直接流入公司账上，成为其扩张或日常运营的资本来源[2]；而在IPO之后的大多数交易中，你通过交易所向其他投资者购买同一股票，资金只是从你的口袋转到卖出者口袋，交易所负责撮合并记录这种供求[2]。
尽管此时公司并未收到现金，但活跃且上涨的股价可提升其市值与信誉，使其未来再度发行新股或其他证券时以更低成本筹资，从而间接得到支持[3]。
无论交易发生在哪个阶段，你获得的都是公司所有权份额，拥有投票权及对公司未来利润和剩余资产的索取权，并可通过股价上涨或分红获取回报[1]。

Title: Sharp increase in central Oklahoma seismicity since 2008 induced by massive wastewater injection (www.sciencemag.org)
Content: The number of earthquakes is increasing in regions with active unconventional oil and gas wells, where water pumped at high pressure breaks open rock containing natural gas, leaving behind wastewater in need of disposing. Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Is Oil And Gas Activity Causing Earthquakes? And Can We Reduce The Risk? (www.iflscience.com)
Content: Studies including two reports issued in April, indicate that human activities, including activities related to oil and gas extraction, are beginning to play a significant role in triggering earthquakes in the central US.


Extracting oil and gas from shale rock involves cracking, or fracturing, a layer of underground rock with a high-pressure mix of water, sand, and chemicals. As the oil and gas are released, those injection fluids and briny water also come up. That wastewater is later disposed of in what are called injection wells, or sometimes disposal wells.


It is important to note that it is not the fracking process itself that usually causes these earthquakes; it is the rapid injection of fluid during wastewater disposal that sometimes pumps hundreds of millions of gallons of brine deep into the earth each year.

佩瑟因62.5万美元保释金无力支付，被关押了整整半年，直到陪审团确认他“在所有方面都不有罪”才获释[1]。
数据表明，像他这样在审前被羁押的被告更可能认罪或被判处更长刑期，因为身处监狱无法有效与检察官讨价还价，急于“脱身”[3]。
对于轻罪，等待开庭的数日或数周往往已等同潜在刑期，使人即便无辜也倾向接受认罪协议[3]。
因此，当贫困导致无法获得自由，“先坐牢再辩护”的现实便让“无罪推定”成为纸面承诺，引发“尚未定罪却已失去自由”的质疑。

Peyser did not have that much. He qualified for representation by a public defender because he was considered indigent. He and his defense attorneys tried to get multiple judges to reduce his bail, pointing out his stellar record and the possibility of losing both his taxi medallion and his rent-controlled apartment. He had turned the gun over to police and didn't want it back. He promised to stay away from the neighbors.

No dice. He would spend half a year in jail until his case was heard in October, at which point the jury watched the security footage of what happened, deliberated, and found him not guilty on all counts. 没有骰子。他将在监狱中度过半年的监狱，直到10月听到他的案子为止，这时陪审团观看了发生，经过审议的事情的安全镜头，并发现他在所有方面都不有罪。一位陪审员说：“看起来就像一个老人在做一些愚蠢的事情。”这些费用（需要意图证明）与他们不匹配

Document ID: 3
Title: Innocent Until Proven Guilty, But Only If You Can Pay – Reason.com (reason.com)
Content: When defendants are stuck in jail while awaiting trial, data indicate they're more likely to plead guilty or be found guilty of crimes. They're also likely to be given longer prison sentences. This is partly a result of their not being in a position to bargain with prosecutors, because they're stuck behind bars and desperate to move things along.

For low-level crimes, all that time spent in pretrial detention can be equivalent to the length of the sentence they'll get if they're found guilty anyway. A poor defendant who can't afford bail may spend days, even weeks, in jail waiting to see a judge for a crime where prison time might not even be required. At that point, it's hard to justify spending time or money fighting the charge, even if backing down leaves an innocent person with a criminal record.

"Everybody who works in the system knows that the assembly-line cash bail system coerces guilty pleas," says Civil Rights Corps founder and executive director Alec Karakatsanis. Because American courts don't have the manpower to prosecute and try every person who gets arrested, he argues, "the system needs a way to coerce them into pleading guilty. The most effective way is to keep them in jail."

claim: 我们仍采用充气轮胎而不用“永不漏气”的实心橡胶轮胎，原因在于空气可充当“弹簧”，在遇到坑洞或减速带时主动压缩，吸收大部分冲击，从而提供更高的行驶舒适性并保护悬架和车身[2]；实心轮胎缺乏这种缓冲，坐感颠簸且对车辆结构损害更大
question_src: 为什么我们使用填充空气的轮胎，而不是由实心橡胶制成的轮胎，而不会冒着平坦的风险？
all_claims: 我们仍采用充气轮胎而不用“永不漏气”的实心橡胶轮胎，原因在于空气可充当“弹簧”，在遇到坑洞或减速带时主动压缩，吸收大部分冲击，从而提供更高的行驶舒适性并保护悬架和车身[2]；实心轮胎缺乏这种缓冲，坐感颠簸且对车辆结构损害更大[1]。
其次，空气近似无重，充气轮胎整体质量显著低于同尺寸的实心橡胶轮胎，较轻的轮胎可减小发动机负荷，使汽车加速更快、油耗更低[1]。
再次，空气能随温度和载荷收缩、膨胀，为胎体提供可变形空间，减少橡胶与轮辋的摩擦磨损，延长寿命[3]。
综合舒适性、能耗与耐用度的优势，充气轮胎的收益远大于偶发爆胎所带来的维护成本，因此至今仍是乘用车的主流选择。
claims_retained: 我们仍采用充气轮胎而不用“永不漏气”的实心橡胶轮胎，原因在于空气可充当“弹簧”，在遇到坑洞或减速带时主动压缩，吸收大部分冲击，从而提供更高的行驶舒适性并保护悬架和车身[2]；实心轮胎缺乏这种缓冲，坐感颠簸且对车辆结构损害更大[1]。

Title: 为什么不是由实心橡胶而不是充气空气制成的轮胎？ （www.autoexpose.org）
Content: 但是，由实心橡胶制成的轮胎不会吸收振动和气动轮胎。这是因为轮胎的固体结构使轮胎没有介质吸收冲击。

因此，实心橡胶轮胎不适合用于优先舒适的乘用车。

除此之外，还有其他缺点。由实心橡胶制成的轮胎的重量高于气动轮胎。较高的重量将增加发动机负载以运行车辆。

因此，如果在乘用车中使用实心轮胎，汽车会缓慢加速并浪费燃料。

因此，可以得出结论，实心橡胶不适合在道路上运行的车辆中使用。

Content: The air in the tires can often absorb impact of a hole or bump because of it’s high suspension capabilities. On airless tires, the suspension would be lower, resulting in a rougher ride. claim: 发生地震前后，动物被认为依靠比人类更灵敏的感官捕捉到地面轻微振动等早期信号
question_src: 动物如何感知即将到来的地震？
all_claims: 发生地震前后，动物被认为依靠比人类更灵敏的感官捕捉到地面轻微振动等早期信号[1]。
P波是地震产生的第一波[5]，它们比破坏性的S波先到达地表，许多具有敏锐听觉或触觉的动物能够在S波到来前感知这些较小而快速的振动或低频声波，因而出现突然奔跑、吠叫或集体迁移等异常行为[4]。
另一种理论认为，岩层断裂时释放的电磁变化或气体可改变周围空气的电场，动物通过皮肤、毛发或胡须探测到这种微弱电气信号，提前做出反应[1]。
还有假设指出，大象等社会性动物可能通过长期积累的经验学习，当族长感觉到远处地面的隆隆声时，会迅速带领族群向高处撤离，显示感觉与行为记忆的共同作用[3]。
不过，动物也会因觅食、求偶或躲避捕食者而出现类似行为，给科学验证增加了难度，因此尚无公认的“动物预测地震”机制[2]。

claim: 从十九世纪起，美国报纸就与特定政党和出版商经济利益紧密相连，显示媒体一开始就带有鲜明政治立场，而非后来才被“主流媒体”蓄意植入
question_src: 是主要的新闻媒体建立了政治偏见还是随着时间的流逝而形成？
all_claims: 从十九世纪起，美国报纸就与特定政党和出版商经济利益紧密相连，显示媒体一开始就带有鲜明政治立场，而非后来才被“主流媒体”蓄意植入[1]。
随后赫斯特与普利策的“黄色新闻”大战为销量与政治议程大肆夸张煽情，偏见因商业竞争与社会运动而进一步演化[2]。
尽管二十世纪出现强调“奥林匹亚式客观性”的职业规范，记者仍难完全摆脱选词、篇幅与赞助商等结构性限制，几乎任何新闻机构都会被指存在某种倾向[3]。
综上，政治偏见并非由现代主要新闻媒体单独“建立”，而是伴随媒体历史、商业模式与社会环境逐步形成并不断变化的长期产物。
claims_retained: 从十九世纪起，美国报纸就与特定政党和出版商经济利益紧密相连，显示媒体一开始就带有鲜明政治立场，而非后来才被“主流媒体”蓄意植入[1]。
随后赫斯特与普利策的“黄色新闻”大战为销量与政治议程大肆夸张煽情，偏见因商业竞争与社会运动而进一步演化[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 媒体偏见的简短历史（www.hoover.org）
Content: 媒体偏见的根源可以追溯到十九世纪，并且对偏见的抱怨部分反映出了对媒体的作用和目的的可疑想法：存在报纸和其他公共信息分配器，以传达客观，事实信息，通过证书专业人士收集和传达。


实际上，记者应该拥有奥林匹亚客观性的观念相对较新。在19世纪，大多数报纸明显与特定政党和出版商的经济利益有关。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: A Brief History of Media Bias (www.hoover.org)
Content: The tradition of lurid sensationalism, scandal-mongering, and exaggeration put in service to profits and a political agenda continued in the “yellow journalism” famously on display in the circulation war between the Hearst and Pulitzer newspapers in the late nineteenth century. More significantly, that was also when the progressive movement promoted the notion that the proper function of the media was to instruct and shape the opinions of voters too uninformed and irrational to be trusted with making the right choice based on facts alone.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What is Media Bias and Where does It Come from? (with pictures) (www.infobloom.com)
Content: It is almost impossible for any network or journalistic publication not to be accused of some bias. Subtle things like word choice, time limits on programming, and sponsors may all suggest that the organization isn't neutral. Each individual who reports or writes the news also has to work hard to guard against revealing his or her own opinions. These opinions can reveal bias simply through word choice or inflections and tone of voice when delivering news.


[Image: The media is often described as biased.] The media is often described as biased.


One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story. Often, this may be viewed as failing to include the opposite viewpoint, but it would be virtually impossible to include all viewpoints on a particular issue, since people approach issues from more than two directions. For example, those belonging to fringe political parties like the Libertarians or Green Party, often feel their viewpoint is not adequately represented in journalism.


[Image: One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.] One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.


This failure to represent all sides of the story may not be intentional bias, however. News stories may simply not have the time to cover all points of view, and may stick to classic “sides,” such as left and right, in an attempt to curb media bias. The media can still technically be biased since it cannot represent all points of view.
---

尽管二十世纪出现强调“奥林匹亚式客观性”的职业规范，记者仍难完全摆脱选词、篇幅与赞助商等结构性限制，几乎任何新闻机构都会被指存在某种倾向[3]。
综上，政治偏见并非由现代主要新闻媒体单独“建立”，而是伴随媒体历史、商业模式与社会环境逐步形成并不断变化的长期产物。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: A Brief History of Media Bias (www.hoover.org)
Content: The roots of media bias go back to the nineteenth century, and complaints about bias in part reflect a questionable idea about the media’s role and purpose: that newspapers and other dispensers of public information exist to transmit objective, factual information gleaned and communicated by credentialed professionals.


In fact, the notion that reporters should possess Olympian objectivity is relatively recent. In the nineteenth century, most newspapers were explicitly linked to a particular political party and the economic interests of the publisher.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 媒体偏见的简短历史（www.hoover.org）
Content: 在19世纪后期，赫斯特和普利策报纸之间的流通战争中，在“黄色新闻”中著名地展示了轰动的轰动，丑闻，丑闻和夸大其词为利润和政治议程所付出的传统。更重要的是，这也是当进步运动推广媒体的正确功能是指导和塑造对选民的意见和塑造过于不知情和不合理的观点，以至于仅基于事实做出正确的选择而受到信任。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What is Media Bias and Where does It Come from? (with pictures) (www.infobloom.com)
Content: It is almost impossible for any network or journalistic publication not to be accused of some bias. Subtle things like word choice, time limits on programming, and sponsors may all suggest that the organization isn't neutral. Each individual who reports or writes the news also has to work hard to guard against revealing his or her own opinions. These opinions can reveal bias simply through word choice or inflections and tone of voice when delivering news.


[Image: The media is often described as biased.] The media is often described as biased.


One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story. Often, this may be viewed as failing to include the opposite viewpoint, but it would be virtually impossible to include all viewpoints on a particular issue, since people approach issues from more than two directions. For example, those belonging to fringe political parties like the Libertarians or Green Party, often feel their viewpoint is not adequately represented in journalism.


[Image: One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.] One form of media bias is the failure to include varied points of view on a story.


This failure to represent all sides of the story may not be intentional bias, however. News stories may simply not have the time to cover all points of view, and may stick to classic “sides,” such as left and right, in an attempt to curb media bias. The media can still technically be biased since it cannot represent all points of view.
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Understanding the Monty Hall Problem – BetterExplained (betterexplained.com)
Content: The Monty Hall problem is a counter-intuitive statistics puzzle:


* There are 3 doors, behind which are two goats and a car.
* You pick a door (call it door A). You’re hoping for the car of course.
* Monty Hall, the game show host, examines the other doors (B & C) and opens one with a goat. (If both doors have goats, he picks randomly.)


Here’s the game: Do you stick with door A (original guess) or switch to the unopened door? Does it matter?


Surprisingly, the odds aren’t 50-50. If you switch doors you’ll win 2/3 of the time!


Today let’s get an intuition for why a simple game could be so baffling. The game is really about re-evaluating your decisions as new information emerges.


## Play the game


You’re probably muttering that two doors mean it’s a 50-50 chance. Ok bub, let’s play the game:


Try playing the game 50 times, using a “pick and hold” strategy. Just pick door 1 (or 2, or 3) and keep clicking. Click click click. Look at your percent win rate. You’ll see it settle around 1/3.


Now reset and play it 20 times, using a “pick and switch” approach. Pick a door, Monty reveals a goat (grey door), and you switch to the other. Look at your win rate. Is it above 50% Is it closer to 60%? To 66%?


There’s a chance the stay-and-hold strategy does decent on a small number of trials (under 20 or so). If you had a coin, how many flips would you need to convince yourself it was fair? You might get 2 heads in a row and think it was rigged. Just play the game a few dozen times to even it out and reduce the noise.


## Understanding Why Switching Works


That’s the hard (but convincing) way of realizing switching works. Here’s an easier way:


If I pick a door and hold, I have a 1/3 chance of winning.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 了解Monty Hall问题 - 更好地解释（Better Explaining.com）
Content: 如果我选择一扇门并握住，我有1/3的获胜机会。


我的第一个猜测是3分之一 - 有3个随机选择，对吗？


如果我严格坚持自己的第一选择，无论如何我都无法提高机会。蒙蒂可能会增加50扇门，将其他门炸开，做伏都教雨舞 - 没关系。我可以做的最好的选择是三分之一。另一扇门必须具有其余的机会，即2/3。


解释可能是有道理的，但不能解释为什么另一端的几率“变得更好”。 （几个读者在评论中留下了自己的解释 - 如果1/3停留vs 2/3开关未单击，请尝试一下）。
---

question_src: 电力生产期间电子的流量
all_claims: 在电力生产期间，带负电的电子会从其原子外层获得足够能量后脱离束缚，跳跃到相邻原子的外层轨道，这一“接力”式迁移在导体内部形成了连续有序的电子流动[1]；当这种迁移过程在发电装置（如发电机线圈）中被持续驱动时，就产生了我们称为电流的宏观现象[2]。
电流大小取决于单位时间内通过导体截面的电子总量，若保持电子流动的方向和速率稳定，则可输出稳定的电力[1]。
在国际单位制中，1 安培电流对应每秒约6.24 × 10¹⁸个电子穿过导体截面，这说明哪怕极短时间内的微观电子运动，也能累积成可观的能量传输。

Title: Current Flow Overview: How Electricity Travels Through Wires (greencoast.org)
Content: An atom is the smallest constituent unit of an element that can exist, but within each atom, there are three particles. The three particles include electrons, protons, and neutrons.


The electrons carry a negative electromagnetic charge and have unique characteristics as they can skip from one atom to another.


The ability of an electron to disassociate itself from one atom and move to the adjacent atom is what makes it the most vital particle when it comes to electricity.


This movement of electrons from one atom to another is what creates an electric current. A consistent flow of electrons within a circuit determines the current in a wire. See how to calculate potential energy to understand electrons and energy.

question_src: 如何发生进化以及第一个生物如何产生
all_claims: 地球早期的大气可能含有沸水蒸气、氢气、氨和甲烷，雷电频繁，为化学反应提供能量[1]。
米勒1952年的实验表明，这种环境在一周内即可合成甘氨酸、丙氨酸等氨基酸，为生命奠定基本组分[2]。
这些有机分子经过聚合和自我复制的化学演化，形成最初的原核微生物。
至少24亿年前，部分微生物进化出光合作用，成为蓝细菌，释放氧气，引发大气含氧量急升并改变生态格局[3]。
随后，某些微生物进入他者体内形成互惠共生，演变出线粒体及被膜包裹的细胞核，标志着具有专门细胞器的真核细胞诞生[4]。
真核细胞继续通过分工协作集结为多细胞体，最终在约8亿年前出现最早的动物，开启生物多样化[4]。
化学演化→单细胞→共生复杂化→多细胞的连续过程展示了进化如何发生及最初生命的产生机制。
