prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 地球生活如何开始的秘密（www.bbc.com）
Content: 1952年，米勒（Miller）开始了关于生活起源的最著名实验。

设置很简单。米勒连接了一系列玻璃烧瓶，并循环四种他怀疑的化学物质，这些化学物质存在于地球早期：沸水，氢气，氨和甲烷。他对气体进行了重复的电击，以模拟很久以前在地球上很常见的雷击
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The secret of how life on Earth began (www.bbc.com)
Content: Miller found that "the water in the flask became noticeably pink after the first day, and by the end of the week the solution was deep red and turbid". Clearly, a mix of chemicals had formed.

When Miller analysed the mixture he found that it contained two amino acids: glycine and alanine. Amino acids are often described as the building blocks of life. They are used to form the proteins that control most biochemical processes in our bodies. Miller had made two of life's most important components, from scratch
---
Document ID: 3
Title: History of Life on Earth (naturalhistory.si.edu)
Content: When cyanobacteria evolved at least 2.4 billion years ago, they set the stage for a remarkable transformation. They became Earth’s first photo-synthesizers, making food using water and the Sun’s energy, and releasing oxygen as a result. This catalyzed a sudden, dramatic rise in oxygen, making the environment less hospitable for other microbes that could not tolerate oxygen
---
Document ID: 4
Title: History of Life on Earth (naturalhistory.si.edu)
Content: While they can process lots of chemicals, microbes did not have the specialized cells that are needed for complex bodies. Animal bodies have various cells –skin, blood, bone – which contain organelles, each doing a distinct job. Microbes are just single cells with no organelles and no nuclei to package their DNA.

Something revolutionary happened as microbes began living inside other microbes, functioning as organelles for them. Mitochondria, the organelles that process food into energy, evolved from these mutually beneficial relationships. Also, for the first time, DNA became packaged in nuclei. The new complex cells (“eukaryotic cells”) boasted specialized parts playing specialized roles that supported the whole cell.

Cells also began living together, probably because certain benefits could be obtained. Groups of cells might be able to feed more efficiently or gain protection from simply being bigger. Living collectively, cells began to support the needs of the group by each cell doing a specific job. Some cells were tasked with making junctions to hold the group together, while other cells made digestive enzymes that could break down food.

## The First Animals

These clusters of specialized, cooperating cells eventually became the first animals, which DNA evidence suggests evolved around 800 million years ago
---

Title: 地球上的生命历史（自然历史.si.edu）
Content: 尽管它们可以处理大量化学物质，但微生物没有复杂物体所需的专门细胞。动物体有各种细胞 - 皮肤，血液，骨头 - 包含细胞器，每个细胞器都有独特的工作。微生物只是没有细胞器的单个细胞，没有核可以包装其DNA。

当微生物开始生活在其他微生物内时，发生了一些革命性的事情，对它们起了细胞器的作用。线粒体是将食物加工成能量的细胞器，这些细胞体是从这些互惠关系中演变而来的。同样，DNA首次包装在核中。新的复杂细胞（“真核细胞”）拥有专门的零件，扮演了支持整个细胞的专业角色。

细胞也开始在一起生活，可能是因为可以获得某些好处。一组细胞可能能够更有效地食用或获得更大的保护。单元格集体生活，每个细胞都会通过每个细胞来支持小组的需求。一些细胞的任务是使结合组合在一起，而其他细胞则制造了可能分解食物的消化酶。

##第一批动物

all_claims: 地球早期的大气可能含有沸水蒸气、氢气、氨和甲烷，雷电频繁，为化学反应提供能量[1]。
米勒1952年的实验表明，这种环境在一周内即可合成甘氨酸、丙氨酸等氨基酸，为生命奠定基本组分[2]。
这些有机分子经过聚合和自我复制的化学演化，形成最初的原核微生物。
至少24亿年前，部分微生物进化出光合作用，成为蓝细菌，释放氧气，引发大气含氧量急升并改变生态格局[3]。
随后，某些微生物进入他者体内形成互惠共生，演变出线粒体及被膜包裹的细胞核，标志着具有专门细胞器的真核细胞诞生[4]。
真核细胞继续通过分工协作集结为多细胞体，最终在约8亿年前出现最早的动物，开启生物多样化[4]。
化学演化→单细胞→共生复杂化→多细胞的连续过程展示了进化如何发生及最初生命的产生机制。

Title: The secret of how life on Earth began (www.bbc.com)
Content: in 1952, Miller began the most famous experiment on the origin of life ever attempted.

The set-up was simple. Miller connected a series of glass flasks and circulated four chemicals that he suspected were present on the early Earth: boiling water, hydrogen gas, ammonia and methane. He subjected the gases to repeated electric shocks, to simulate the lightning strikes that would have been a common occurrence on Earth so long ago
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The secret of how life on Earth began (www.bbc.com)
Content: Miller found that "the water in the flask became noticeably pink after the first day, and by the end of the week the solution was deep red and turbid". Clearly, a mix of chemicals had formed.

When Miller analysed the mixture he found that it contained two amino acids: glycine and alanine. Amino acids are often described as the building blocks of life. They are used to form the proteins that control most biochemical processes in our bodies. Miller had made two of life's most important components, from scratch
---
Document ID: 3
Title: History of Life on Earth (naturalhistory.si.edu)
Content: When cyanobacteria evolved at least 2.4 billion years ago, they set the stage for a remarkable transformation. They became Earth’s first photo-synthesizers, making food using water and the Sun’s energy, and releasing oxygen as a result. This catalyzed a sudden, dramatic rise in oxygen, making the environment less hospitable for other microbes that could not tolerate oxygen

Title: 第二（en.wikipedia.org）
Content: 尽管该单位的历史定义是基于地球旋转周期的这一划分的，但国际单位体系（SI）的形式定义是一个稳定的计时员：

>第二个定义为等于辐射的9,192,631,770个时期的持续时间，对应于两个基本不受干扰的基本状态的两个高精细水平之间的过渡，caesium-133原子
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The Standard Meter (surveyhistory.org)
Content: The French originated the meter in the 1790s as one/ten-millionth of the distance from the equator to the north pole along a meridian through Paris. It is realistically represented by the distance between two marks on an iron bar kept in Paris. The International Bureau of Weights and Measures, created in 1875, upgraded the bar to one made of 90 percent platinum/10 percent iridium alloy.

In 1960 the meter was redefined as 1,650,763.73 wavelengths of orange-red light, in a vacuum, produced by burning the element krypton (Kr-86). More recently (1984), the Geneva Conference on Weights and Measures has defined the meter as the distance light travels, in a vacuum, in 1/299,792,458 seconds with time measured by a cesium-133 atomic clock which emits pulses of radiation at very rapid, regular intervals
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Gram (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The gram (alternative spelling: gramme;[1] SI unit symbol: g) is a metric system unit of mass.

Originally defined as "the absolute weight of a volume of pure water equal to the cube of the hundredth part of a metre [1 cm^3], and at the temperature of melting ice"[2] (later at 4 °C, the temperature of maximum density of water). However, in a reversal of reference and defined units, a gram is now defined as one thousandth of the SI base unit, the kilogram, or 1×10−3 kg, which itself is defined by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, not in terms of grams, but by taking the fixed numerical value of the Planck constant h to be 6.626 070 15×10−34 kg⋅m^2⋅s−1

>第二个定义为等于辐射的9,192,631,770个时期的持续时间，对应于两个基本不受干扰的基本状态的两个高精细水平之间的过渡，caesium-133原子
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The Standard Meter (surveyhistory.org)
Content: The French originated the meter in the 1790s as one/ten-millionth of the distance from the equator to the north pole along a meridian through Paris. It is realistically represented by the distance between two marks on an iron bar kept in Paris. The International Bureau of Weights and Measures, created in 1875, upgraded the bar to one made of 90 percent platinum/10 percent iridium alloy.

In 1960 the meter was redefined as 1,650,763.73 wavelengths of orange-red light, in a vacuum, produced by burning the element krypton (Kr-86). More recently (1984), the Geneva Conference on Weights and Measures has defined the meter as the distance light travels, in a vacuum, in 1/299,792,458 seconds with time measured by a cesium-133 atomic clock which emits pulses of radiation at very rapid, regular intervals
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Gram (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The gram (alternative spelling: gramme;[1] SI unit symbol: g) is a metric system unit of mass.

Originally defined as "the absolute weight of a volume of pure water equal to the cube of the hundredth part of a metre [1 cm^3], and at the temperature of melting ice"[2] (later at 4 °C, the temperature of maximum density of water). However, in a reversal of reference and defined units, a gram is now defined as one thousandth of the SI base unit, the kilogram, or 1×10−3 kg, which itself is defined by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, not in terms of grams, but by taking the fixed numerical value of the Planck constant h to be 6.626 070 15×10−34 kg⋅m^2⋅s−1
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why do dogs shake their legs? (www.animalplanet.com)
Content: Dogs shake or kick their legs when you scratch them because of something known as the scratch reflex. It's a completely involuntary reaction, which explains why your dog may look as puzzled as you do when it starts to happen. When you scratch or tickle your dog's belly, it irritates him, much the same way that the wind or a bug might. It activates nerves under his skin that are connected to his spinal cord and relays a message to his leg muscles to kick in an attempt to get rid of the irritant.

因此，划痕反射可能会使狗通过使用后腿快速尝试去除刺激。

Title: Why We Accidentally Spray Saliva When We Yawn (brightside.me)
Content: Your mouth has a heap of muscles, and sometimes you can be doing some mouth thing — like talking or eating — and hit just the right combination, and whoosh, there it goes. When you get a yawn attack, you accidentally squeeze the salivary glands under your tongue, forcing the saliva to squirt out in a spray. Luckily, people can’t gleek again until the ducts are refilled.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why We Accidentally Spray Saliva When We Yawn (brightside.me)
Content: Gleeking happens when a large amount of saliva builds up in your mouth below your tongue: for example, if you’ve eaten something sour or bitter. Saliva is secreted by the major salivary glands. If you look in the mirror while raising your tongue, you can see the ducts that deliver saliva from the glands to the mouth.


Gleeking is achieved by compressing these ducts with muscles in the base of the mouth when you move your tongue upward. If your mouth is wide open the stream can be launched several feet.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: How come sometimes when you yawn, a spray of water comes from the back of your mouth? (www.answerbag.com)
Content: I t actually comes from under the tongue. Gleeking is the projection of saliva from the submandibular gland on compression by the tongue. In general, gleeking occurs when an accumulation of saliva in the submandibular gland is propelled out in a stream when the gland is compressed by the tongue. The stream of saliva is released in the general direction of the front of the mouth. If the mouth is open the jet may project several feet. Gleeking is more likely when the salivary gland has been recently stimulated, but even a residual amount of saliva in the gland may be released by gleeking. Gleeking may occur spontaneously due to accidental tongue pressure on the sublingual gland while talking, eating, yawning, or cleaning the teeth.
---

Title: Why does a spray of water come out of mouth when yawning? - Answers (www.answers.com)
Content: The sublingual caruncle is found under your tongue (either side of the frenulum - the small folds going from your tongue and the cavity floor).


This is where two salivary glands, the sublingual and submandibular glands, empty into the oral cavity. That is why saliva will sometimes spray out when you lift your tongue while yawning.

question_src: 第二次世界大战后，德国对自己的政治制度做了什么变化，以确保独裁者的人物再也不会掌权？
all_claims: 二战结束后，德国先被划为四个占领区并在经济上统一管理[1]；1949年，西占区成立德意志联邦共和国，引入西方民主制度、议会制和多党竞选，以取代纳粹时期的一人专政，从制度上防止独裁者再现[1]。
东德最初实行社会主义体制，但在1989-1990年间看守政府同各民主政党达成协议举行自由选举并重写宪法；1990年3月18日的首次自由选举产生了以迅速与西德统一为纲领的新政府，实现和平向民主过渡[2]。
随后东德依据《统一条约》和《基本法》第23条于1990年10月3日加入联邦共和国，全国适用联邦德国的民主宪政框架，从而通过权力分立、联邦制与多党制等机制，系统性地阻断个人专断掌权的可能[3]。
claims_retained: 二战结束后，德国先被划为四个占领区并在经济上统一管理[1]；1949年，西占区成立德意志联邦共和国，引入西方民主制度、议会制和多党竞选，以取代纳粹时期的一人专政，从制度上防止独裁者再现[1]。

Content: 该国分为四个独立的区域，每个区域都由盟军和法国之一的统治。目的是将德国视为一个单一的经济区，但贸易问题必须分别考虑该国的西部和东部地区。


到1949年，德国的西半部（也称为德国联邦共和国）采用了西方民主的模式，而苏联控制的东部是社会主义国家。

Title: History of Germany (1945–1990) (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: Prime Minister Hans Modrow headed a caretaker government which shared power with the new, democratically oriented parties. On 7 December 1989, an agreement was reached to hold free elections in May 1990 and rewrite the East German constitution. On 28 January, all the parties agreed to advance the elections to 18 March, primarily because of an erosion of state authority and because the East German exodus was continuing apace; more than 117,000 left in January and February 1990.


In early February 1990, the Modrow government's proposal for a unified, neutral German state was rejected by Chancellor Kohl, who affirmed that a unified Germany must be a member of NATO. Finally, on 18 March, the first free elections were held in East Germany, and a government led by Lothar de Maizière (CDU) was formed under a policy of expeditious unification with West Germany. The freely elected representatives of the Volkskammer held their first session on 5 April, and East Germany peacefully evolved from a communist to a democratically elected government.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: History of Germany (1945–1990) (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The conclusion of the final settlement cleared the way for the unification of East and West Germany. Formal political union occurred on 3 October 1990, preceded by the GDR declaring its accession to the Federal Republic through Article 23 of West Germany's Basic Law (meaning that constitutionally, East Germany was subsumed into West Germany); but affected in strict legality through the subsequent Unification Treaty of 30 August 1990, which was voted into their constitutions by both the West German Bundestag and the East German Volkskammer on 20 September 1990.[62] These votes simultaneously extinguished the GDR and affected fundamental amendments to the West German Basic Law (including the repeal of the very Article 23 under which the GDR had recently declared its post-dated accession).

claim: 并非所有电视都内置蓝牙模组；只有搭配“智能遥控器”的机型才把蓝牙用作遥控器与电视的配对通道
question_src: 他们为什么不制作所有遥控器蓝牙，以便像我这样懒惰的人不必举起手臂呢？
all_claims: 并非所有电视都内置蓝牙模组；只有搭配“智能遥控器”的机型才把蓝牙用作遥控器与电视的配对通道[1]。
为所有产品都加入蓝牙芯片、天线与认证会显著抬高物料成本，而传统红外仅需几乎零成本的 LED 发射管。
蓝牙遥控器需保持低功率广播以维持配对，电池寿命通常短于纯红外，意味着更昂贵的电池或更频繁更换电池，维护成本随之上升。
大量老旧或入门级电视仍缺乏蓝牙硬件，若强行使用蓝牙解决方案，还需像音频那样额外购买适配器才能工作[2]，削弱了“统一蓝牙”带来的便利。
综合成本、功耗、兼容性及市场分层等因素，厂商选择让高端机采用蓝牙遥控，而把低端机继续搭配红外遥控，因此并非所有遥控器都改为蓝牙。

Title: Why gold smuggling is on the rise in India (www.bbc.com)
Content: Triggered by a rise in duty on imports of gold jewellery introduced in June last year, smuggled gold worth 2,500m rupees ($41.18m; £24.75m) was confiscated at various ports and airports between March and December last year, up from 500m rupees during the same period in the previous fiscal year.


Last year, the government hiked the import duty on gold three times, eventually to 15%, to curb demand for the precious metal and rein in a widening current account deficit that had touched a record high of $88bn (£53bn) in 2012-13.

Title: Why Is Gold Smuggled to India? (globalbullionsuppliers.com)
Content: In trying to bring in some revenue to cover debts and bring a halt to the strong demand for gold jewelry, the government has only produced conditions for more illegal activity.


4. Festival Season Means Consistent Demand


Smugglers can rely on this market being strong throughout the year – but especially in the fall, when the Diwali Festival occurs. An especially joyous time of year in India and Nepal, many people spend on new clothing, home furnishings, and expensive gold jewellery.


In fact, people that would never buy gold for daily use will buy gold for religious festivals. One festival in particular, Dushera, is characterized by the purchase of gold itself.


5. It is Easy to Smuggle


Part of why smuggling continues to happen is due to a lack of oversight. Indian government regulations for checking baggage and following up on suspicious travellers is not as thorough as it needs to be.


As long as travellers are able to stuff gold in planes and make it across the border there will be an issue.

question_src: 人们为什么要从一个国家到各个国家走私黄金条？
all_claims: 人们之所以跨国走私黄金条，核心动机是套利避税与满足需求。
印度将黄金进口税提高至15%，走私客若绕过关口即可省下全部关税，仅去年3-12月被查获的就值25亿卢比[1]；在日本，超过20万日元的黄金需缴8%消费税，嫌疑人一次即可逃税1080万日元[4]。
各地税负叠加形成价差，例如今年以来大陆金价低于香港，导致边境一次查获价值1000万港元的金条[3]。
与此同时，印度排灯节等宗教节日带来持续且季节性旺盛的购金需求，为走私品迅速出手创造市场[5]。
负利率与量化宽松刺激日本买金热，也推高了走私量[2]。
再加上海关监管有限、携带便利，走私成为获得快速、高额且相对低风险回报的手段[5]。

与此同时，印度排灯节等宗教节日带来持续且季节性旺盛的购金需求，为走私品迅速出手创造市场[5]。

Title: Why Is Gold Smuggled to India? (globalbullionsuppliers.com)
Content: In trying to bring in some revenue to cover debts and bring a halt to the strong demand for gold jewelry, the government has only produced conditions for more illegal activity.


4. Festival Season Means Consistent Demand


Smugglers can rely on this market being strong throughout the year – but especially in the fall, when the Diwali Festival occurs. An especially joyous time of year in India and Nepal, many people spend on new clothing, home furnishings, and expensive gold jewellery.


In fact, people that would never buy gold for daily use will buy gold for religious festivals. One festival in particular, Dushera, is characterized by the purchase of gold itself.


5. It is Easy to Smuggle


Part of why smuggling continues to happen is due to a lack of oversight. Indian government regulations for checking baggage and following up on suspicious travellers is not as thorough as it needs to be.


As long as travellers are able to stuff gold in planes and make it across the border there will be an issue.

Title: 为什么黄金走私到印度？ （globalbullionsuppliers.com）
Content: 在试图带来一些收入来偿还债务并停止对黄金珠宝的强烈需求时，政府只为更非法的活动带来了条件。


4。节日季节意味着一致的需求


走私者可以全年依靠这个市场强劲，但尤其是在排灯节举行的秋天。在印度和尼泊尔，一年中特别欢乐的时光，许多人花在新衣服，家具和昂贵的黄金珠宝上。


实际上，永远不会为日常使用购买黄金的人会为宗教节日购买黄金。尤其是一个节日，杜什拉（Dushera）的特点是购买黄金本身。


5。走私很容易


走私持续发生的部分原因是由于缺乏监督。印度政府检查行李和跟进可疑旅行者的法规并不像需要的那样彻底。


只要旅行者能够在飞机上塞满黄金并将其跨越边界，就会出现问题。

claim: 是的，传热具有可度量的“速率”（通常称为传热速率或功率，单位瓦特，即焦耳/秒），它描述单位时间内通过导热、对流或辐射转移的热量多少；实验上可观察到温度变化速率与热量传递速率呈正比：若热量以高速率传递，样品温度变化更快，若速率较低，则温度变化较慢
question_src: 是否有传热速度？
all_claims: 是的，传热具有可度量的“速率”（通常称为传热速率或功率，单位瓦特，即焦耳/秒），它描述单位时间内通过导热、对流或辐射转移的热量多少；实验上可观察到温度变化速率与热量传递速率呈正比：若热量以高速率传递，样品温度变化更快，若速率较低，则温度变化较慢[1]。
当两个物体达到热平衡、温差消失时，传热速率降为零[1]。
因此，传热过程不仅存在方向（从高温到低温），也有大小随时间可变的“速度”，并可用公式 Q̇ = k·A·ΔT/L（对稳态导热）或 Q̇ = h·A·ΔT（对对流）等定量计算。
claims_retained: 是的，传热具有可度量的“速率”（通常称为传热速率或功率，单位瓦特，即焦耳/秒），它描述单位时间内通过导热、对流或辐射转移的热量多少；实验上可观察到温度变化速率与热量传递速率呈正比：若热量以高速率传递，样品温度变化更快，若速率较低，则温度变化较慢[1]。
当两个物体达到热平衡、温差消失时，传热速率降为零[1]。

question_src: 温室气体使它们成为温室气体是什么？
all_claims: 温室气体之所以被称为温室气体，关键在于其分子能够有效吸收地球向外辐射的红外线：红外辐射撞击如二氧化碳等分子时，会激发其键的弯曲和振动，能量被吸收并转化为动能，随后通过碰撞传递给周围的氮、氧分子，引起大气整体升温[4]；而氮气和氧气本身对太阳辐射和红外辐射几乎透明，不具此吸收性[2]。
二氧化碳在15 µm处有强吸收峰[1]，水汽与二氧化碳还能在4-80 µm的宽波段吸收，吸收曲线越宽，对热量的截留就越显著[3]。
这种捕获并再散射地表热量、减少热量逸散到太空的能力，使这些气体成为调节地球温度的“温室气体”[2]。
claims_retained: 温室气体之所以被称为温室气体，关键在于其分子能够有效吸收地球向外辐射的红外线：红外辐射撞击如二氧化碳等分子时，会激发其键的弯曲和振动，能量被吸收并转化为动能，随后通过碰撞传递给周围的氮、氧分子，引起大气整体升温[4]；而氮气和氧气本身对太阳辐射和红外辐射几乎透明，不具此吸收性[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Climate Science Investigations South Florida (www.ces.fau.edu)
Content: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is also an important greenhouse gas. It has a long lifetime in Earth's atmosphere. Carbon dioxide strongly absorbs energy with a wavelength of 15 μm (micrometers). This makes carbon dioxide a good absorber of wavelengths falling in the infrared radiation region of the spectrum.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 气候科学调查南佛罗里达州（www.ces.fau.edu）
Content: 您已经了解到，地球的大气主要由氮和氧气组成。这些气体对于传入的太阳辐射是透明的。它们也对外向红外辐射透明，这意味着它们不吸收或发射太阳或红外辐射。但是，地球大气中还有其他气体会吸收红外辐射。这些气体称为温室气体。以下是影响地球气候系统的最重要的温室气体。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Climate Science Investigations South Florida (www.ces.fau.edu)
Content: An effective absorber of infrared radiation has a broader absorption profile, which means that it can absorb a wider spectrum of wavelengths. Water vapor and carbon dioxide can absorb radiation wavelengths in the range of 4 μm to 80 μm, except those between 8 μm and 12 μm. Ozone can absorb wavelengths between 9 μm and 10 μm, but as you have learned, it is found in low concentrations. The sun's ultraviolet wavelengths are strongly absorbed by ozone in the stratosphere.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Greenhouse Gases (chemistry.elmhurst.edu)
Content: Certain gases in the atmosphere have the property of absorbing infrared radiation. Oxygen and nitrogen the major gases in the atmosphere do not have this property. The infrared radiation strikes a molecule such as carbon dioxide and causes the bonds to bend and vibrate - this is called the absorption of IR energy. The molecule gains kinetic energy by this absorption of IR radiation. This extra kinetic energy may then be transmitted to other molecules such as oxygen and nitrogen and causes a general heating of the atmosphere. Analogy: Think of a partially stretched "toy slinky" - if you bump the slinky, the energy of the bump is absorbed by the vibrations in the slinky.
---

claim: 制作不同类型的奶酪，先选择原料乳：牛、羊或山羊乳因成分差异而影响风味和质地[2]；再接种特定微生物：表面喷霉可制卡门贝、布里等软熟奶酪，其分泌酶分解凝乳、形成流心和独特风味[3]；若用中嗜性启动菌可得切达等硬质奶酪，而耐高温的嗜热菌结合产丙酸菌可制瑞士奶酪并产生典型“眼睛”
question_src: 如何制作不同类型的奶酪？
all_claims: 制作不同类型的奶酪，先选择原料乳：牛、羊或山羊乳因成分差异而影响风味和质地[2]；再接种特定微生物：表面喷霉可制卡门贝、布里等软熟奶酪，其分泌酶分解凝乳、形成流心和独特风味[3]；若用中嗜性启动菌可得切达等硬质奶酪，而耐高温的嗜热菌结合产丙酸菌可制瑞士奶酪并产生典型“眼睛”[4]。
加工过程中，凝乳的切割、搅拌、加热与压榨强度决定脱水量：切得越细、温度越高、压力越大，成品越干硬[4]。
最后在受控温湿环境下熟成数天至两年以上，时间越长，水分越少，奶酪更硬、更碎且风味更浓[5]。
综上，通过调整乳源、菌种、加工强度和熟成期，即可制得从新鲜柔软到陈年坚硬的多样奶酪[1]。
claims_retained: 制作不同类型的奶酪，先选择原料乳：牛、羊或山羊乳因成分差异而影响风味和质地[2]；再接种特定微生物：表面喷霉可制卡门贝、布里等软熟奶酪，其分泌酶分解凝乳、形成流心和独特风味[3]；若用中嗜性启动菌可得切达等硬质奶酪，而耐高温的嗜热菌结合产丙酸菌可制瑞士奶酪并产生典型“眼睛”[4]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: There’s no single method of classifying cheese, and a number of criteria can be used such as length of ageing, texture and region of origin. However, key differences in cheese characteristics can generally be attributed to:

 * the origin of the milk * * specific moulds and bacteria added * varying lengths of ageing
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: While all milk is made up of the same basic elements, its composition varies according to:

 * the type and breed of animal * the season and geographic location * the health and nutrition of the animal.

While most cheese is made using cows’ milk, milk from other animals, especially goats and sheep, is also used
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: Soft, ripened cheeses such as Camembert and Brie have a mould added to the surface, which produces a protein-digesting enzyme. The enzyme breaks down the curd during ripening, creating a runny texture and developing the characteristic flavour
---
Document ID: 4
Title: 创建不同的奶酪特征（www.sciencelearn.org.nz）
Content: 更硬的奶酪经历了更复杂的处理，并且有两个主要组：

 *那些使用中嗜性启动器制成的简单微生物群的人。 *使用嗜热启动细菌制成的瑞士奶酪品种，可以承受更高的加工温度。随后在成熟过程中产生丙酸的细菌的生长有助于这些奶酪的味道，还会产生特征性的气孔或“眼睛”。

有助于去除水分的处理步骤包括：

 *切割和搅拌凝乳 - 更精细的切割释放更多的水分 *加热有助于缩小凝乳并去除更多的乳清 *按下最终的奶酪 - 变化的压力和时间会影响释放的乳清量
---
Document ID: 5
Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: Freshly made cheese usually tastes salty and quite bland, as it is the ageing or ripening period that helps develop flavour. As cheese ages, microbes and enzymes break down the casein proteins, changing the texture and intensifying the flavour of the cheese.

Ripening conditions are carefully controlled with different temperatures and humidity levels affecting the rate of ripening, loss of moisture and rind formation.

The ripening period can be anything from several days to 2 or more years. As the ripening period increases, the cheese loses more moisture, develops a stronger flavour and becomes harder and more crumbly in texture
---

Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: There’s no single method of classifying cheese, and a number of criteria can be used such as length of ageing, texture and region of origin. However, key differences in cheese characteristics can generally be attributed to:

 * the origin of the milk * * specific moulds and bacteria added * varying lengths of ageing

Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: While all milk is made up of the same basic elements, its composition varies according to:

 * the type and breed of animal * the season and geographic location * the health and nutrition of the animal.

While most cheese is made using cows’ milk, milk from other animals, especially goats and sheep, is also used
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: Soft, ripened cheeses such as Camembert and Brie have a mould added to the surface, which produces a protein-digesting enzyme. The enzyme breaks down the curd during ripening, creating a runny texture and developing the characteristic flavour
---

Title: 创建不同的奶酪特征（www.sciencelearn.org.nz）
Content: 更硬的奶酪经历了更复杂的处理，并且有两个主要组：

 *那些使用中嗜性启动器制成的简单微生物群的人。 *使用嗜热启动细菌制成的瑞士奶酪品种，可以承受更高的加工温度。随后在成熟过程中产生丙酸的细菌的生长有助于这些奶酪的味道，还会产生特征性的气孔或“眼睛”。

有助于去除水分的处理步骤包括：

 *切割和搅拌凝乳 - 更精细的切割释放更多的水分 *加热有助于缩小凝乳并去除更多的乳清 *按下最终的奶酪 - 变化的压力和时间会影响释放的乳清量

Document ID: 5
Title: Creating different cheese characteristics (www.sciencelearn.org.nz)
Content: Freshly made cheese usually tastes salty and quite bland, as it is the ageing or ripening period that helps develop flavour. As cheese ages, microbes and enzymes break down the casein proteins, changing the texture and intensifying the flavour of the cheese.

Ripening conditions are carefully controlled with different temperatures and humidity levels affecting the rate of ripening, loss of moisture and rind formation.

The ripening period can be anything from several days to 2 or more years. As the ripening period increases, the cheese loses more moisture, develops a stronger flavour and becomes harder and more crumbly in texture

claim: 嬉皮运动是20世纪60年代美国以白人中产阶级青年和婴儿潮学生为主体的反文化潮流，他们厌倦父母和社会强加的模具与限制，倡导和平、爱与自由
question_src: 什么是嬉皮运动，它是如何开始的，为什么？
all_claims: 嬉皮运动是20世纪60年代美国以白人中产阶级青年和婴儿潮学生为主体的反文化潮流，他们厌倦父母和社会强加的模具与限制，倡导和平、爱与自由[1]。
嬉皮士拒绝追逐金钱，尝试依靠地球资源过更健康的生活[1]，并将这种理念落实为游行、静坐、罢工等和平抗议形式，传播和平与团结的信息[2]。
运动兴起的直接诱因是越南战争；嬉皮士认为政府的贪婪和军事行动是社会问题根源，战争并非解决矛盾之道[1]。
于是，他们以非暴力方式呼吁全国反战，既反抗战争与暴力，也拒绝传统社会期待，迈开了一场寻找自我与重塑价值观的青年文化革命。
claims_retained: 嬉皮运动是20世纪60年代美国以白人中产阶级青年和婴儿潮学生为主体的反文化潮流，他们厌倦父母和社会强加的模具与限制，倡导和平、爱与自由[1]。
嬉皮士拒绝追逐金钱，尝试依靠地球资源过更健康的生活[1]，并将这种理念落实为游行、静坐、罢工等和平抗议形式，传播和平与团结的信息[2]。

Title: 嬉皮运动 - 城市研究101（了解theurban.qwriting.qc.cuny.edu）
Content: 嬉皮士是白人，通常是中产阶级的青少年和婴儿繁荣的一代学生。他们厌倦了被迫适合的模具以及父母对他们的限制。众所周知，嬉皮士会拒绝花任何形式的钱或赚钱。他们相信更多有益健康的生活，并通过地球提供的东西来竭尽所能。

越南战争的导致大部分嬉皮运动发生了。美国人民一直是偏执的，并产生了这种战争愤怒的一种贪婪。美国人建立的紧张局势以及这些白人中产阶级的年轻人带来了改变它的道路。嬉皮运动是关于寻找自己的全部，拒绝遵守社会对我们所有人的期望的必要性。这也是关于与战争和暴力的和平作战。嬉皮士认为，政府是全国所有问题的根源，也是街上猖ramp的贪婪和仇恨。目的是让国家看到战争不是解决问题的答案，而是和平，爱与自由
---

question_src: 什么是嬉皮运动，它是如何开始的，为什么？
all_claims: 嬉皮运动是20世纪60年代美国以白人中产阶级青年和婴儿潮学生为主体的反文化潮流，他们厌倦父母和社会强加的模具与限制，倡导和平、爱与自由[1]。
嬉皮士拒绝追逐金钱，尝试依靠地球资源过更健康的生活[1]，并将这种理念落实为游行、静坐、罢工等和平抗议形式，传播和平与团结的信息[2]。
运动兴起的直接诱因是越南战争；嬉皮士认为政府的贪婪和军事行动是社会问题根源，战争并非解决矛盾之道[1]。
于是，他们以非暴力方式呼吁全国反战，既反抗战争与暴力，也拒绝传统社会期待，迈开了一场寻找自我与重塑价值观的青年文化革命。
claims_retained: 嬉皮运动是20世纪60年代美国以白人中产阶级青年和婴儿潮学生为主体的反文化潮流，他们厌倦父母和社会强加的模具与限制，倡导和平、爱与自由[1]。
嬉皮士拒绝追逐金钱，尝试依靠地球资源过更健康的生活[1]，并将这种理念落实为游行、静坐、罢工等和平抗议形式，传播和平与团结的信息[2]。

Title: The Hippie Movement – Urban Studies 101 (understandingtheurban.qwriting.qc.cuny.edu)
Content: Hippies were the white, typically middle-class teenagers and college students of the baby boom generation. They were tired of the molds they were forced to fit and the restrictions placed upon them by their parents. Hippies were known to refuse spending any sort of money or earning anything. They believed in more wholesome living and doing what they could with what Earth has to offer.

Much of the hippie movement came about as a result of the Vietnam War. The people of the U.S. were constantly paranoid and developed a sort of greed that came along with the anger of this war. Tensions among Americans built, and these white, middle-class youngsters lead the way to change it. The hippie movement was all about finding oneself and rejecting the need to conform to what society expects of us all. It was also about fighting peacefully against war and violence. Hippies believed that the government was the root of all the country’s problems as well as greed and hatred that ran rampant in the streets. The goal was to get the country to see that war is not the answer to its problems, but rather peace, love, and freedom

question_src: 为什么无证移民返回墨西哥开车的工资，但放松移民的支持者说他们在这里不这样做？
all_claims: 学术界早已指出，移民是否压低工资的结论高度依赖所采用的衡量方法：有的比较不同技能组内部的变化，有的比较不同城市的流入量，得出的结果往往不一致[1]。
放宽移民限制的支持者之所以坚持“在美国总体上看不到工资被拉低”，主要依据的是使用上述方法的综合评估——美国国家科学院的权威分析称“几乎没有证据表明移民对本地出生工人的总体就业或工资水平造成显著负面冲击”[3]。
然而，批评者强调在园艺、洗车等低薪行业，外国出生劳工比例极高，本地低技能工人面临直接竞争，因而其工资可能受到抑制[2]。
当无证移民返回墨西哥时，他们与当地同质工人技能高度重叠，缺乏语言与制度壁垒缓冲，工资挤压效应便更易显现；而在美国，由于产业分工、资本充裕和技能互补等因素，本地总体工资受到的“均摊”与吸收能力更大，这也是支持者强调“不压低工资”的原因。

Content: 关于移民对工资影响的实质性分歧的原因之一是，即使存在相对统一的理论，经济学家也使用几种不同的经验方法来研究工资关系（Altonji and Card 1991）。每种经验方法都使用不同的方法来衡量移民数量的变化来产生工资估计。 Dustmann，Schonberg和Stuhler（2016）总结了三种主要方法为（1）国家技能细胞方法，（2）纯空间方法，以及（3）一种混合方法。国家技能细胞的方法在移民进入国家人口内的不同教育经验群体时使用了差异。纯空间方法使用跨城市或地区移民流的变化。混合方法利用教育群体和地区移民流入的差异。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Does Immigration Reduce Wages? (www.cato.org)
Content: One reason for the substantial disagreement about the effects of immigration on wages is that there are several different empirical methods that economists use to study the wage relationship even though there is a relatively uniform theory (Altonji and Card 1991). Each empirical method uses a different way of measuring variation in the quantity of immigrants to generate wage estimates. Dustmann, Schonberg, and Stuhler (2016) summarize the three major methods as (1) the national skill-cell approach, (2) the pure spatial approach, and (3) a mixed approach. The national skill-cell approach uses variation in the entry of immigrants to different education-experience groups within the national population. The pure spatial approach uses variation in the immigrant flow across cities or regions. The mixed approach uses variation in immigration inflows across both education groups and regions.

question_src: 人类为什么开始剃须？
all_claims: 最早的穴居人在约10万年前就开始用石块或贝壳拔除体毛，约7万年前又利用锋利燧石切除毛发，显示剃须已有深远历史[1]。
其首要动机是卫生——体毛为虱子等寄生虫提供温床，也易在炎热潮湿环境下滋生真菌并加重体味[1]。
到了古埃及，人们把体毛视为“不洁”象征，为彻底驱除害虫并适应高温，男女都从头到脚剃净，并使用含砒霜等苛性脱毛剂[1]。
光滑无毛随后演变为社会地位的象征，富裕阶层甚至雇专职理发师保持“洁净”外貌[2]。

Content: 尽管剃须的确切时间表尚不清楚，但大多数专家和文物都表明，自公元前大约100,000以来，剃须就已经存在，当穴居人一次将它们一次拉出，即使使用像镊子这样的岩石或贝壳来加快过程来消除身体。快进了70，000年，早期的男人已经认识到锋利的火石的价值，不仅对击打火，而且还可以从身体上切掉头发！

然而，直到我们到达埃及文明之前，剃须的真实历史才开始，剃须行为在世界舞台上真正首次亮相。埃及人强烈相信身体头发是不洁的标志，因此男人和女人都从身体上完全从身体上脱掉头发 - 头到脚趾！在某些情况下，这些原始的脱敏霜和剃须乳液中使用了速溶和砷等苛性成分。早期的剃须刀也大约在当时出现，世界许多地区的金属加工和采矿的上升。埃及与清洁和身体头发的关系在痴迷中接壤，上层阶级通常每天沐浴多次。他们会完全剃光头，然后设计冷却假发以在公共场合磨损。

对不清洁的恐惧是一个真正的问题，也可能是史前人剃须的早期原因。身体为虱子和其他不需要的小动物提供了理想的环境，也可以成为真菌感染的繁殖场，尤其是在炎热或潮湿的天气下。埃及人试图通过消除任何可以壮成长的环境来消除害虫或病原体的风险！此外，在埃及的炎热和潮湿的天气中，过多的身体发型导致体味更快地发展，这是僵化的埃及社会中不洁的另一个迹象。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: History of shaving: When did men and women start shaving? (www.scienceabc.com)
Content: Although the exact timeline of shaving isn’t clear, most experts and found artifacts suggest that shaving has been around since approximately 100,000 BC, when cavemen would eliminate hair from their body by pulling them out one at a time, even using rocks or shells like tweezers to speed the process. Fast-forward another 70,000 years and early man has recognized the value of sharpened flint, not only good for striking fire, but also for delicately slicing off hair from the body!

[Image: not only do i keep my face smooth but i also built this computer meme]

The real history of shaving, however, doesn’t begin until we reach the Egyptian civilization, where the act of shaving made its real debut on the world stage. Egyptians had a powerful belief that body hair was a sign of uncleanliness, so both men and women engaged in the complete removal of hair from the body—head to toe! In some cases, caustic ingredients like quicklime and arsenic were used in these primitive depilatory creams and shaving lotions. Early razors also appeared around the time, with the rise in metalworking and mining in many areas of the world. The Egyptian relationship to cleanliness and body hair bordered on the obsessive, and the upper classes often bathed multiple times per day. They would shave their heads completely bald, and then design cooling wigs to wear out in public.

The fear of uncleanliness was a real concern, and may have been the early reason for prehistoric man to shave as well. Body hair provides an ideal environment for lice and other unwanted critters, and can also be a breeding ground for fungal infections, particularly in hot or humid weather. Egyptians attempted to eliminate the risk of pests or pathogens by removing any environment where they could thrive! Furthermore, in the hot and humid weather of Egypt, having an excess of body hair led to the much faster development of body odor, another sign of uncleanliness within the rigid Egyptian society.

question_src: 法官如何允许像必须坐在垃圾场中八个小时的女人那样发出异常句子？
all_claims: 在美国多数州，刑法只规定了监禁、罚金或社区服务等“框架”惩罚上限，法官在此范围内拥有广泛自由裁量权，可把社区服务设计成具有教育或羞辱意味的“个性化”任务；例如俄亥俄州的迈克尔·西科蒂法官每天处理约40起案件，经常用“适合其罪”的非常规方式取代传统刑期[1]。
只要这种做法未超过法定最高刑、未违反被告的基本权利（如第八修正案禁止的残酷和非常惩罚）且通常作为被告自愿选择的缓刑条件，便被视为合法[2]。
美国法院和上诉机制会审查创意量刑是否“走得太远”，因此像让偷窃宠物的女子在垃圾场坐八小时的命令，若旨在惩戒并符合法定社区劳动的性质，就能通过审查[2]。
这种“公开羞辱”源于殖民时代的股票台传统，如今被一些法官当作提高震慑力、减轻监狱负担的手段[3]。

Title: For Shame! Public Shaming Sentences on the Rise (www.prisonlegalnews.org)
Content: Punishments intended to shame offenders for wrongdoing, popular throughout history, are once again on the rise – particularly as penalties imposed by judges who enjoy seeing their names in the newspaper or on television due to their “creative” sentencing practices.


Whether judges hand down sentences that humiliate defendants for the purpose of entertainment, self-aggrandizement or as a unique way of deterring crime with a “punishment that fits” is subject to debate. The only certainty is that most sanctions designed to shame offenders are legal, so long as judges do not go too far.

Title: For Shame! Public Shaming Sentences on the Rise (www.prisonlegalnews.org)
Content: Shaming criminals has long been an integral part of America’s criminal justice system, and public whipping and the stocks were commonly used in Puritan and colonial times. During that era, imprisonment was reserved for debtors and those awaiting trial; upon conviction, a judge could order an offender to be executed, flogged, banished or shamed

all_claims: 在美国多数州，刑法只规定了监禁、罚金或社区服务等“框架”惩罚上限，法官在此范围内拥有广泛自由裁量权，可把社区服务设计成具有教育或羞辱意味的“个性化”任务；例如俄亥俄州的迈克尔·西科蒂法官每天处理约40起案件，经常用“适合其罪”的非常规方式取代传统刑期[1]。
只要这种做法未超过法定最高刑、未违反被告的基本权利（如第八修正案禁止的残酷和非常惩罚）且通常作为被告自愿选择的缓刑条件，便被视为合法[2]。
美国法院和上诉机制会审查创意量刑是否“走得太远”，因此像让偷窃宠物的女子在垃圾场坐八小时的命令，若旨在惩戒并符合法定社区劳动的性质，就能通过审查[2]。
这种“公开羞辱”源于殖民时代的股票台传统，如今被一些法官当作提高震慑力、减轻监狱负担的手段[3]。

Title: Ohio Judge Michael Cicconetti uses 'personal sentences' for justice (www.dailymail.co.uk)
Content: Meet Judge Michael Cicconetti, who may possibly be America's most eccentric lawman.


The judge, who presides over up to 40 cases daily at Painesville Municipal Court in Ohio, has made a habit of offering criminals 'personal' sentences that fit their offense - instead of traditional ones
---
Document ID: 2
Title: For Shame! Public Shaming Sentences on the Rise (www.prisonlegalnews.org)
Content: Punishments intended to shame offenders for wrongdoing, popular throughout history, are once again on the rise – particularly as penalties imposed by judges who enjoy seeing their names in the newspaper or on television due to their “creative” sentencing practices.


Whether judges hand down sentences that humiliate defendants for the purpose of entertainment, self-aggrandizement or as a unique way of deterring crime with a “punishment that fits” is subject to debate. The only certainty is that most sanctions designed to shame offenders are legal, so long as judges do not go too far.
---

claim: 有些人拥有“可爱”的笔迹，而另一些人则笔迹潦草，最核心的差异在于精细运动发展与训练强度：手写教学通常在幼年进行，此时女孩的精细运动技能往往领先于男孩，因此她们更易写出匀称流畅的字形 [1]；若缺乏对手、前臂与肩部正确肌肉群的系统训练，笔迹往往难以清晰可辨
question_src: 有些人怎么有可爱的笔迹而其他人没有？
all_claims: 有些人拥有“可爱”的笔迹，而另一些人则笔迹潦草，最核心的差异在于精细运动发展与训练强度：手写教学通常在幼年进行，此时女孩的精细运动技能往往领先于男孩，因此她们更易写出匀称流畅的字形 [1]；若缺乏对手、前臂与肩部正确肌肉群的系统训练，笔迹往往难以清晰可辨 [2]。
持续的书写练习能加强相关肌肉并建立平稳的书写动作，使字形更一致、线条更顺滑 [3]；而在学龄前进行适合年龄的线条和形状练习，可为日后书写打下结构与节奏基础 [4]。
此外，良好的手眼协调通过玩抛接球、迷宫等活动即可得到改善，这有助于控制笔画方向与间距，从而让笔迹更加整洁美观 [5]。
换言之，“可爱”笔迹是早期精细动作成熟度、后续肌群训练、手眼协调与日积月累练习共同作用的结果，而不是天生无法改变的才能 [6]。
claims_retained: 有些人拥有“可爱”的笔迹，而另一些人则笔迹潦草，最核心的差异在于精细运动发展与训练强度：手写教学通常在幼年进行，此时女孩的精细运动技能往往领先于男孩，因此她们更易写出匀称流畅的字形 [1]；若缺乏对手、前臂与肩部正确肌肉群的系统训练，笔迹往往难以清晰可辨 [2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Is thunder during snowstorms more dangerous than regular thunderstorms? (sites.psu.edu)
Content: thunder snow is pretty much what is sounds like. During a snowstorm, thunder forms. It is a very rare and unusual occurrence, but is known to happen in mid-latitude climates, in the United States. When convection is strong enough, thunderstorms can happen even in the winter. Thunder snow can happen in three different instances. The normal one is when a thunderstorm is on the edge of a cold front or a warm front where the precipitation in the atmosphere takes the form of snow. The second instance is when there is a synoptic snowstorm that allows for conditions that make lightning and thunder to occur, but those are the most rare ones. The third one is called the lake effect where a thunderstorm is produced by cold air passing over warmer water, which produces snow squalls that then connect to the thunderstorm.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Are thunder and lightning possible during a snowstorm? (www.msn.com)
Content: Thunder can occur while it's snowing, sleeting, or even during freezing rain.


Thundersnow usually requires extremely strong vertical motion. This tends to exist when there is a large temperature difference across the center of a storm. If warmer air wraps into the storm, the production of lightning can increase.


This might transpire in nor'easters along the east coast and late fall or early spring snowstorms in the Midwest, which tend to feature access to warmer air to the southeast of the storm's center.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: 什么是雷声，为什么会发生？ |天气频道 - 来自天气频道的文章| Weather.com（Weather.com）
Content: 湖泊效应的暴风雪的狭窄云层的形状更像是普通的雷暴，实际上有时会产生雷声和闪电。


[图像：图像]


如第二图所示，大多数雷击事​​件会在“普通”平坦的平面雪云向上或“炮塔”形成上升或“炮塔”时会发展。它们向上升起，在平坦的雪云上方约5,000英尺。当在20,000英尺左右有一些强大的起重机制时，这些炮塔可以发展，例如接近强的中高层槽。上槽的风将较冷的空气高空，举起也使层冷却。空气升起时会冷却。


[图像：图像]


当初始云层上方的空气相对较酷且干燥时，当添加的冷却和举起强烈时，正好在原始平面云上方的浅层层就会变得不稳定。这使其有利于“提升对流”  - 阵雨或雷暴。

claim: 签证（Visa）是一份由目的地国家移民当局签发的官方许可文件，通常以贴纸或盖章形式置于申请人的护照内，用以表明其被允许在限定时间内入境、离境或停留该国
question_src: 什么是签证？ （不是信用卡）
all_claims: 签证（Visa）是一份由目的地国家移民当局签发的官方许可文件，通常以贴纸或盖章形式置于申请人的护照内，用以表明其被允许在限定时间内入境、离境或停留该国[1]。
申请人通常需在该国驻本国的领事馆、使馆办理，如该国未设馆则须前往第三国代馆申请[2]。
各国虽政策不同，但基本流程相似，并依据申请者国籍、访问目的及入境次数划分多种类型，如旅游、商务、工作、学生等签证[3]。
需要提交护照、照片、行程说明等材料，签证获批并不等同于保证入境，最终放行权仍在边防官员[2]。
与护照相比，护照是证明国籍与身份的旅行证件，而签证只是附加其上的入境许可标记[4]。
claims_retained: 签证（Visa）是一份由目的地国家移民当局签发的官方许可文件，通常以贴纸或盖章形式置于申请人的护照内，用以表明其被允许在限定时间内入境、离境或停留该国[1]。

Title: What is a Visa? | US Visa Help (visahelp.us.com)
Content: The visa is issued by the immigration authorities of the country you are planning to visit, usually, a consulate or embassy in your country. In cases when your destination country does not have a consulate or embassy in your home country, you will have to obtain a travel visa at the embassy of another country which is authorized to issue visas for the country you will visit.


Each country has its own visa policy, but the application process for a visa is generally similar. There are many types of travel visas depending on your nationality, destination country, the purpose of travel and even the number of times you wish to visit that country.


There are also a number of requirements that you will have to fulfill which vary from country to country. Although there are not a lot of differences since most of the immigration authorities ask for approximately the same documents, depending on your purpose of travel, you might have to submit some extra or fewer documents.


However, a visa does not guarantee you will enter that country since the border guard has the final decision to make.
---

* Tourist Visa

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Is Ocean Desalination the Answer to the World's Water Shortage? (www.thoughtco.com)
Content: Desalination -- a process whereby highly pressurized ocean water is pushed through tiny membrane filters and distilled into drinking water -- is being held forth by some as one of the most promising solutions to the problem. But critics point out it doesn't come without its economic and environmental costs.

## Costs and Environmental Impact of Desalination

According to the non-profit Food & Water Watch, desalinated ocean water is the most expensive form of fresh water out there, given the infrastructure costs of collecting, distilling and distributing it. The group reports that, in the U.S., desalinated water costs at least five times as much to harvest as other sources of fresh water. Similar high costs are a big hurdle to desalination efforts in poor countries as well, where limited funds are already stretched too thin.

On the environmental front, widespread desalination could take a heavy toll on ocean biodiversity. "Ocean water is filled with living creatures, and most of them are lost in the process of desalination," says Sylvia Earle, one of the world's foremost marine biologists and a National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence. “Most are microbial, but intake pipes to desalination plants also take up the larvae of a cross-section of life in the sea, as well as some fairly large organisms…part of the hidden cost of doing business,” she says.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 将海水变成饮用水有助于水短缺吗？ （www.globalcitizen.org）
Content: 从淡化获得的水费用是淡水来源的两倍。但是现在，加利福尼亚的部分地区没有太多其他选择。

淡化解决水危机的唯一方法是使用可再生能源，降低成本并为海洋生物提供了适当的环境保护。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Seawater Desalination: A Solution To Water Shortage: AMPAC USA (www.wateronline.com)
Content: * Desalination offers the comfort of potable water being available without the stress of exhaustion. * At a larger scale, it provides safe drinking water to thousands of households daily making the supply to everyone a consistent service. * The more advanced plants set up around the world use Reverse Osmosis as the core process for filtration. It is a proven method for potable drinking water. * Countries are less dependent on natural resources which can now begin replenishing via the water cycle. * Even better, the process of RO purification of waste from industries can give safe water that can be used to refill the aquifer, lakes, reservoirs of the region and in turn lifting stress from the environment.

Plants have been set across the world in Australia, U.S, Saudi Arabia and more where each day tens of thousands of gallons of freshwater are produced from an endless supply of the sea.

“It is a growing trend. It has given hope to countries where the geography is not naturally blessed with rivers and reservoirs. People have begun irrigation and agriculture thanks to the abundant supply. Reverse osmosis makes the process effective. Still, we have miles to go in technology regarding its environmental effects,” added Farag.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 海洋淡化是世界水资源短缺的答案吗？ （www.thoughtco.com）
Content: 淡化 - 一种过程，将高度加压的海水推入微小的膜过滤器并蒸馏到饮用水中 - 有些人将其作为解决问题的最有希望的解决方案之一。但是批评家指出，没有它的经济和环境成本。

##淡化的成本和环境影响

根据非营利性食品和水监视，淡化海水是那里最昂贵的淡水形式，鉴于收集，蒸馏和分配的基础设施成本。该组织报告说，在美国，淡化水的成本至少是其他淡水来源的五倍。类似的高成本也是在贫困国家的淡化工作的一个巨大障碍，在贫困国家，有限的资金已经太薄了。

在环境方面，广泛的淡化可能会对海洋生物多样性造成巨大损失。世界上最重要的海洋生物学家，国家地理探险家之一西尔维亚·厄尔（Sylvia Earle）说：“海水充满了生物，其中大多数人在海水淡化过程中迷失了。”她说：“大多数是微生物，但是对海水淡化植物的进气管也占据了海洋横截面的幼虫，以及一些相当大的生物体……是从事业务的隐藏成本的一部分。”
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Will Turning Seawater Into Drinking Water Help Water Shortages? (www.globalcitizen.org)
Content: Water obtained from desalination costs twice the amount of water from freshwater sources. But now, parts of California don’t have many other options.

The only way desalination can be a good option to solving the water crisis is if renewable energy is used, costs are lowered, and environmental protections are put in place for marine life too.

claim: 数百万年前，水果中的糖既稀缺又需冒险攀树获取，因此自然选择强化了对甜味的本能渴求，促使祖先优先摄取这种高能量资源
question_src: 如果蔬菜对我们有好处，为什么我们不像我们喜欢的巧克力一样喜欢它们？
all_claims: 从进化角度看，人类味觉偏好首先服务于生存而非现代“健康”概念。
数百万年前，水果中的糖既稀缺又需冒险攀树获取，因此自然选择强化了对甜味的本能渴求，促使祖先优先摄取这种高能量资源[1]。
当时以天然形式、适量摄入的糖不仅快速提供能量，而且与水果中的多种营养素一起被视为“非常健康”[2]。
相比之下，叶子和其他蔬菜含糖量低、随处可得，对生存的即时价值较小，因而大脑没有为它们建立同等强度的奖赏机制[1]。
进入现代，工业农业让含糖食物（如巧克力）随手可得，而古老的甜味偏好依旧存在，于是我们本能地更喜欢甜食，常常忽略味道较淡、能量密度低的蔬菜[3]。
claims_retained: 数百万年前，水果中的糖既稀缺又需冒险攀树获取，因此自然选择强化了对甜味的本能渴求，促使祖先优先摄取这种高能量资源[1]。
相比之下，叶子和其他蔬菜含糖量低、随处可得，对生存的即时价值较小，因而大脑没有为它们建立同等强度的奖赏机制[1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 人类为什么渴望含糖食品？进化不应该导致我们渴望健康食品吗？ （wtamu.edu）
Content: 简而言之，早期的灵长类动物演变为渴望果实，恰恰是因为这些食物在可用的少量中是如此健康。因为从高高的树上找回水果要比吃任何草或叶子坐在周围要困难，所以需要对糖的天生渴望来驱动早期的灵长类动物。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why do humans crave sugary foods? Shouldn't evolution lead us to crave healthy foods? (wtamu.edu)
Content: Sugar is actually quite healthy when consumed in moderate amounts and in its natural form. The main natural source of sugar is fruit.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Why do humans crave sugary foods? Shouldn't evolution lead us to crave healthy foods? (wtamu.edu)
Content: Now fast forward millions of years to our modern age. With improved agricultural technology, rich countries became able to grow fruits cheaply and in abundance. Instead of being rare caches of calories that could boost survival, fruits became staple foods that could be consumed anytime. The innate craving for sweet foods was still present in humans, but the scarcity of such foods was no longer a problem for many people, leading to over-consumption.
---

低心率并非病态，而是效率提升的体现：心脏在向全身输送同等血液时所需跳动次数更少[2]。

---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why Do Athletes Have a Lower Resting Heart Rate? (www.healthline.com)
Content: Athletes often have a lower resting heart rate than others. If you exercise frequently and are reasonably fit, your heart rate may be lower than other people.


This isn’t necessarily a bad thing. A low heart rate means your heart needs fewer beats to deliver the same amount of blood throughout your body.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Why Do Athletes Have a Lower Heart Rate? | Livestrong.com (www.livestrong.com)
Content: Increased cardiovascular fitness causes real physical changes in the structure of the heart. The muscles in the heart wall thicken, and the heart pumps more blood with each beat. That increased efficiency means an athlete's resting heart rate falls to a level that could indicate trouble in a nonathlete. Many athletes don't realize that high levels of conditioning also cause heart symptoms that doctors might mistake for serious problems.

prompt:

Title: Runners and low heart rate (www.runnersworld.com)
Content: A heart rate of less than 60 is called a bradycardia, or slow heart rate. It is not unusual for healthy people involved in endurance activities to develop a bradycardia based on the increased vagal tone from training that suppresses heart rate. Training also increases the heart size so it can push out a greater volume of blood to the body with each contraction.

question_src: 人们是如何在计算机前操纵照片的？
all_claims: 在计算机出现之前，摄影师与修图师主要依靠手工在底片或相纸上进行物理改动来操纵影像[1]。
他们会在显影阶段使用墨水、油漆、喷枪、刮刀等直接涂抹或刻划，以减淡、遮盖或重绘细节[1]。
为弥补底片对天空曝光不足的缺陷，常先分别拍摄“土地负片”和“天空负片”，再在同一张相纸上拼合打印，甚至反复使用同一块云负片以塑造理想天气[3]。
暗房里亦常用漂白剂局部洗掉银盐，或通过刮擦宝丽来表面创造艺术化笔触效果[1]。
商业修饰师需配合放大镜、喷枪、油漆和极稳的手逐点修补，整个过程既无“历史记录”亦无“图层”，一张照片常耗费数小时乃至数天[2]。
此外，多重曝光、剪贴拼接及手工上色等技术也广泛应用，为后来的数字软件功能奠定了基础[3]。
claims_retained: 在计算机出现之前，摄影师与修图师主要依靠手工在底片或相纸上进行物理改动来操纵影像[1]。
为弥补底片对天空曝光不足的缺陷，常先分别拍摄“土地负片”和“天空负片”，再在同一张相纸上拼合打印，甚至反复使用同一块云负片以塑造理想天气[3]。
暗房里亦常用漂白剂局部洗掉银盐，或通过刮擦宝丽来表面创造艺术化笔触效果[1]。
商业修饰师需配合放大镜、喷枪、油漆和极稳的手逐点修补，整个过程既无“历史记录”亦无“图层”，一张照片常耗费数小时乃至数天[2]。
此外，多重曝光、剪贴拼接及手工上色等技术也广泛应用，为后来的数字软件功能奠定了基础[3]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 照片操纵（en.wikipedia.org）
Content: Hoto操纵可以追溯到19世纪在玻璃和锡板上捕获的一些最早的照片。这种练习不久之后不久就创作了第一张照片（1825年）的JosephNicéphoreNiépce，后者开发了heliography，并用光子雕刻的印刷板制作了第一张照片。[3] [4]可以使用各种涉及直接操纵印刷品的方法和技术来更改传统的摄影印刷品，例如在发育过程中使用墨水，油漆，喷枪或刮擦宝丽来擦洗（宝丽来艺术）。[5]可以使用双曝光技术在摄像机中操纵底片，或者通过将照片或负面拼凑在一起。一些暗房的操作涉及诸如漂白以巧妙地减轻或完全洗净照片的一部分或用于美学目的或模仿美术绘画的技术。[6]
---
Document ID: 2
Title: A Short History of Photo Manipulation (Before Photoshop) (www.creativelive.com)
Content: In a 2013 blog post for Fstoppers, professional retoucher Pratik Naik described the painstaking process as such:


“Need to zoom into a photo? Be sure to bust out the magnifying glass and a bottle of patience along with that steady hand of yours. No sorry, there’s no history states or layers. You can also forget about that wonderful healing brush! Here’s a paint brush instead”


Art directors, graphic designers, and publishers labored long hours over images, attempting to perfect skin, materials, and other issues which, today, would be easily whisked away with the click of a mouse. Tools like paint, erasers, airbrushes, and other art supplies were necessary in any studio — as was a steady hand and a keen eye for color and shadow. You can even see some of the hard work that went into perfecting photos in this annotation of a famous Dennis Stock image, which has been marked up by Pablo Inirio.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What Did We Do Before Photoshop? (www.pbs.org)
Content: MIA FINEMAN: Most of the earliest manipulated photographs were attempts to compensate for the new medium’s technical limitations — specifically, its inability to depict the world as it appears to the naked eye.


When photography was first introduced in 1839, people wondered how a medium that could render forms and textures with such exquisite detail could fail to register the ever-present element of color. Eager to please potential customers, photographers immediately resorted to manual intervention, enlivening their pictures with powdered pigment, watercolor and oil paint.


Early photography was color-blind in other ways as well. In the 19th century, photographic emulsions were much more sensitive to blue and violet light than to other colors on the spectrum, which meant that blue skies almost always appeared blotchy and overexposed. To overcome the problem, many landscape photographers would make two separate negatives — one exposed for the land, the other for the sky — and print them together on a single sheet of paper. The French photographer Gustave Le Gray used this technique in his majestic seascapes of the 1850s. The exhibition features three seascapes by Le Gray, all using the same cloud negative. The show also includes a great pair of before-and-after landscapes by the American photographer Carleton Watkins — one with a blank white sky, the other with added clouds.
---
Using the above information, the response is the answer to the query or task: "人们是如何在计算机前操纵照片的？" in a single sentence.
You MUST cite the most relevant document by including only its Source ID in brackets at the end of the sentence (e.g., [Source ID]).
Do NOT include any additional words inside or outside the brackets.
Please output ONLY the number of the Source ID that is most relevant to the sentence.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Photograph manipulation (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: hoto manipulation dates back to some of the earliest photographs captured on glass and tin plates during the 19th century. The practice began not long after the creation of the first photograph (1825) by Joseph Nicéphore Niépce who developed heliography and made the first photographic print from a photoengraved printing plate.[3][4] Traditional photographic prints can be altered using various methods and techniques that involve manipulation directly to the print, such as retouching with ink, paint, airbrushing, or scratching Polaroids during developing (Polaroid art).[5] Negatives can be manipulated while still in the camera using double-exposure techniques, or in the darkroom by piecing photos or negatives together. Some darkroom manipulations involved techniques such as bleaching to artfully lighten or totally wash-out parts of the photograph, or hand coloring for aesthetic purposes or to mimic a fine art painting.[6]
---
Document ID: 2
Title: A Short History of Photo Manipulation (Before Photoshop) (www.creativelive.com)
Content: In a 2013 blog post for Fstoppers, professional retoucher Pratik Naik described the painstaking process as such:


“Need to zoom into a photo? Be sure to bust out the magnifying glass and a bottle of patience along with that steady hand of yours. No sorry, there’s no history states or layers. You can also forget about that wonderful healing brush! Here’s a paint brush instead”


Art directors, graphic designers, and publishers labored long hours over images, attempting to perfect skin, materials, and other issues which, today, would be easily whisked away with the click of a mouse. Tools like paint, erasers, airbrushes, and other art supplies were necessary in any studio — as was a steady hand and a keen eye for color and shadow. You can even see some of the hard work that went into perfecting photos in this annotation of a famous Dennis Stock image, which has been marked up by Pablo Inirio.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: 我们在Photoshop之前做了什么？ （www.pbs.org）
Content: MIA Fineman：大多数最早的操纵照片都是试图弥补新媒体的技术局限性的尝试 - 特别是它无法描绘出肉眼看来的世界。


当摄影于1839年首次引入时，人们想知道如何以如此精致的细节呈现形式和纹理的媒介可能无法注册鲜明的色彩元素。渴望吸引潜在客户的摄影师立即诉诸手动干预，用粉状颜料，水彩和油漆使他们的照片充满活力。


早期摄影也是其他方式的色盲。在19世纪，摄影乳液对蓝色和紫罗兰色的光更敏感，而不是对频谱上的其他颜色，这意味着蓝天几乎总是显得斑点和暴露过度。为了克服这个问题，许多景观摄影师会做出两个单独的负面因素 - 一种暴露在土地上，另一个是天空 - 并将它们一起在一张纸上打印在一起。法国摄影师古斯塔夫·勒·格雷（Gustave Le Gray）在1850年代雄伟的海景中使用了这种技术。该展览的特色是Le Grey的三个海景，所有海景都使用相同的云负面。该节目还包括美国摄影师卡尔顿·沃特金斯（Carleton Watkins）的一对前后风景，一个是空白的白色天空，另一个带有云彩。
---

艺术导演，图形设计师和出版商在图像上工作了很长时间，试图完善皮肤，材料和其他问题，如今，这些问题将很容易被鼠标击中。在任何工作室中，都必须使用油漆，橡皮擦，喷枪和其他艺术品等工具 - 稳定的手，对色彩和阴影的敏锐眼光也是如此。您甚至可以看到在著名的Dennis Stock Image的注释中完善照片的一些艰苦工作，该图像已由Pablo Inirio标记。

Eager to please potential customers, photographers immediately resorted to manual intervention, enlivening their pictures with powdered pigment, watercolor and oil paint.


Early photography was color-blind in other ways as well. In the 19th century, photographic emulsions were much more sensitive to blue and violet light than to other colors on the spectrum, which meant that blue skies almost always appeared blotchy and overexposed. To overcome the problem, many landscape photographers would make two separate negatives — one exposed for the land, the other for the sky — and print them together on a single sheet of paper. The French photographer Gustave Le Gray used this technique in his majestic seascapes of the 1850s. The exhibition features three seascapes by Le Gray, all using the same cloud negative. The show also includes a great pair of before-and-after landscapes by the American photographer Carleton Watkins — one with a blank white sky, the other with added clouds.

question_src: 人们是如何在计算机前操纵照片的？
all_claims: 在计算机出现之前，摄影师与修图师主要依靠手工在底片或相纸上进行物理改动来操纵影像[1]。
他们会在显影阶段使用墨水、油漆、喷枪、刮刀等直接涂抹或刻划，以减淡、遮盖或重绘细节[1]。
为弥补底片对天空曝光不足的缺陷，常先分别拍摄“土地负片”和“天空负片”，再在同一张相纸上拼合打印，甚至反复使用同一块云负片以塑造理想天气[3]。
暗房里亦常用漂白剂局部洗掉银盐，或通过刮擦宝丽来表面创造艺术化笔触效果[1]。
商业修饰师需配合放大镜、喷枪、油漆和极稳的手逐点修补，整个过程既无“历史记录”亦无“图层”，一张照片常耗费数小时乃至数天[2]。
此外，多重曝光、剪贴拼接及手工上色等技术也广泛应用，为后来的数字软件功能奠定了基础[3]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Photograph manipulation (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: hoto manipulation dates back to some of the earliest photographs captured on glass and tin plates during the 19th century. The practice began not long after the creation of the first photograph (1825) by Joseph Nicéphore Niépce who developed heliography and made the first photographic print from a photoengraved printing plate.[3][4] Traditional photographic prints can be altered using various methods and techniques that involve manipulation directly to the print, such as retouching with ink, paint, airbrushing, or scratching Polaroids during developing (Polaroid art).[5] Negatives can be manipulated while still in the camera using double-exposure techniques, or in the darkroom by piecing photos or negatives together. Some darkroom manipulations involved techniques such as bleaching to artfully lighten or totally wash-out parts of the photograph, or hand coloring for aesthetic purposes or to mimic a fine art painting.[6]
---
Document ID: 2
Title: A Short History of Photo Manipulation (Before Photoshop) (www.creativelive.com)
Content: In a 2013 blog post for Fstoppers, professional retoucher Pratik Naik described the painstaking process as such:


“Need to zoom into a photo? Be sure to bust out the magnifying glass and a bottle of patience along with that steady hand of yours. No sorry, there’s no history states or layers. You can also forget about that wonderful healing brush! Here’s a paint brush instead”


Art directors, graphic designers, and publishers labored long hours over images, attempting to perfect skin, materials, and other issues which, today, would be easily whisked away with the click of a mouse. Tools like paint, erasers, airbrushes, and other art supplies were necessary in any studio — as was a steady hand and a keen eye for color and shadow. You can even see some of the hard work that went into perfecting photos in this annotation of a famous Dennis Stock image, which has been marked up by Pablo Inirio.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: 我们在Photoshop之前做了什么？ （www.pbs.org）
Content: MIA Fineman：大多数最早的操纵照片都是试图弥补新媒体的技术局限性的尝试 - 特别是它无法描绘出肉眼看来的世界。


当摄影于1839年首次引入时，人们想知道如何以如此精致的细节呈现形式和纹理的媒介可能无法注册鲜明的色彩元素。渴望吸引潜在客户的摄影师立即诉诸手动干预，用粉状颜料，水彩和油漆使他们的照片充满活力。


早期摄影也是其他方式的色盲。在19世纪，摄影乳液对蓝色和紫罗兰色的光更敏感，而不是对频谱上的其他颜色，这意味着蓝天几乎总是显得斑点和暴露过度。为了克服这个问题，许多景观摄影师会做出两个单独的负面因素 - 一种暴露在土地上，另一个是天空 - 并将它们一起在一张纸上打印在一起。法国摄影师古斯塔夫·勒·格雷（Gustave Le Gray）在1850年代雄伟的海景中使用了这种技术。该展览的特色是Le Grey的三个海景，所有海景都使用相同的云负面。该节目还包括美国摄影师卡尔顿·沃特金斯（Carleton Watkins）的一对前后风景，一个是空白的白色天空，另一个带有云彩。
---

question_src: 赌场正在印度保护的趋势是如何开始的？他们为什么选择赌场而不是在土地上保护其他东西？
all_claims: 美国原住民在保留地开设赌场的潮流始于1970年代末至1980年代初，导火索是最高法院裁定各州无权在保留地征税或监管博彩活动，促使部落率先经营高回报的“印度宾果”游戏[1]。
1988年《印度博彩监管法》确立了联邦监管框架，博彩遂成为众多部落“取回其主权和经济独立性”的核心经济策略[3]。
相比耕作、制造等受州法限制且资本要求高的产业，博彩因部落主权豁免而监管障碍低、启动快、现金流充裕；其收益可直接用于住房、医疗、教育等急需项目，带来显著社会和经济改善[3]。
数据显示，1996-2008年部落赌场总收入年均增长12.9%，仅2009年短暂下滑后继续上升，印证了该行业的高盈利能力[4]。
正因监管优势、见效速度和收益规模远超其他产业，赌场成为保留地优先发展的经济项目。

question_src: 为什么不同的欧洲语言对德国有如此不同的名字？
all_claims: 德国直到1871年才由俾斯麦统一，此前长期由不同部落和公国分割，各民族遂以自己最常接触或最具代表性的部落、地域特征来称呼这片土地[1]。
法语 Allemagne、西班牙语 Alemania 源于与法国相邻的阿勒曼尼人[1]；芬兰语 Saksa 与爱沙尼亚语 Saksamaa 取自活跃于波罗的海的萨克逊人[1]。
罗马人使用拉丁语 Germania 指“日耳曼部落之地”，英语直到16世纪左右才出现 Germany，此前曾称 Almain、Alman 等[2]。
北欧语系的 Tyskland、荷兰语 Duitsland 以及德语 Deutschland 都源自原始日耳曼语 *þeudō/þeudiskaz，意为“民族、人民”[3]。
斯拉夫语如波兰语 Niemcy、捷克语 Německo 源于原始斯拉夫词根 něm-，意指“哑巴”，引申为“不说本地话的外国人”，后来专指德国人[3]。
波罗的语族词形 Vācija（拉脱维亚语）、Vokietija（立陶宛语）尚无定论，可能源于原始印欧语 *wek“说话”或维京称谓[3]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 为什么德国有这么多名字？ | Supertext-Magazin（blog.supertext.ch）
Content: 在冷战期间，德国在东西方之间被分裂，但这远非该国第一次分为领土。我们今天所知道的德国直到19世纪才真正形成，当时奥托·冯·巴斯马克（Otto von Bismarck United）在1871年以不同的习俗，姓名和方言为帝国的政治独立地区。


这意味着大多数“德国”术语源于德国真正不存在的时期。取而代之的是，阿尔萨斯（Alsace）讲德语的地区和巴登·韦尔滕伯格（Baden-Württemberg）地区与法国接壤的地区有“ Alemanni”部落，他们说“ Allemagne”。同时，在爱沙尼亚和芬兰，今天德国分别被称为萨克萨马和萨克萨，人们在与德国人打交道时通常会想到撒克逊人。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why does Germany have so many names? | Supertext-Magazin (blog.supertext.ch)
Content: When the Roman Empire was taking over Europe, Germania was the Latin term used to describe the area inhabited by Germanic tribes. However, ‘German’ and ‘Germany’ only began to be used in English around the 1500s; before that, ‘Almain’, ‘Alman’ and ‘Dutch’ were used – which brings us to the next category.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Why does Germany have so many names? | Supertext-Magazin (blog.supertext.ch)
Content: Tyskland (Scandinavian languages like Danish and Swedish), Duitsland (Dutch) and, of course, Deutschland (German) were terms that likely developed from the Proto-Germanic þeudō or Þeudiskaz, which respectively mean ‘nation’ and ‘of the people’. Indeed, these are the variations used (or that used to be used) in Germanic languages themselves.


## Not our people


Slavic terms for Germany, like Niemcy (Polish) or Německo (Czech), have an altogether different origin. They come from the Proto-Slavic němьcь, which means ‘mute’. The word went on to be used to describe foreigners (i.e. people who couldn’t speak the local languages), who frequently turned out to be Germanic people.


## Who knows?


There’s no definitive answer for where the Baltic terms like Vācija (Latvian) and Vokietija (Lithuanian) come from. Some think they stem from the Proto-Indo-European word *wek (which means ‘to speak’), while others suggest that they could have developed from terms used for the Vikings.
---

Title: Why does Germany have so many names? | Supertext-Magazin (blog.supertext.ch)
Content: Germany was split between East and West during the Cold War, but that was far from the first time the nation was divided into territories. Germany as we know it today didn’t actually form until the 19th century, when Otto von Bismarck united politically independent regions with different customs, names and dialects into an empire in 1871.


This means that most terms for ‘Germany’ stem from a time when Germany didn’t really exist. Instead, there was the ‘Alemanni’ tribe in the German-speaking part of the Alsace and the Baden-Württemberg region bordering France, where they say ‘Allemagne’. Meanwhile, in Estonia and Finland, where Germany today is known as Saksamaa and Saksa respectively, people generally thought of Saxons when dealing with Germans.

罗马人使用拉丁语 Germania 指“日耳曼部落之地”，英语直到16世纪左右才出现 Germany，此前曾称 Almain、Alman 等[2]。
北欧语系的 Tyskland、荷兰语 Duitsland 以及德语 Deutschland 都源自原始日耳曼语 *þeudō/þeudiskaz，意为“民族、人民”[3]。
斯拉夫语如波兰语 Niemcy、捷克语 Německo 源于原始斯拉夫词根 něm-，意指“哑巴”，引申为“不说本地话的外国人”，后来专指德国人[3]。
波罗的语族词形 Vācija（拉脱维亚语）、Vokietija（立陶宛语）尚无定论，可能源于原始印欧语 *wek“说话”或维京称谓[3]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why does Germany have so many names? | Supertext-Magazin (blog.supertext.ch)
Content: Germany was split between East and West during the Cold War, but that was far from the first time the nation was divided into territories. Germany as we know it today didn’t actually form until the 19th century, when Otto von Bismarck united politically independent regions with different customs, names and dialects into an empire in 1871.


This means that most terms for ‘Germany’ stem from a time when Germany didn’t really exist. Instead, there was the ‘Alemanni’ tribe in the German-speaking part of the Alsace and the Baden-Württemberg region bordering France, where they say ‘Allemagne’. Meanwhile, in Estonia and Finland, where Germany today is known as Saksamaa and Saksa respectively, people generally thought of Saxons when dealing with Germans.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why does Germany have so many names? | Supertext-Magazin (blog.supertext.ch)
Content: When the Roman Empire was taking over Europe, Germania was the Latin term used to describe the area inhabited by Germanic tribes. However, ‘German’ and ‘Germany’ only began to be used in English around the 1500s; before that, ‘Almain’, ‘Alman’ and ‘Dutch’ were used – which brings us to the next category.
---

Title: 为什么德国有这么多名字？ | Supertext-Magazin（blog.supertext.ch）
Content: 泰斯克兰（丹麦语和瑞典语等斯堪的纳维亚语言），杜伊斯兰（荷兰语），当然还有德国（德语），这可能是从原始的 - 德国人Þeudō或þeudiskaz中发展出来的，分别是“民族”和“人民”的意思。确实，这些是日耳曼语本身使用的（或曾经使用过的）的变体。


##不是我们的人


德国的斯拉夫语术语，例如Niemcy（波兰）或NěMecko（捷克），其起源完全不同。它们来自原始的斯拉夫něm-cc  - ，意思是“静音”。这个词继续用于描述外国人（即无法说本地语言的人），他们经常被证明是日耳曼人。


##谁知道？


对于诸如Vācija（Latvian）和Vokietija（Lithuanian）之类的波罗的海术语来看，没有确切的答案。有些人认为它们源于原始印度 - 欧洲词 *wek（意思是“说话”），而另一些人则认为它们可以从维京人使用的术语中发展出来。

question_src: 当您的体内还将宣传为0卡路里的食物和饮料如何被代谢并用作能量？
all_claims: 卡路里是能量单位，代表食物被人体氧化时可释放的能量[4]。
市面标榜“0卡”的食品可分为天然低能量高纤维蔬果（如芹菜、黄瓜）与采用非营养性甜味剂的加工饮料或零食。
前者虽标签写零，但仍含微量碳水与纤维；消化它们需耗费热效应，却不足以抵消其自身热量，对整体能量收支影响极小[1]。
纤维大多无法被人体酶分解，仅少部分经肠菌发酵成短链脂肪酸后在肝脏产生约1–2 kcal/g的能量，仍远低于常规碳水[2]。
人工“零卡”饮料几乎不提供热量，但甜味信号令身体预期能量输入，若热量未到来，可激发饥饿反应，使随后摄入的高热量食物增加，从而间接储存更多脂肪[3]。
此外，高度加工的零卡食品因加工度高、消化负担低并含多种添加剂，可能抑制基础脂肪氧化率并诱发炎症，进一步促进脂肪堆积[3]。
因此，这类食品在体内要么仅产生极少直接能量，要么通过扰乱食欲与代谢间接提高总能量摄入。

Title: The Truth About Zero-Calorie Drinks and Foods (www.yahoo.com)
Content: In fact, zero calorie foods cause us to gain weight in several ways, according to our crack researchers at Eat This, Not That! (who will continue to report out the story on EatThis.com):


* They dampen your natural fat burners. The body burns a lot of calories trying to turn a pat of butter into a pat of you. But highly processed foods—which is what most zero calorie foods are—come so highly processed that they’re basically digested for you, so they don’t keep the body’s natural fat-burners firing.


* They cause inflammation—and that causes weight gain. Introduce a bunch of chemicals into your digestive tract and you’re basically introducing an irritant. That can interfere with the body’s ability to absorb nutrients in food, and it calls the digestive system’s natural defenses into play, creating inflammation. Inflammation causes our fat genes to “turn on,” increasing belly fat. (Speaking of: To melt away your belly, check out the essential Daily Habits That Blast Belly Fat)


* They mess up our ability to regulate what we eat. Here’s why: When you swallow that diet soda, the sweet taste makes your body anticipate the arrival of calories. And when the calories don’t show up, your body gets confused, and triggers your hunger response, sending you looking high and low for those missing calories—and often finding them in a snack bowl.

因此，这类食品在体内要么仅产生极少直接能量，要么通过扰乱食欲与代谢间接提高总能量摄入。

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How I Sleep in a Noisy City Apartment | Sleeping.Guide (sleeping.guide)
Content: Sleep is extremely important to our well-being. A good sleep means good health, ability to focus, and better happiness overall. However, it’s so easy for sleepiness to be ruined by a sudden high-pitched police alarm or the cheers of drunken revelers. The reason this is such an issue is that, unlike a constant noise, or brains just can’t get used to sudden volume spikes. Every sudden noise could be a danger, which leaves us permanently on alert and unable to relax. After all, sleep is when we’re most defenseless, so our brain really doesn’t want to ‘switch off’ when there’s what seems like potential danger.

Document ID: 2
Title: 我如何在嘈杂的城市公寓里睡觉|睡觉。
Content: 白噪声可以帮助这一点。假设汽车号角是70分贝的声音。如果您躺在几乎完全沉默中，也许外面有一点风，那大约是20分贝。突然的50分贝跳跃是巨大的，它将完全春天您醒着。取而代之的是，如果您有白噪声发生器或正在从扬声器/笔记本电脑上播放白噪声，那么这可能是50分贝的不错，连续的声音（几乎是正常对话的水平）。突然，同样的70分贝汽车噪音只是20分贝的跳跃。它不那么明显了，而且震惊您被震动的可能性要少得多。

Document ID: 3
Title: Best tips if you’re having trouble sleeping due to noise (www.ressleep.com.au)
Content: Reactions to sounds during sleep can be influenced by meaning and significance. Sounds indicating possible danger—even very quiet sounds, like the opening of a door—often will easily wake a sleeping person. Hearing their children cry usually causes parents to wake almost instantly. These responses to noise are highly individual, and a sign of how deeply engaged the brain remains to external stimuli during sleep.

question_src: 电影“交易场所”中的证券交易所部分
all_claims: 在影片高潮的交易所场景中，杜克兄弟凭伪造农作物报告误判橙汁将短缺，开盘后不断“做多”冷冻浓缩橙汁期货，试图通过“低买高卖”的传统方式获利[1]。
而拿到真实报告的路易和比利·雷则在高位大量“卖空”，即先以虚高价格卖出自己并未持有的合约，计划稍后再买入交割[1]。
官方报告公布后，市场发现供应充足，价格暴跌，其他交易者竞相抛售以止损；二人趁机低价回补合约，在不到一小时内获利数亿美元，令杜克兄弟血本无归[2]。
这一幕揭示了卖空在预知价格下跌时的高杠杆收益，也突显依赖内幕信息的法律与财务风险[2]。
claims_retained: 在影片高潮的交易所场景中，杜克兄弟凭伪造农作物报告误判橙汁将短缺，开盘后不断“做多”冷冻浓缩橙汁期货，试图通过“低买高卖”的传统方式获利[1]。
这一幕揭示了卖空在预知价格下跌时的高杠杆收益，也突显依赖内幕信息的法律与财务风险[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 电影交易场所可以教会我们有关股票市场的知识（www.canstar.com.au）
Content: 杜克兄弟（Duke Brothers）试图长期以橙汁的期货为例，而路易（Louis）和比利·雷（Billy Ray）正在实施短暂的销售策略。长期的策略是在股市上赚钱的传统方式。低购买和销售高。一个简短的策略是相反的，卖得很高，购买低价。


杜克斯（Dukes）认为，由于伪造的农作物报告，橙汁将短缺，因此价格会飙升。因此，通过购买所有可用的果汁，当揭示短缺时，每个人都必须以高昂的价格从中购买。另一方面，路易（Louis）和比利·雷（Billy Ray）知道有很多果汁可用，并开始以杜克斯（Dukes）创造的高价出售合同。重要的是，他们承诺要提供他们实际上尚未拥有的橙汁，但正计划在释放农作物报告后购买所需的果汁。


一旦公开官方报告，所有其他交易者都迫切希望出售，以最大程度地减少损失。实际上，他们已经损失了，但是如果他们可以出售自己购买的果汁，那么他们也许可以赚到一点钱。由于其他交易者疯狂地销售，路易斯和比利·雷（Louis and Billy Ray）可以非常便宜地购买所需的所有橙汁，以履行他们已经签订的合同。如果他们无法购买所需的果汁，他们将违约，承诺的交货，使他们欠了数百万美元。卖空可能是一种有利可图的策略，但这也是一种冒险的策略。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Short-selling explained (case study: movie "Trading Places") (im-an-economist.blogspot.com)
Content: Going back to the movie, the question is how was it possible for Winthorpe and Valentine to make hundreds of millions in one hour on the trading floor, while simultaneously bankrupting Duke and Duke (the final scene)?


The answer: Short-selling. And of course: rigged insider information. This is the most important piece of the puzzle. Short-selling can only be fully efficient if you know the price will go down. Then you can scam everyone else easily.


The insider information I'm referring to is the Dept of Agriculture crop report for oranges (they're trading a commodity - frozen orange juice). The Dukes hired their secret agent Mr Beeks to get them the report before anyone else sees it. Unfortunately for them, Winthorpe and Valentine get their hands on the report before the Dukes do and feed them false information. The Dukes are led to believe that the weather was bad and so the harvest was less than normal. Therefore the Dukes are expecting high prices (low supply + high demand = high prices). However the actual report signals the opposite - the harvest was unaffected by the bad weather, and the supply will be plentiful. Hence the scope for short-selling, as Winthorpe and Valentine know that the price is likely to go down.
---

而拿到真实报告的路易和比利·雷则在高位大量“卖空”，即先以虚高价格卖出自己并未持有的合约，计划稍后再买入交割[1]。
官方报告公布后，市场发现供应充足，价格暴跌，其他交易者竞相抛售以止损；二人趁机低价回补合约，在不到一小时内获利数亿美元，令杜克兄弟血本无归[2]。
这一幕揭示了卖空在预知价格下跌时的高杠杆收益，也突显依赖内幕信息的法律与财务风险[2]。
claims_retained: 在影片高潮的交易所场景中，杜克兄弟凭伪造农作物报告误判橙汁将短缺，开盘后不断“做多”冷冻浓缩橙汁期货，试图通过“低买高卖”的传统方式获利[1]。
这一幕揭示了卖空在预知价格下跌时的高杠杆收益，也突显依赖内幕信息的法律与财务风险[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: What The Film Trading Places Can Teach Us About the Stock Market (www.canstar.com.au)
Content: The Duke brothers are attempting to go long on orange juice futures, while Louis and Billy Ray are implementing a short selling strategy. A long strategy is the traditional way of making money on the stock markets; buying low and selling high. A short strategy is the reverse, selling high and buying low.


The Dukes believe because of the fake crop report that there will be a shortage of orange juice, and the price will therefore skyrocket. So, by buying all the juice available now, when the shortage is revealed, everyone will have to buy it off of them at inflated prices. Louis and Billy Ray, on the other hand, know that there is plenty of juice available, and begin selling contracts at the high price the Dukes have created. Importantly, they are promising to deliver orange juice that they don’t actually own yet, but are planning to buy up the juice they need to deliver after the crop report is released.


Once the official report is made public, all the other traders are desperate to sell, in order to minimise their losses. In fact, they have already made a loss, but if they can sell the juice that they have bought, then they might be able to make back a little of their money. Because the other traders are frantically selling, Louis and Billy Ray can buy very cheaply all the orange juice they need in order to fulfil the contracts they have already made. If they weren’t able to buy the juice they needed, they would default on their promised deliveries, leaving them owing potentially millions of dollars. Short selling can be a profitable strategy, but it is also a risky one.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 卖空解释（案例研究：电影“交易场所”）（im-an-Ecomonist.blogspot.com）
Content: 回到电影中，问题是温特普（Winthorpe）和瓦伦丁（Valentine）如何在一小时内在交易楼内制造数亿美元，同时破产杜克和杜克（Duke and Duke）（最后一幕）？


答案：卖空。当然：操纵内部信息。这是难题中最重要的一部分。仅当您知道价格下跌时，卖空才能完全有效。然后，您可以轻松地骗其他所有人。


我所指的内部信息是农业农作物报告的橘子报告（他们正在交易商品 - 冷冻橙汁）。公爵雇用了他们的秘密特工Beeks先生，将其报告给其他人之前。对于他们来说，不幸的是，温特普和情人队在公爵夫妇做之前就可以接受报告，并给他们提供虚假的信息。公爵被认为天气恶劣，因此收成比正常情况不足。因此，公爵预计价格高（低供应 +高需求=高价）。然而，实际报告恰恰相反 - 收成不受恶劣天气的影响，供应将有很多。因此，由于温特普（Winthorpe）和瓦伦丁（Valentine）知道价格可能会下跌，因此卖空的范围。
---

claim: 1787年制宪时，代表们规定总统必须是“自然出生公民”，核心意图是防范外国势力渗透共和国最高军政权力
question_src: 为什么必须在美国出生美国总统有资格竞选？
all_claims: 1787年制宪时，代表们规定总统必须是“自然出生公民”，核心意图是防范外国势力渗透共和国最高军政权力[1]。
约翰·杰伊在给乔治·华盛顿的信中直言，非本土人士若掌握总司令职位，美国难以对其忠诚实施“强有力的检查”，故应明确排除外国出生者[1]。
制宪者的噩梦场景是某位欧洲贵族凭财富与声望操纵选举人团、控制陆军，并把美国重新推向王室统治，这在当时拉法耶特等人在美深受欢迎的背景下并非空想[2]。
他们还警惕波兰因邻国扶植傀儡国王而被瓜分的惨痛先例，认定外国代理人足以拖垮新生国家[2]。
乔治·梅森亦忧虑诸如英国等“富裕外国国家”派出工具，通过贿赂混入联邦公职以达“令人震惊的目的”[3]。
因此，“本土出生”条款被视为确保总统对美国忠诚且免受外部操控的最直接防火墙。

约翰·杰伊在给乔治·华盛顿的信中直言，非本土人士若掌握总司令职位，美国难以对其忠诚实施“强有力的检查”，故应明确排除外国出生者[1]。
他们还警惕波兰因邻国扶植傀儡国王而被瓜分的惨痛先例，认定外国代理人足以拖垮新生国家[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 为什么总统必须是本地出生的？ （slate.com）
Content: 这是第I条第I条的1787年宪法辩论，其中包含“自然诞生”条款，这是很少的主要资料材料。然而，在联邦主义者的论文中多次提到了外国影响力的潜在祸害。最高法院未来第一任首席大法官约翰·杰伊（John Jay）在1787年7月25日的一封信中写信给乔治·华盛顿：


>请允许我暗示，向外国人提供强有力的检查是否是不明智的和调味的；明确地宣布，除了天生的公民之外，美国军队的总司令部不得赋予或推动。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why must presidents be native-born? (slate.com)
Content: Though their concerns may now seem archaic, the framers were genuinely afraid of foreign subversion. Among their nightmare scenarios was the prospect of a European noble using his money and influence to sway the Electoral College, take command of the American army, and return the nascent nation to the royalist fold. At the time, several European figures—such as France’s Marquis de Lafayette, a hero of the Revolutionary War—were quite popular in the New World, so the idea wasn’t completely far-fetched.


The framers also took a lesson from Europe, where dynasties constantly schemed against one another. The men who drafted the Constitution were certainly familiar with the tragic example of Poland, where agents from Russia, Prussia, and Austria conspired to install a friendly monarch, Stanislaus II, and subsequently seized upon his weakness and partitioned the country among themselves. Keep in mind, too, that dynasties occasionally shuffled around Europe regardless of national origin; England’s King George I, for example, was a Hanoverian who spoke zero English.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Qualifications for President and the “Natural Born” Citizenship Eligibility Requirement (www.everycrsreport.com)
Content: In stating concerns regarding the citizenship of congressional officeholders, and the required length of such citizenship, George Mason argued that although he "was for opening a wide door for immigrants; ... [h]e did not chuse to let foreigners and adventurers make laws for us"; nor would he want "a rich foreign Nation, for example Great Britain, [to] send over her tools who might bribe their way" into federal office for "invidious purposes."
---

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why must presidents be native-born? (slate.com)
Content: here is scant primary source material attesting to the 1787 Constitutional debate over Article II, Section I, which contains the “natural born” provision. The potential scourge of foreign influence, however, is mentioned several times in the Federalist Papers. And in a letter dated July 25, 1787, John Jay, the future first Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, wrote to George Washington:


> Permit me to hint, whether it would not be wise & seasonable to provide a strong check to the admission of Foreigners into the administration of our national Government; and to declare expressly that the Command in chief of the American army shall not be given to, nor devolve on, any but a natural born Citizen.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 为什么总统必须是本地出生的？ （slate.com）
Content: 尽管他们的担忧现在似乎很古老，但框架确实害怕外国颠覆。在他们的噩梦场景中，有一个欧洲贵族利用他的金钱和影响力来摇摆选举学院，指挥美国陆军，并将新生的国家归还皇室成员。当时，几个欧洲人物，例如法国的革命战争英雄侯爵·德拉法耶特（Marquis de Lafayette），在新世界中很受欢迎，因此这个想法并没有完全牵强。


框架还从欧洲上了一堂课，王朝不断地相互陷入困境。起草宪法的人当然熟悉波兰的悲惨榜样，俄罗斯，普鲁士和奥地利的特工密谋安装了友好的君主斯坦尼斯劳斯二世，随后抓住了他的软弱，并彼此划分了国家。同样请记住，无论国籍如何例如，英格兰国王乔治一世（George I）是汉诺威人，英语零英语。

The potential scourge of foreign influence, however, is mentioned several times in the Federalist Papers. And in a letter dated July 25, 1787, John Jay, the future first Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, wrote to George Washington:


> Permit me to hint, whether it would not be wise & seasonable to provide a strong check to the admission of Foreigners into the administration of our national Government; and to declare expressly that the Command in chief of the American army shall not be given to, nor devolve on, any but a natural born Citizen.

Document ID: 2
Title: Why must presidents be native-born? (slate.com)
Content: Though their concerns may now seem archaic, the framers were genuinely afraid of foreign subversion. Among their nightmare scenarios was the prospect of a European noble using his money and influence to sway the Electoral College, take command of the American army, and return the nascent nation to the royalist fold. At the time, several European figures—such as France’s Marquis de Lafayette, a hero of the Revolutionary War—were quite popular in the New World, so the idea wasn’t completely far-fetched.


The framers also took a lesson from Europe, where dynasties constantly schemed against one another. The men who drafted the Constitution were certainly familiar with the tragic example of Poland, where agents from Russia, Prussia, and Austria conspired to install a friendly monarch, Stanislaus II, and subsequently seized upon his weakness and partitioned the country among themselves. Keep in mind, too, that dynasties occasionally shuffled around Europe regardless of national origin; England’s King George I, for example, was a Hanoverian who spoke zero English.

Title: Why does reading in a moving car cause motion sickness? (www.scientificamerican.com)
Content: Consider the situation when one is reading in the back seat of a car. Your eyes, fixed on the book with the peripheral vision seeing the interior of the car, say that you are still. But as the car goes over bumps, turns, or changes its velocity, your ears disagree. This is why motion sickness is common in this situation.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Motion Sickness: Symptoms & Treatment (my.clevelandclinic.org)
Content: What causes motion sickness?


Your brain receives signals from motion-sensing parts of your body: your eyes, inner ears, muscles and joints. When these parts send conflicting information, your brain doesn’t know whether you’re stationary or moving. Your brain’s confused reaction makes you feel sick.


For example, when riding in a car, your:


* Eyes see trees passing by and register movement.
* Inner ears sense movement.
* Muscles and joints sense that your body is sitting still.
* Brain senses a disconnect among these messages.

Title: How to Avoid Nausea when Reading in the Car (www.wikihow.com)
Content: Sometimes it’s really hard to put down a good book, even in the car. The problem is that when you are reading, your eyes are signaling to your brain that you are stationary. This conflicts with the signals from your inner ears, muscles, and joints which feel the vibrations of the car.[1] This results in carsickness which can involve nausea, vomiting, dizziness, sweating, salivation, shallow breathing, headaches, and sleepiness.

Content: 声音的音调完全取决于峰值在声波中的距离相距多远。当您发出声音的速度更快时，峰会越来越近，音高就会上升。当您播放声音较慢时，它们会越远，而且音高下降了。无论您是以数字方式进行的，还是使用乙烯基，都是这样。
