Document ID: 2
Title: Audio time stretching and pitch scaling - Wikipedia (en.wikipedia.org)
Content: The simplest way to change the duration or pitch of an audio recording is to change the playback speed. For a digital audio recording, this can be accomplished through sample rate conversion. Unfortunately, the frequencies in the recording are always scaled at the same ratio as the speed, transposing its perceived pitch up or down in the process. Slowing down the recording to increase duration also lowers the pitch, speeding it up for a shorter duration also raises the pitch creating the Chipmunk effect. Thus the two effects cannot be separated when using this method. A drum track containing no pitched instruments can be moderately sample-rate converted to adjust tempo without adverse effects, but a pitched track cannot.

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Does Changing The Speed Of Digital Audio Change The Pitch? | Naked Science Forum (www.thenakedscientists.com)
Content: The pitch of a sound is entirely determined by how far apart in time the peaks are in the soundwave. When you play a sound faster, the peaks become closer together and the pitch goes up. When you play a sound slower, they're further apart, and the pitch goes down. And that's true whether you do it digitally or with analogue tapes or with vinyl.

Title: 音频时间拉伸和音高缩放-Wikipedia（en.wikipedia.org）
Content: 更改音频录制持续时间或音高的最简单方法是改变播放速度。对于数字音频录制，可以通过样本率转换来实现。不幸的是，记录中的频率总是以与速度相同的比率缩放，在此过程中向上或向下转移其感知的音高。减慢记录以增加持续时间，还可以降低音高，使其持续时间较短，也提高了音高，从而产生了花栗鼠效应。因此，使用此方法时，这两个效果无法分离。一个包含没有倾斜仪器的鼓轨可以将样品速率适度转换为调整速度而不会产生不利影响，但是俯仰轨道不能。

claim: 运动后体温和心率都升高，口腔及皮肤的热感让人倍感疲惫；此时摄入冰冷的水可以快速把部分热量带走，显著降低或抑制核心体温的进一步上升，从而减轻因过热造成的倦怠感，所以主观上更“提神”
question_src: 当您刚锻炼或从宿醉中醒来时，为什么冰冷的水比冷淡的水更令人耳目一新？
all_claims: 运动后体温和心率都升高，口腔及皮肤的热感让人倍感疲惫；此时摄入冰冷的水可以快速把部分热量带走，显著降低或抑制核心体温的进一步上升，从而减轻因过热造成的倦怠感，所以主观上更“提神”[3]。
研究还发现，锻炼结束后冷水对降低体温尤为有效，可让人更快恢复舒适状态[1]。
冷水还能帮助调节并冷却体温，是炎热环境或剧烈运动后最直接、最迅速的降温方式[4]。
而在宿醉或清晨头痛时，身体往往因脱水而水分不足；空腹喝冰冷的水既能补充流失的水分，又能通过低温刺激收缩扩张的血管，缓解疼痛并带来醒脑清新的感觉，因此比温水更“醒神”[2]。
综合来看，冰冷水凭借快速降温与迅速补水两大生理效应，使人在运动后或宿醉时获得比冷淡水更强烈的清凉、振奋体验。

Title: Should You Not Drink Ice Cold Water After Exercise? | Livestrong.com (www.livestrong.com)
Content: What about water temperature? In a May 2018 analysis published by the Gatorade Sports Science Institute, the researchers affirmed that drinking cold drinks before exercise, as opposed to during exercise, is more effective at lowering body temperature.


That might help you work out for longer without overheating, especially in hot or humid conditions. But the effect is limited. Drinking too many cold fluids will cause your body to reflexively shiver, which warms you back up again.


The same authors also note that drinking cold water during exercise may help lower your core temperature and reduce fluid lost through sweating. They speculate that drinking cold water after you work out may be particularly effective for helping to lower body temperature. What little clinical research there is on this topic seems to bear that conclusion out, but further study is needed.

Content: Why do reheated potatoes taste bad?

Noticeable taste difference. A lot of what makes things taste weird when they’re re-heated is that they’re more dehydrated. Adding a bit of water or other moisture and sealing (for the oven) or slightly ventilating (for the microwave) helps in my experience.

Document ID: 2
Title: 如何将剩余的炸薯条重新加热到完美（www.chatelaine.com）
Content: 当薯条在非常高的温度下煮熟时，其中的淀粉会得到水合（水分进口），膨化它们，并帮助外部皮肤变得良好和酥脆。当这些相同的薯条凉爽时，淀粉分泌水分，将水分变成炸薯条的外壳，使它们湿透和li行。

Document ID: 3
Title: The Science of Leftovers: Why Don't They Taste As Good? (gizmodo.com)
Content: But the chemicals work some delicious magic, too. The flavor called umami, which you may know if you've watched enough Top Chef, is used to describe a food's savory flavor. And sometimes when food ages, this umami flavor will appear. It happens because, over time, proteins in food break down into amino acid chunks, and those chunks taste good. "We're hardwired to associate their presence with healthfulness," says Loss.

Document ID: 4
Title: Is it safe to reheat leftover rice? (www.veg-world.com)
Content: Raw rice contains traces of a bacterium known as Bacillus cereus. Unfortunately, this bacterium survives cooking, especially if the rice is cooked at or below 212°F (100°C) - as is the case if the rice is boiled in water. If the rice is then slowly cooled and stored at room temperature, the bacterium germinates, and might produce enterotoxins which in turn cause food poisoning. These remain in the rice, even after it's been reheated.

claim: 许多哺乳动物（如母犬）在产后头三个星期会舔幼崽肛门并吞食粪便，以刺激排泄并保持巢穴清洁 [1]；幼犬、幼猫随后也会少量吞粪，从而快速获得建立肠道正常菌群所需的微生物
question_src: 为什么大多数哺乳动物在修饰时可以安全地舔自己的粪便，但是人类必须避免任何污染或可怕的病态呢？
all_claims: 许多哺乳动物（如母犬）在产后头三个星期会舔幼崽肛门并吞食粪便，以刺激排泄并保持巢穴清洁 [1]；幼犬、幼猫随后也会少量吞粪，从而快速获得建立肠道正常菌群所需的微生物 [2]。
这类行为发生在生命早期、持续时间短且通常局限于自体或同窝个体，其粪便来源相对“干净”，因此对动物本身多为无害 [4]。
然而，一旦粪便来自外部环境，就可能携带寄生虫、病毒或毒素并导致疾病 [4]。
在人类粪便中常检测到隐孢子虫、贾第虫及甲型肝炎病毒，摄入后可引起腹泻、脱水甚至肝炎，需药物治疗 [5]。
人类已通过母乳、发酵食品等途径获得稳定菌群，不再需要粪口补菌；加之高度社会化、粪便密集累积，病原体浓度远超野外哺乳动物的“自家粪”，因此“舔便”对人类几乎只有感染风险而无生理收益，必须严格避免。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Do Dogs Eat Their Own Poop? (www.msn.com)
Content: “Mothers of young animals lick the rear ends of their young to stimulate defecation and to keep their young clean. This can lead to inadvertent ingestion of feces,” Dr. Dundas explained. “In young dogs and cats, this behavior of licking the rear end and ingesting fecal material can then become a learned behavior from their mothers.”
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 狗为什么要吃自己的便便？ （www.msn.com）
Content: Dundas博士说：“幼犬和小猫在胃肠道中并不生细菌。吃粪便可能有助于人体在胃肠道中建立正常或健康的细菌平衡。”
---
Document ID: 3
Title: What does it mean when cats eat their poop? – joewongcomedy.com (www.joewongcomedy.com)
Content: Coprophagia is the eating and ingesting of feces. Also, their butts are fairly clean anyway, because of the way they expel feces, there isn’t normally any dirt remaining a the exit hole. Cats lick their own – and their buddies’ – butts.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Why Dogs Eat Poop and How to Stop It – American Kennel Club (www.akc.org)
Content: For some species, such as rabbits, eating fecal droppings is a totally normal way of obtaining key nutrients. In fact, if you prevent rabbits from doing this, they will develop health problems, and young ones will fail to thrive. Fortunately, dogs do not need to get nutrition this way. It is, however, a normal, natural behavior at some canine life stages. Mother dogs will lick their puppies to urge them to eliminate, and clean up their feces by eating it, for about the first three weeks after birth. Puppies will also naturally engage in this behavior, eating both their own poop (autocoprophagia), poop from other dogs (allocoprophagia), as well as poop from cats and other animals. Some dogs find horse manure and goose droppings particularly appealing. Eating their own poop is harmless, but consuming poop from other animals may cause health problems if the stool is contaminated with parasites, viruses, or toxins. In most cases, this behavior will fade before the puppy is about nine months old.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: What happens if you eat poop? Effects, in children, and more (www.medicalnewstoday.com)
Content: A person who ingests human or animal feces may be at risk of contracting a number of viruses, bacteria, or parasites.


Parasites are tiny organisms that can live in the intestines of humans and animals. If a person ingests feces from someone who has a parasite, they themselves can contract the infection. Parasites such as Cryptosporidium and Giardia can cause symptoms including diarrhea and dehydration.


A doctor may prescribe medication to get rid of parasites.


Hepatitis A is a liver disease that can transmit to a person if they ingest contaminated feces.
---

Content: 对于某些物种，例如兔子，吃粪便是获得关键营养素的完全正常的方法。实际上，如果您防止兔子这样做，它们将会出现健康问题，而年轻人将不会繁衍生息。幸运的是，狗不需要这种营养。但是，在某些犬类生活阶段，这是一种正常的自然行为。母狗会舔幼犬，敦促它们消除，并在出生后的头三个星期内通过食用粪便清理粪便。幼犬还会自然地参与这种行为，同时吃自己的粪便（Autocopophagia），其他狗的大便（Allocoprophagia）以及猫和其他动物的粪便。一些狗发现马粪和鹅粪便特别有吸引力。食用自己的大便是无害的，但是如果粪便被寄生虫，病毒或毒素污染，食用其他动物的粪便可能会导致健康问题。在大多数情况下，这种行为将在小狗大约九个月大之前消失。

Title: What happens if you eat poop? Effects, in children, and more (www.medicalnewstoday.com)
Content: A person who ingests human or animal feces may be at risk of contracting a number of viruses, bacteria, or parasites.


Parasites are tiny organisms that can live in the intestines of humans and animals. If a person ingests feces from someone who has a parasite, they themselves can contract the infection. Parasites such as Cryptosporidium and Giardia can cause symptoms including diarrhea and dehydration.


A doctor may prescribe medication to get rid of parasites.


Hepatitis A is a liver disease that can transmit to a person if they ingest contaminated feces.
---

Title: Which OTC Pain Reliever Is the Right Choice for You? (www.webmd.com)
Content: ## Acetaminophen


This type of medication works on the parts of your brain that receive pain messages and control your body temperature. It can ease pain and lower a fever, but it won’t reduce any swelling and inflammation.


It may be a good choice to treat a headache, arthritis pain, or a fever.


Bonus:Acetaminophen is less likely to cause stomach issues than other OTC pain-relievers.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Which OTC Pain Reliever Is the Right Choice for You? (www.webmd.com)
Content: ## Ibuprofen


This medication is a type of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that reduces fevers, pain, and inflammation. NSAIDs work by lowering the amount of hormone-like substances called prostaglandins. Those cause the feeling of pain by irritating your nerve endings. So if you have less, you'll feel better.


Ibuprofen may be a good choice for treating menstrual cramps, headaches, toothaches, backaches, arthritis, muscle strains, and gout.

question_src: 为什么只有圆形行星？为什么不能有正方形或矩形？
all_claims: 行星几乎都是圆形，因为当它们在早期被撞击加热到熔融状态时，自身引力会从核心向各方向均匀拉拽，将流体物质塑成能让整体质量最接近重心的球体，这一过程称为“等静止调整”[1]。
若要维持棱角，岩石需足够坚固以抵抗重力，但质量越大，引力越强，尖角便会被拉平；因此只有重力不足的小行星才保持不规则形状，而行星终会趋于球形[4]。
此外，自转产生的离心力会把赤道稍微拉胖，自转越快，凸起越明显，所以行星是“块状球体”而非完美球体[2]。
要形成正方形或矩形星球，物质必须在全球尺度上同时抵御引力和离心力，这在自然条件下几乎不可能发生，因此宇宙中只见圆形行星，而不会出现方块或长方体行星。

Title: 为什么所有行星球体球？ （www.wonderopolis.org）
Content: 所有行星的球形形状都可以用我们都熟悉的一种力来解释：重力。当我们的太阳系中的行星开始形成时，空间充满了数十亿美元的灰尘和天然气。


当这些碎片互相碰到时，它们开始形成逐渐越来越大的团块。最终，这些材料团长大了，足以发展自己的引力场。


随着形成行星的持续增长，与其他物质相撞的力量使它们变得热和熔融，其作用就像液体一样。每个星球的重力都以其核心为中心。它从芯子上平均地向各个方向拉动，从而将所有熔融材料拉到球形形状上。科学家称这一过程为“等静止调整”。

Title: Why Are Planets Almost Spherical? (science.howstuffworks.com)
Content: "But gravity is not the whole story," says Carpenter. While gravity conspires to render the planets spherical, the speed of their rotations is simultaneously trying to flatten them. The faster a celestial body spins, the more disproportionate its equatorial bulge gets. "This is why there are no perfect spheres in our solar system ... only oblate spheroids," Carpenter tells us. "The sun is almost a perfect sphere, due to its immense gravity and relatively slow rotation rate of 25 days. A significant percentage of stars in the sky rotate much faster and bulge noticeably at their equators."

Document ID: 4
Title: Why are planets round? (www.scientificamerican.com)
Content: Derek Sears, professor of cosmochemistry at the University of Arkansas, explains.


Planets are round because their gravitational field acts as though it originates from the center of the body and pulls everything toward it. With its large body and internal heating from radioactive elements, a planet behaves like a fluid, and over long periods of time succumbs to the gravitational pull from its center of gravity. The only way to get all the mass as close to planet's center of gravity as possible is to form a sphere. The technical name for this process is "isostatic adjustment."


With much smaller bodies, such as the 20-kilometer asteroids we have seen in recent spacecraft images, the gravitational pull is too weak to overcome the asteroid's mechanical strength. As a result, these bodies do not form spheres. Rather they maintain irregular, fragmentary shapes.

Title: Why Are All Planets Spheres? (www.wonderopolis.org)
Content: The spherical shape of all the planets can be explained by one force that we're all familiar with: gravity. When the planets in our solar system began to form, space was filled with billions and billions of pieces of dust and gas.


As these pieces bumped into each other, they began to form clumps that slowly grew larger and larger. Eventually these clumps of material grew large enough to develop their own gravitational fields.


As the forming planets continued to grow, the force of the collisions with additional matter caused them to become hot and molten, acting much like a liquid. Each planet's gravitational force is centered at its core. It pulls equally in every direction from the core, thus pulling all the molten material into a spherical shape. Scientists call this process "isostatic adjustment."

Title: 为什么行星是圆形的？ （www.scientificamerican.com）
Content: 阿肯色大学的宇宙化学教授德里克·西尔斯（Derek Sears）解释说。


行星之所以圆，是因为它们的引力场的作用似乎源于身体的中心，并将所有东西拉向它。行星的大量身体和内部加热，就像流体一样，长期以来，从重力中心屈服于重力。使所有质量尽可能接近星球的重心的唯一方法是形成一个球体。此过程的技术名称是“等静止调整”。


由于我们在最近的航天器图像中看到的较小的身体，例如20公里的小行星，重力拉力太弱，无法克服小行星的机械强度。结果，这些身体不形成球体。相反，它们保持不规则的碎片形状。

all_claims: 行星几乎都是圆形，因为当它们在早期被撞击加热到熔融状态时，自身引力会从核心向各方向均匀拉拽，将流体物质塑成能让整体质量最接近重心的球体，这一过程称为“等静止调整”[1]。
若要维持棱角，岩石需足够坚固以抵抗重力，但质量越大，引力越强，尖角便会被拉平；因此只有重力不足的小行星才保持不规则形状，而行星终会趋于球形[4]。
此外，自转产生的离心力会把赤道稍微拉胖，自转越快，凸起越明显，所以行星是“块状球体”而非完美球体[2]。
要形成正方形或矩形星球，物质必须在全球尺度上同时抵御引力和离心力，这在自然条件下几乎不可能发生，因此宇宙中只见圆形行星，而不会出现方块或长方体行星。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Are All Planets Spheres? (www.wonderopolis.org)
Content: The spherical shape of all the planets can be explained by one force that we're all familiar with: gravity. When the planets in our solar system began to form, space was filled with billions and billions of pieces of dust and gas.


As these pieces bumped into each other, they began to form clumps that slowly grew larger and larger. Eventually these clumps of material grew large enough to develop their own gravitational fields.


As the forming planets continued to grow, the force of the collisions with additional matter caused them to become hot and molten, acting much like a liquid. Each planet's gravitational force is centered at its core. It pulls equally in every direction from the core, thus pulling all the molten material into a spherical shape. Scientists call this process "isostatic adjustment."
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 为什么行星几乎是球形的？ （science.howstuffworks.com）
Content: 卡彭特说：“但是重力不是整个故事。”尽管重力阴谋使行星球形渲染，但它们的旋转速度正同时试图使它们变平。天体旋转的速度越快，其赤道凸起越多。卡彭特告诉我们：“这就是为什么我们的太阳系中没有完美的球体……只有块状球体。” “由于其巨大的重力和相对较慢的旋转速度为25天，太阳几乎是一个完美的球体。天空中的恒星很大一部分旋转得更快，并且在其赤道上明显凸出。”

Document ID: 3
Title: Why are planets always shown as spheres? Why can't they be cubes or prisms? | Notes and Queries (www.theguardian.com)
Content: * Planets aren't perfect spheres - because they are spinning they get pulled out slightly around their equator making them a bit "fatter" so they are in fact oval.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Why are planets round? (www.scientificamerican.com)
Content: Derek Sears, professor of cosmochemistry at the University of Arkansas, explains.


Planets are round because their gravitational field acts as though it originates from the center of the body and pulls everything toward it. With its large body and internal heating from radioactive elements, a planet behaves like a fluid, and over long periods of time succumbs to the gravitational pull from its center of gravity. The only way to get all the mass as close to planet's center of gravity as possible is to form a sphere. The technical name for this process is "isostatic adjustment."


With much smaller bodies, such as the 20-kilometer asteroids we have seen in recent spacecraft images, the gravitational pull is too weak to overcome the asteroid's mechanical strength. As a result, these bodies do not form spheres. Rather they maintain irregular, fragmentary shapes.

question_src: 为什么我们有有限的牙齿？
all_claims: 人类一生只有乳牙和恒牙两套，共32颗恒牙，这是进化上的权衡结果[3]。

同时，哺乳动物为适应草食、肉食等精细多样的饮食，演化出切齿、犬齿、前磨牙、磨牙等不同形态的牙齿，上下颌每颗牙的位置与形状都必须精确对应才能高效咀嚼[2]。
若像壁虎那样频繁换牙，新生牙齿极易错位，降低吃草或撕肉的效率，生存代价更高[2]。
因此，大多数哺乳动物放弃无限换牙，改为先长一套乳牙塑造颌骨、学习发声，再长一套排列精确的恒牙陪伴终生，这就是我们牙齿数量有限的原因。

Title: 估计有90％的美国成年人有填充物 - 这就是为什么我们不能只能再生牙齿的原因（www.businessinsider.com）
Content: 与50,000种爬行动物和鱼类相比，只有少数哺乳动物可以多次再生牙齿。以壁虎为例，谁将每3至4个月替换所有100颗牙齿。而且，由于壁虎可以活6至10年，因此它们一生中将从1,800到4,000颗牙齿长大！这全都归功于其牙龈中的一种特殊类型的细胞，称为干细胞。


干细胞很方便，因为它们可以在需要时变成不同的细胞。像牙齿干细胞来构建新的牙齿。当我们小时候，人类患有这些干细胞。但是，在我们的成年牙齿生长后，干细胞死亡并消失。

Title: An estimated 90% of adults in the US have fillings — here's why we can't just regrow our teeth (www.businessinsider.com)
Content: Mammals, on the other hand, developed more specific diets. Like grazers who only eat grass and hunters who rip flesh from their kills. As a result, mammals evolved different shaped teeth for different purposes. And it's this difference, that could also explain why most mammals can't regrow more teeth.


Now, let's say you could regrow your molars multiple times, for example. It's important that the top and bottoms sets match up. Otherwise, they can't grind up food as efficiently. It sounds good in principle, but with each new set, there's a risk that the regrown teeth won't line up. So the leading theory is that adult humans can't regrow our teeth because it was better for survival to only grow one, well-aligned adult set.

Most children will start with 20 primary baby teeth, 10 on the top and 10 on the bottom. These teeth are eventually replaced with 32 permanent adult teeth, 16 on each upper and lower jaw, as we grow older and our jaws start to develop.

Title: An estimated 90% of adults in the US have fillings — here's why we can't just regrow our teeth (www.businessinsider.com)
Content: Only a handful of mammals can regrow teeth multiple times, compared to the 50,000 species of reptiles and fish. Take geckos, for example, who will replace all 100 teeth, or so, every 3 to 4 months. And since geckos can live for 6 to 10 years, they'll grow anywhere from 1,800 to 4,000 teeth in a lifetime! It's all thanks to a special type of cell in their gums, called stem cells.


Stem cells are handy because they can morph into different cells when needed. Like tooth stem cells to build new teeth. Humans have these stem cells when we're younger. But after our adult teeth grow in, the stem cells die and disappear.

question_src: 人类的“自然”睡眠位置是什么？
all_claims: 多项观察显示，人类最“自然”的睡眠姿势是侧卧，尤其是双腿微屈、手臂置于身体前方的胎儿式侧卧[6]。
追踪数据显示，人们在床上约 55% 的时间采用侧卧，这一比例随年龄上升而增加，远高于仰卧或俯卧，说明侧卧是放松状态下最自动的选择[6]。
胎儿式侧卧备受青睐的原因在于其舒适且生理优势明显，可缓解下背痛、为孕妇提供支持并减少打鼾[1]，左侧卧还能改善消化并减轻胃灼热[3]。
相比之下，俯卧会增加颈背压力[4]，仰卧则可能加重打鼾和睡眠呼吸暂停[7]。
因此，从人群习惯与健康效果的双重角度看，侧卧（特别是胎儿式侧卧）最符合人类的“自然”睡眠位置。
claims_retained: 追踪数据显示，人们在床上约 55% 的时间采用侧卧，这一比例随年龄上升而增加，远高于仰卧或俯卧，说明侧卧是放松状态下最自动的选择[6]。

question_src: 为什么自动变速箱流体如此独特？ ATF的粘度会改变它的移动越多吗？
all_claims: 自动变速箱流体（ATF）必须同时承担润滑、液压驱动与散热任务，因此采用合成基础油和多功能添加剂，以保证在高温高压、高剪切的环境下仍难氧化或分解[3]；这类综合性能需求远非手动变速箱油所能满足[2]。
为降低泵送阻力和燃油消耗，ATF被调成较低粘度，但仍需在极薄油膜下为齿轮和轴承提供足够保护[6]。
正常行驶中粘度会随温度升高而下降，这是物理规律且在设计范围内，不会因为“移动得多”而突然失效；然而随着金属磨屑与氧化物逐渐累积，流体一致性被破坏，粘度可能变稀或变稠，液压效率及润滑能力同步下降[4]，所以制造商要求按规定里程或时间定期更换ATF[5]。

Content: Within each gearbox are many moving parts that are engineered to work together under stress. question_src: 广告如何从手机到计算机关注我？
all_claims: 当你在手机或电脑上访问购物或服务网站时，页面中的广告网络会在浏览器放置 cookie，记录“这台设备正在查看 X 产品”的信息；当你稍后在另一台设备打开同一广告网络合作的网站，它读取或匹配这些 cookie，于是向你展示 X 广告[1]。
与此同时，你常在手机、台式机和平板上使用同一 Google 或 Facebook 账户，这些平台把登录信息当成“同一用户”的凭证，将多台设备归在同一身份下[2]。
完成匹配后，它们再结合浏览器历史或电话联系人等数据，生成更完整的兴趣画像，并在所有已识别设备上同步投放相关广告[3]。
因此， cookie 让广告商在单一设备内追踪，而账号登录则把多台设备的行为合并，实现广告“从手机追到电脑”的跨屏跟随[2]。

Title: Why Do Ads Follow Me Around the Internet? (askleo.com)
Content: It works like this:


1. You visit a shopping site, or a site that offers some kind of service. This site may or may not show ads, but they do include content from an advertising network.
2. The advertising network places a cookie on your computer. That cookie contains information to the effect of, “This computer was looking at X,” where X is the product or service offered by the site you’re visiting.
3. Eventually, you move on to another website — a site that also displays ads, and coincidentally uses the same advertising network as the site we started at.
4. That advertising network is given its own cookie back — the one that says, “This computer was looking at X” — and as a result, elects to show you ads for X.

question_src: 为什么这些天有这么多人选择长板上的长板？他们更容易骑吗？有什么好处？
all_claims: 这几年许多人改选长板，原因在于它天生的稳定与舒适：长板比滑板更长更宽，给双脚留出更大站位并提升直线稳定性[3]；大型柔软轮毂可以在高速顺利碾过裂缝与小碎石，带来更平滑的骑行感受[1]；某些长板长度可达59英寸，相比典型36英寸的滑板进一步增强巡航安全感[2]；同时，宽体卡车结构减少高速摆动，让新手也能轻松保持平衡[1]。
这些特点使学习门槛大幅降低，用户只需少量练习即可用于城市通勤、校园代步或休闲下坡，而不必像滑板那样掌握Ollie、翻板等技巧；相对而言，柔软轮在做技巧时易反弹并不利于翻转[1]。
因此，长板凭借“易上手、舒适、省力”的综合优势，成为当下大众与初学者的热门选择。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Longboard vs滑板 - 优点，缺点和差异 -  Boardcoast（www.boardcoast.com）
Content: 长板通常比滑板更长且更宽。它们也有不同类型的车轮。长板有较大的柔软轮毂，而滑板则具有小的硬车轮。长板也更加灵活，并且往往更容易为初学者骑行。

长板上的柔软的车轮非常适合骑行，在高速上滚动裂缝和小碎片，但它们比硬轮弹跳。通常，在执行技巧时，您不想使用软轮，因为在车轮撞到人行道后，板可能会弹回。它使降落技巧和保持稳定更加困难。

滑板和长板的卡车也不同。滑板有小型卡车，可以留在板下方，但长板的卡车具有不同的设计。宽的卡车提供了更高的稳定性，在高速上需要。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Longboards Vs. Skateboards (www.redbull.com)
Content: If you put a longboard and skateboard side by side, you'll notice how flat the nose and tail of the longboard are. On a skateboard, you'll see more of a curve on its nose and tail to make it easier to land tricks and flips.

It should be no surprise that longboards are, of course, longer. They can be as long as 59 inches, while the typical skateboard is around 36 inches. Here's where it gets confusing: longboards also come in sizes as small as 28 inches long. If the length trips you up, just remember the key difference between the two is that longboards are flat and skateboards curve. So, if you see a flat, shorter board, it's probably just a short longboard.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Longboard vs Skateboard – Similarities and Differences | SkateboardersHQ (www.skateboardershq.com)
Content: Longboards are wider and longer than skateboards, are more flexible and easier to ride for beginners. Longboards have large soft wheels and skateboard have small hard wheels.

Big soft wheels are great for riding but are more bouncy compared to hard wheels. This means if you do an ollie (jump) for example, the board is more likely to bounce back up. This makes landing a trick unstable and more chances of landing primo (both feet on the side of the deck).

Skateboards have smaller trucks, longboards have wider trucks and have a different design. Wider trucks provide more stability which you need at higher speeds. Smaller trucks make a board more agile which is needed for ollies and flips.

claim: 鹦鹉之所以能“说话”，根源在于它们是少数具备“声乐学习”能力的鸟——先倾听再精确模仿声音
question_src: 为什么鹦鹉可以说话？他们只能重复人们所说的话，还是可以表达自己的想法并有时会发声？
all_claims: 鹦鹉之所以能“说话”，根源在于它们是少数具备“声乐学习”能力的鸟——先倾听再精确模仿声音[1]。
生理上，它们的syrinx位于气管分叉处，可细致调整通过气流，发出多样而清晰的音节，甚至接近人类语音[3]。
在野外，鹦鹉本就用叫声示警、求偶、喂雏或捍卫领地，因此具备丰富的自主发声需求[4]。
当与人类同住时，它们把这种模仿天赋用在我们常说的词汇上，有时能为词语建立简单关联，但语义层面通常不深[2]。
然而“亚历克斯”实验显示，训练充分的鹦鹉可理解颜色、数量等概念并用词语准确回答，从而证明它们并非只为讨零食而随意复读[6]。
claims_retained: 鹦鹉之所以能“说话”，根源在于它们是少数具备“声乐学习”能力的鸟——先倾听再精确模仿声音[1]。

在野外，鹦鹉本就用叫声示警、求偶、喂雏或捍卫领地，因此具备丰富的自主发声需求[4]。
当与人类同住时，它们把这种模仿天赋用在我们常说的词汇上，有时能为词语建立简单关联，但语义层面通常不深[2]。

question_src: 为什么鹦鹉可以说话？他们只能重复人们所说的话，还是可以表达自己的想法并有时会发声？
all_claims: 鹦鹉之所以能“说话”，根源在于它们是少数具备“声乐学习”能力的鸟——先倾听再精确模仿声音[1]。
生理上，它们的syrinx位于气管分叉处，可细致调整通过气流，发出多样而清晰的音节，甚至接近人类语音[3]。
在野外，鹦鹉本就用叫声示警、求偶、喂雏或捍卫领地，因此具备丰富的自主发声需求[4]。
当与人类同住时，它们把这种模仿天赋用在我们常说的词汇上，有时能为词语建立简单关联，但语义层面通常不深[2]。
然而“亚历克斯”实验显示，训练充分的鹦鹉可理解颜色、数量等概念并用词语准确回答，从而证明它们并非只为讨零食而随意复读[6]。

question_src: 为什么女性通常在美国打垒球而不是棒球？
all_claims: 二战后曾短暂兴盛的女子职业棒球在1950年代被整体撤销，美国社会“把妇女送回家”，棒球的大门随之关闭[1]；1972年小联盟甚至因12岁女孩玛丽亚·佩佩参赛而威胁吊销球队资格，面对诉讼压力干脆另设“小联盟垒球”，进一步将女孩排除在棒球之外[1]。
同年出台的Title IX要求学校为男女提供“同等”运动，立法者把垒球视为与棒球等价，只要设有女子垒球队，学校即可合法拒绝女孩加入棒球队[2]。
在高中和大学层面，垒球被官方确认为女性项目，女孩若坚持打棒球不仅缺乏奖学金机会，还要面对巨大的转项和社交压力[3]。
历史排斥、法律替代及教育体系激励共同导致美国女性通常被引导去打垒球而非棒球。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 美国女性为什么不能打棒球？ （www.thedailybeast.com）
Content: 但是，就像第二次世界大战期间美国妇女的许多进步一样，后来棒球不再是专业选择。 “在1950年代，我们将妇女从所有事物中脱颖而出，”林说。 “我们为美国历史上的妇女提供了这个不幸的十年。这是妇女被送回家中的十年。”


随着妇女解放运动和第IX冠军，体育在1970年代为妇女重新出现，但棒球没有。林说：“棒球从未转过角，向女性打开大门。”


确实，有证据表明，有一致的努力使女孩脱离棒球。 1972年，国家小联盟组织威胁要撤销新泽西州霍博肯市一支团队的宪章，因为他们允许12岁的玛丽亚·佩佩（Maria Pepe）参加比赛。国家妇女组织采取了此案，并成功起诉允许Pepe和其他女孩能够尝试。为了应对压力，小联盟创造了小联盟垒球。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Why not let girls play baseball instead of softball? (www.carolinacoastonline.com)
Content: When Title IX, the 1972 law that required equal funding to both male and female sports teams, finally appeared, women were given fair ground on nearly every sport.


Baseball was not on that list, though. Instead, the law dictated that the school must provide an equivalent sport, and in that case, it was softball. Thus, schools were within their right to deny girls who were interested in baseball as long as a softball team was provided.


Since then, women all over the country, and now the world, have fought for the chance to play on their school’s baseball team. Some have succeeded, and most have failed, but none have made a serious impact.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Will Women Play Major League Baseball? (And Not Just on TV) (www.nytimes.com)
Content: Women’s baseball is not a high school sport in the United States, although it is in other nations, like Canada and Japan. In this country, girls are directed to softball, which is a women’s sport at the high school and collegiate level, Dr. Ring says.


“If a girl here wants to play baseball, she almost has to play with the boys and the pressure to switch from baseball to softball can be overwhelming,” she says. “People will tell her, you’re missing out on college scholarships” and may also suggest that she is hurting both her body and possibly male opponents’ egos if she sticks with hardball.


Playing elite baseball also can be profoundly lonely for a woman, says Ms. Hudek, the Bossier Parish college player and one of the most successful young female pitchers of recent years.
---

claim: “流沙”其实是一层被地下水充分饱和的细粒沉积物；当人踏上去时，脚步施加的压力使上层看似坚实的沙子与下层水迅速混合，土体瞬间液化，变成稠厚泥浆，失去支撑力，于是人开始下沉
question_src: 为什么“快速沙子”会让您下沉，沙子去了哪里？
all_claims: “流沙”其实是一层被地下水充分饱和的细粒沉积物；当人踏上去时，脚步施加的压力使上层看似坚实的沙子与下层水迅速混合，土体瞬间液化，变成稠厚泥浆，失去支撑力，于是人开始下沉[1]。
这种泥浆的平均密度约为2 g/ml，而人体约为1 g/ml，因此人在不挣扎的情况下会一直下沉，直到自身排开的泥浆重量与体重相等，一般约到腰或胸部位置[2]。
下沉过程中，液化的沙粒被人体向下与向外排挤——沙子被迫侧移或上涌，而水则填充原本颗粒间的空隙，所以看起来“沙子不见了”[3]。
当人停止动作后，混合物中的水逐渐渗出，沙粒重新堆积成半固态床，将人紧紧固定，使逃脱变得困难[3]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Quickss并真的会杀死您吗？ （thescienceexplorer.com）
Content: 实际上，研究发现，不可能完全淹没在速度中，因为人类比Quicksand的密度较少，并且一个人在开始漂浮之前只会沉入胸口。


但是，可以使快速和致命的方法陷入困境并抓住毫无戒心的受害者的能力。


当粘土，沙子，淤泥或其他颗粒状土壤等细小的沉积物（通常是从地下来源）饱和时，就会发生速度。通常，这些陷阱在天然水源的外围或边缘附近发现。通常，顶部的沙子可能看起来很固体，但是随着脚步的添加压力，沙子会与其下面的水混合在一起，形成厚厚的污泥。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Quicksand. The science behind the properties of Quicksand. (www.zigya.com)
Content: Objects in the quicksand sink to the level at which the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the displaced soil/water mix and the submerged obje ct floats due to its buoyancy. The density of quicksand is 2 g/ml which is about twice that of a human body (1 g/ml), Thus, a human should sink only half way in (till the waist line), in case he/she does not struggle. Even objects with a higher density than quicksand will float on it—until they move.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Quicksand. The science behind the properties of Quicksand. (www.zigya.com)
Content: The sand particles get displaced and the animal/human sinks in it. Objects in liquefied sand sink to the level at which the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the displaced soil/water mix. Since Quicksand has a density twice than that of human, thus a person is usually trapped to their waist.


As the weight of the organism becomes equal to that of the displaced quicksand, the liquefaction process stops and the sand eventually forms a semi-solid bed again. The denser sand grains hold the animal tight, preventing it from escaping.

question_src: 为什么“快速沙子”会让您下沉，沙子去了哪里？
all_claims: “流沙”其实是一层被地下水充分饱和的细粒沉积物；当人踏上去时，脚步施加的压力使上层看似坚实的沙子与下层水迅速混合，土体瞬间液化，变成稠厚泥浆，失去支撑力，于是人开始下沉[1]。
这种泥浆的平均密度约为2 g/ml，而人体约为1 g/ml，因此人在不挣扎的情况下会一直下沉，直到自身排开的泥浆重量与体重相等，一般约到腰或胸部位置[2]。
下沉过程中，液化的沙粒被人体向下与向外排挤——沙子被迫侧移或上涌，而水则填充原本颗粒间的空隙，所以看起来“沙子不见了”[3]。
当人停止动作后，混合物中的水逐渐渗出，沙粒重新堆积成半固态床，将人紧紧固定，使逃脱变得困难[3]。

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Will Quicksand Really Kill You? (thescienceexplorer.com)
Content: In fact, studies have found it is impossible to be completely submerged in quicksand because humans are less dense than quicksand and a person would only sink to their chest before they begin to float.


But what can make quicksand deadly is its ability to trap and hold unsuspecting victims.


Quicksand occurs when fine sediment such as clay, sand, silt, or other grainy soil becomes saturated with water, typically from a subterranean source. Often these traps are found near the periphery or edge of natural water sources. Often the sand on top may appear solid, but with the added pressure of a footstep, the sand will mix with the water beneath it forming a thick sludge.
---

Title: 流沙。 Quicksand属性背后的科学。 （www.zigya.com）
Content: 速度中的物体将物体重量等于流离失所的土壤/水混合物的重量以及由于其浮力而淹没的OBJE CT浮子的水平。速度的密度为2 g/ml，大约是人体的两倍（1 g/ml），因此，如果他/她不挣扎，人类应该只沉入一半（直到腰线）。即使是比速度较高的物体，也会漂浮在其上 - 直到它们移动。
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Quicksand. The science behind the properties of Quicksand. (www.zigya.com)
Content: The sand particles get displaced and the animal/human sinks in it. Objects in liquefied sand sink to the level at which the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the displaced soil/water mix. Since Quicksand has a density twice than that of human, thus a person is usually trapped to their waist.


As the weight of the organism becomes equal to that of the displaced quicksand, the liquefaction process stops and the sand eventually forms a semi-solid bed again. The denser sand grains hold the animal tight, preventing it from escaping.

question_src: 他们是如何弄清楚菲利亚彗星降落的？
all_claims: Rosetta团队为了让菲利亚成功降落，首先要确定母船在彗星周围的理想位置与光照条件，他们利用探测器上多台相机获取的高分辨率图像，对彗星及其近空间进行精细制图，并规划出呈“三角形”或金字塔形的环绕轨道，使Rosetta始终飞在彗星前方便于供电与通信[1]。
飞行器在这些不同高度和方位的轨道上多次运行，科研人员通过分析探测器所受微弱引力变化反推彗星的重力场，从而计算出其密度和质量，并据此完善动力学模型，预测菲利亚的自由落体轨迹与接触速度[1]。
参考对半径约5 km、密度约1 g/cm³的冰雪天体估算，彗星质量约为5 × 10¹⁴ kg，这一数据为着陆器的减速、反弹控制和锚定装置提供了设计边界[2]。
在全面掌握重力分布和最佳光照后，任务团队选择了合适的着陆窗口，使菲利亚得以沿预定路径下沉约7小时后接触彗星表面并开始科学观测。
claims_retained: Rosetta团队为了让菲利亚成功降落，首先要确定母船在彗星周围的理想位置与光照条件，他们利用探测器上多台相机获取的高分辨率图像，对彗星及其近空间进行精细制图，并规划出呈“三角形”或金字塔形的环绕轨道，使Rosetta始终飞在彗星前方便于供电与通信[1]。
飞行器在这些不同高度和方位的轨道上多次运行，科研人员通过分析探测器所受微弱引力变化反推彗星的重力场，从而计算出其密度和质量，并据此完善动力学模型，预测菲利亚的自由落体轨迹与接触速度[1]。
参考对半径约5 km、密度约1 g/cm³的冰雪天体估算，彗星质量约为5 × 10¹⁴ kg，这一数据为着陆器的减速、反弹控制和锚定装置提供了设计边界[2]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Rosetta Comet Chaser背后的技术：从3D打印到太阳能到复杂映射-TechRepublic（www.techrepublic.com）
Content: 要降落在彗星上，ESA必须弄清楚围绕它的Rosetta的最佳方法。罗塞塔（Rosetta）必须在彗星前，才能获得太阳的最佳光条件。使用从航天器上的几个摄像机（包括广角镜）和科学摄像机收集的高分辨率数字图像来帮助绘制该区域，团队在彗星周围产生了三角形轨道图案。现在的挑战是找出彗星的引力。金字塔形状使他们能够更好地接收和分析数据，最终确定彗星的密度和质量。
---
Document ID: 2
Title:  (www.vanderbilt.edu)
Content: What is the mass of a comet?


Let's assume the comet is a sphere with a radius of 5 km. Then the volume of this comet is


> V = 4/3 pi R^3= 500 km^3= 5 x 10^17 cm^3


Assuming a density of 1 gm/cc, typical for water ice, then this comet would have a total mass of 5 x 10^17 gm = 5 x 10^14 kg.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: JimsAstronomy: Using Calculus to determine the mass of a comet (jdetrick.blogspot.com)
Content: - The comet was 2,000 meters long. We can use Calculus to calculate the volume of the comet by measuring the radius at each point along its length then summing up (integrating) an infinite number of areas of circles with each radius over the entire length.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: The tech behind the Rosetta comet chaser: From 3D printing to solar power to complex mapping - TechRepublic (www.techrepublic.com)
Content: To land on the comet, the ESA had to figure out the best way to orbit Rosetta around it. Rosetta has to be in front of the comet for the best light conditions from the sun. Using high-resolution digital images collected from several cameras on the spacecraft, including a wide angle lens, and scientific cameras to help map the area, the team generated a triangular orbit pattern around the comet. The challenge is now to figure out the gravitational pull of the comet. A pyramid shape allows them to better receive and analyze that data, eventually figuring out the density and mass of the comet.

Title: （www.vanderbilt.edu）
Content: 什么是彗星的质量？


假设彗星是半径为5 km的球体。那么这个彗星的体积是


> v = 4/3 pi r^3 = 500 km^3 = 5 x 10^17 cm^3


假设密度为1 gm/cc，典型的水冰，那么该彗星的总质量为5 x 10^17 gm = 5 x 10^14 kg。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 我们可以控制天气吗？ （science.howstuffworks.com）
Content: 最后，科学家至少在实验室找到了一种控制天气的方法。在接下来的30年中，世界各地的研究人员和企业家开始将Langmuir，Schaefer和Vonnegut开发的原则应用于现实世界中的云种子。他们将飞机飞入云层中，释放出自己的碘化银云，或者开了装满银碘化物的炮弹到云层中。在某些情况下，这些天气修饰符试图在干旱影响的地区降雨，从而防止冰雹生长如此大或在机场周围散布雾库来减轻冰雹损害。这项新技术的许多老板对他们的云种子服务提出了大胆的说法。不幸的是，硬科学永远无法证实主张。如果有的话，严格的实验似乎表明云种子几乎没有起作用，或者更糟的是根本没有起作用。

尽管如此，多年来，已经积累了足够的诱人证据，以使人们对天气修改的兴趣保持兴趣。例如，在南非和墨西哥进行的研究表明，用盐颗粒播种温暖的雨云（所谓的吸湿播种）比用碘化银播种冷雨云更有效。中国科学家认为，他们已经掌握了云播种的程度，以至于他们可以保证某天会下雨或晴天，就像这篇相关文章所描述的那样，北京2008年夏季奥运会的开幕式。

Title: New World War: Weather Warfare (www.newworldwar.org)
Content: A precision lightning strike with synthetic lightning is also possible. The 2005 book, Weapons Grade: How Modern Warfare Gave Birth to Our High-Tech World, mentioned that artificial lightning had been accomplished using lasers. One reportedly had a range of about 200 meters, but could possibly be extended to about 2 miles. The 1997 Weather Wars: Pentagon Plans Weather as a Weapon article by the New York Times noted that the US Air Force was considering using such lasers for lightning attacks.

The US Air Force itself referenced using controlled lightning strikes to attack its targets. The Tofflers suggested that lasers can even be used to cut holes in the ozone layer above the land of an adversary.

HAARP

According to this information, weather modification is possible using electromagnetic waves. In the US and other countries, large weapons platforms to accomplish this appear to have been created.2

One such weapon is known as the High Frequency Active Auroral Research Project (HAARP). In their book Angels Don’t Play This HAARP: Advances in Tesla Technology, Jeane Manning and Dr. Nick Begich refer to it as one of the most powerful multi-purpose weapons developed by the US military.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Can we control the weather? (science.howstuffworks.com)
Content: Finally, scientists had found a way to control the weather -- at least in the lab. For the next 30 years, researchers and entrepreneurs across the world began applying the principles developed by Langmuir, Schaefer and Vonnegut to real-world cloud seeding. They flew airplanes into the clouds, releasing their own clouds of silver iodide as they went, or fired artillery shells filled with silver iodide into clouds. In some cases, these weather modifiers were trying to produce rain in drought-afflicted areas, mitigate hail damage by preventing hailstones from growing so large, or disperse fog banks around airports. Many proprietors of this new technology made audacious claims about their cloud seeding services. Unfortunately, hard science could never substantiate the claims. If anything, rigorous experimentation seemed to suggest that cloud seeding barely worked or, worse, didn't work at all.

Still, enough tantalizing evidence has accumulated over the years to keep interest in weather modification alive. For example, research conducted in South Africa and Mexico has shown that seeding warm rain clouds with salt particles -- what is known as hygroscopic seeding -- is more effective than seeding cold rain clouds with silver iodide. And Chinese scientists believe they have mastered cloud seeding to such a degree that they can guarantee a certain day will be rainy or sunny, like say the opening ceremony of the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, as this related article describes.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 新世界大战：气象战（www.newworldwar.org）
Content: 还可以通过合成闪电进行精确的雷击。 2005年的书《武器等级：现代战争如何诞生了我们的高科技世界》，提到人造闪电是使用激光完成的。据报道，一个人的射程约为200米，但可能会延伸到约2英里。 1997年的天气战：五角大楼计划天气作为《纽约时报》的武器文章指出，美国空军正在考虑使用此类激光器进行闪电袭击。

美国空军本身使用受控雷击来攻击其目标。太妃糖建议激光甚至可以用来在对手土地上方的臭氧层中切下孔。

哈普

根据这些信息，使用电磁波可以改变天气。在美国和其他国家，似乎已经创建了实现这一目标的大型武器平台。2

一种这样的武器被称为高频主动极光研究项目（HAARP）。在他们的著作《天使》中，没有扮演这一HAARP：特斯拉技术的进步，让·曼宁（Jeane Manning）和尼克·贝吉奇（Nick Begich）博士将其称为美国军方开发的最强大的多用途武器之一。

question_src: 为什么雇主让工人获得补偿时间而不是加班费会更便宜？
all_claims: 雇主之所以让员工拿补偿时间（comp time）而不是加班费，核心在于现金成本：补偿时间按“每加班一小时换一小时休息”的 1∶1 比例兑现，无需额外工资支出[1]；而《公平劳动标准法》（FLSA）规定企业在发生加班时必须按法定方式支付报酬，意味着公司需立即承担现金成本[2]。
对部分 FLSA 免税且薪级高于 GS-10 的员工，机构甚至可“要求…获得补偿时间，以代替…加班费”[4]，从而避免向高薪员工具付加班现金并减少相关税费及即时财务压力。
只要做法符合法规，补偿时间既满足对额外工作时间的补偿义务，又推迟或消除了雇主的现金支出，因此总体上比直接支付加班费便宜；反之，若非法拒付加班费将被视为盗窃工资，可能招致高额罚款和监禁[3]，使得合规使用补偿时间成为更低成本且风险更小的选择。

question_src: 为什么雇主让工人获得补偿时间而不是加班费会更便宜？
all_claims: 雇主之所以让员工拿补偿时间（comp time）而不是加班费，核心在于现金成本：补偿时间按“每加班一小时换一小时休息”的 1∶1 比例兑现，无需额外工资支出[1]；而《公平劳动标准法》（FLSA）规定企业在发生加班时必须按法定方式支付报酬，意味着公司需立即承担现金成本[2]。
对部分 FLSA 免税且薪级高于 GS-10 的员工，机构甚至可“要求…获得补偿时间，以代替…加班费”[4]，从而避免向高薪员工具付加班现金并减少相关税费及即时财务压力。
只要做法符合法规，补偿时间既满足对额外工作时间的补偿义务，又推迟或消除了雇主的现金支出，因此总体上比直接支付加班费便宜；反之，若非法拒付加班费将被视为盗窃工资，可能招致高额罚款和监禁[3]，使得合规使用补偿时间成为更低成本且风险更小的选择。

question_src: 为什么美国铁路系统如此糟糕？
all_claims: 美国至今没有真正意义上的高速铁路网络，整体水平远落后于中、日、欧等国[1]。
目前唯一被称作高速的东北走廊 Acela，仅在457英里线路中的34英里能达到150英里/小时，纽约至波士顿平均时速仅约65英里/小时，效率低下[1]。
首要障碍是资金与政治：升级 Acela 需要数百亿美元，但两极化的国会难以批准如此规模的联邦投入[2]。
政治博弈还直接拖慢项目进展，2019年联邦政府甚至撤回加州高铁9.29亿美元拨款，工程雪上加霜[2]。
加州项目本身又因无意义且昂贵的新增站点、仓促建设和糟糕的财务决策导致成本失控[2]。
其次，美国深厚的汽车文化使公众不愿接受为铁路建设提高税收；与一些对汽车征收最高150%购置税的国家不同，这在美国几乎不可想象[3]。
结果，中国十年内新建超过1.9万英里高铁的速度，与美国形成鲜明对比[1]。

日本的子弹列车每小时可以达到近200英里，到1960年代。他们搬走了超过90亿人，没有一次乘客伤亡。


法国于1981年开始为高速TGV火车提供服务，欧洲其他地区很快随之而来。


但是，除了东北走廊的Amtrak线路以外，美国没有真正的高速火车。 ACELA只能在其457英里跨度的34英里处达到150英里 /小时。它在纽约和波士顿之间的平均速度约为65英里 /小时。


加利福尼亚州的高铁系统正在建设中，但是它是否会按预期完成。

Document ID: 2
Title: The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
Content: High-speed rail isn't just achievable: It already exists. However, as with anything else in the U.S. today, the biggest obstacle in the way of American high-speed rail is politics. Speeding up the Acela Express, for example, would require billions in federal funding, according to Fortune. Good luck with that in today's polarized environment. Meanwhile, the political squabbles that have faced California's bullet train ambitions are now legendary, and not in a good way. While the concept of connecting the Golden State's biggest cities via bullet train is brilliant, Vox says the planning has been horrendous, between the addition of pointless and expensive stops, rushed construction, and bad financial decisions. The political battles got even nastier in 2019, when the Trump administration pulled $929 million in federal grants for California's high-speed rail, according to MSN.

Title: The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
Content: The U.S. automobile obsession is an obstacle for high-speed rail dreams, according to Forbes, because cultural mores impact funding decisions. The U.S. has higher car ownership rates than other nations, so these countries are far more open to the idea of putting higher taxes on vehicles to cut demand — sometimes to the point of taxing purchasers an additional 150 percent on the car's base price. You think a tax like that would ever fly in the U.S.? Not in this lifetime.

question_src: 为什么美国铁路系统如此糟糕？
all_claims: 美国至今没有真正意义上的高速铁路网络，整体水平远落后于中、日、欧等国[1]。
目前唯一被称作高速的东北走廊 Acela，仅在457英里线路中的34英里能达到150英里/小时，纽约至波士顿平均时速仅约65英里/小时，效率低下[1]。
首要障碍是资金与政治：升级 Acela 需要数百亿美元，但两极化的国会难以批准如此规模的联邦投入[2]。
政治博弈还直接拖慢项目进展，2019年联邦政府甚至撤回加州高铁9.29亿美元拨款，工程雪上加霜[2]。
加州项目本身又因无意义且昂贵的新增站点、仓促建设和糟糕的财务决策导致成本失控[2]。
其次，美国深厚的汽车文化使公众不愿接受为铁路建设提高税收；与一些对汽车征收最高150%购置税的国家不同，这在美国几乎不可想象[3]。
结果，中国十年内新建超过1.9万英里高铁的速度，与美国形成鲜明对比[1]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 美国在建造高铁方面非常糟糕 - 这就是为什么（www.cnbc.com）
Content: 中国拥有世界上最快，最大的高速铁路网络 - 超过19,000英里，其中绝大多数是在过去十年中建造的。


日本的子弹列车每小时可以达到近200英里，到1960年代。他们搬走了超过90亿人，没有一次乘客伤亡。


法国于1981年开始为高速TGV火车提供服务，欧洲其他地区很快随之而来。


但是，除了东北走廊的Amtrak线路以外，美国没有真正的高速火车。 ACELA只能在其457英里跨度的34英里处达到150英里 /小时。它在纽约和波士顿之间的平均速度约为65英里 /小时。


加利福尼亚州的高铁系统正在建设中，但是它是否会按预期完成。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
Content: High-speed rail isn't just achievable: It already exists. However, as with anything else in the U.S. today, the biggest obstacle in the way of American high-speed rail is politics. Speeding up the Acela Express, for example, would require billions in federal funding, according to Fortune. Good luck with that in today's polarized environment. Meanwhile, the political squabbles that have faced California's bullet train ambitions are now legendary, and not in a good way. While the concept of connecting the Golden State's biggest cities via bullet train is brilliant, Vox says the planning has been horrendous, between the addition of pointless and expensive stops, rushed construction, and bad financial decisions. The political battles got even nastier in 2019, when the Trump administration pulled $929 million in federal grants for California's high-speed rail, according to MSN.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
Content: The U.S. automobile obsession is an obstacle for high-speed rail dreams, according to Forbes, because cultural mores impact funding decisions. The U.S. has higher car ownership rates than other nations, so these countries are far more open to the idea of putting higher taxes on vehicles to cut demand — sometimes to the point of taxing purchasers an additional 150 percent on the car's base price. You think a tax like that would ever fly in the U.S.? Not in this lifetime.

Title: The US is terrible at building high-speed rail — here's why (www.cnbc.com)
Content: China has the world's fastest and largest high-speed rail network — more than 19,000 miles, the vast majority of which was built in the past decade.


Japan's bullet trains can reach nearly 200 miles per hour and date to the 1960s. They have moved more than 9 billion people without a single passenger casualty.


France began service of the high-speed TGV train in 1981 and the rest of Europe quickly followed.


But the U.S. has no true high-speed trains, aside from sections of Amtrak's Acela line in the Northeast Corridor. The Acela can reach 150 mph for only 34 miles of its 457-mile span. Its average speed between New York and Boston is about 65 mph.


California's high-speed rail system is under construction, but whether it will ever get completed as intended is uncertain.

Title: The US is terrible at building high-speed rail — here's why (www.cnbc.com)
Content: China has the world's fastest and largest high-speed rail network — more than 19,000 miles, the vast majority of which was built in the past decade.


Japan's bullet trains can reach nearly 200 miles per hour and date to the 1960s. They have moved more than 9 billion people without a single passenger casualty.


France began service of the high-speed TGV train in 1981 and the rest of Europe quickly followed.


But the U.S. has no true high-speed trains, aside from sections of Amtrak's Acela line in the Northeast Corridor. The Acela can reach 150 mph for only 34 miles of its 457-mile span. Its average speed between New York and Boston is about 65 mph.


California's high-speed rail system is under construction, but whether it will ever get completed as intended is uncertain.

Title: The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
Content: High-speed rail isn't just achievable: It already exists. However, as with anything else in the U.S. today, the biggest obstacle in the way of American high-speed rail is politics. Speeding up the Acela Express, for example, would require billions in federal funding, according to Fortune. Good luck with that in today's polarized environment. Meanwhile, the political squabbles that have faced California's bullet train ambitions are now legendary, and not in a good way. While the concept of connecting the Golden State's biggest cities via bullet train is brilliant, Vox says the planning has been horrendous, between the addition of pointless and expensive stops, rushed construction, and bad financial decisions. The political battles got even nastier in 2019, when the Trump administration pulled $929 million in federal grants for California's high-speed rail, according to MSN.

claim: 在 HTTPS 中，SSL/TLS 通过 X.509 数字证书来完成服务器身份验证，协议依赖“证书链”而非账号口令，因此被称为“基于证书”的安全机制[2]；浏览器验证证书后，与服务器协商会话密钥，实现数据加密，让访客放心输入信用卡等敏感信息，因为这些信息“不能被盗或拦截”
question_src: 为什么HTTPS/SSL需要证书来进行安全传输，而SSH则没有？
all_claims: 在 HTTPS 中，SSL/TLS 通过 X.509 数字证书来完成服务器身份验证，协议依赖“证书链”而非账号口令，因此被称为“基于证书”的安全机制[2]；浏览器验证证书后，与服务器协商会话密钥，实现数据加密，让访客放心输入信用卡等敏感信息，因为这些信息“不能被盗或拦截”[1]。
公开网站访问者通常事先并不认识服务器，必须借助受信任 CA 颁发的证书来快速、自动地确认“你是谁”，证书于是成为大规模匿名通信场景下的第三方担保。
相反，SSH 在两端之间直接用用户名/密码或公私钥对完成认证，“没有”使用证书，也无需 CA[2]；客户端第一次连接时记录服务器指纹，后续比对即可（TOFU 模型），适合系统管理员等受控、点对点的远程登录需求。
综上，SSL/HTTPS 需证书是为了在开放互联网里自动验证身份并建立信任，而 SSH 面向可控环境，可通过直接密钥或口令即可实现安全传输，无须证书。
claims_retained: 在 HTTPS 中，SSL/TLS 通过 X.509 数字证书来完成服务器身份验证，协议依赖“证书链”而非账号口令，因此被称为“基于证书”的安全机制[2]；浏览器验证证书后，与服务器协商会话密钥，实现数据加密，让访客放心输入信用卡等敏感信息，因为这些信息“不能被盗或拦截”[1]。

Information: Document ID: 1
Title: https：什么是SSL证书，为什么需要一个证书？ | Redwood Valley技术解决方案Web Design（RVTechsolutions.com）
Content: [图片：SSL证书安全浏览] HTTPS和SSL都可以确保您的网站值得信赖和负责。通过批准您的网页，您的受众知道他们在浏览或从页面上购买时或多或少受到保护。

如果您不熟悉HTTPS和SSL，则需要仔细研究它们的含义和所包含的内容。首先，看看HTTP和SSL的代表。

HTTPS代表超文本传输​​协议安全。 HTTPS是HTTP的安全版本，这意味着您的访问者和网站之间的通信是安全和加密的。

与标准HTTP相比，拥有HTTPS网站有很多好处，尤其是如果您的访客在访问您的网站时经常输入详细信息或敏感信息时。如果您的客户需要输入信用卡信息或其他个人信息，则需要拥有HTTPS页面。

拥有HTTPS向您的访客展示您是一家有效的公司，因此他们无需担心输入信用卡信息即可在线购买。他们输入的信息将被加密，因此不能被盗或拦截。

您的HTTPS网站可以与您的客户建立更强的信任水平。当他们知道自己的信息受到保护时，他们更有可能在您的公司中从公司购买。

##什么是SSL？

代表安全套接字层的SSL与您的HTTPS网站合作，以保护客户的信息和隐私。 SSL（也可以称为TLS或运输层安全性）是您的HTTPS网站使用的加密通信来加密客户或客户将信息输入您网站的信息。

Document ID: 2
Title: SSH vs SSL | Top 8 Differences and Comparisons You Should Learn (www.educba.com)
Content: Both SSH and SSL are public-key cryptography protocols that create a secure, confidential exchange of data and connection across the Internet. Let’s discuss some of the major key differences:

 1. Usually, SSH uses Port 22, whereas SSL uses Port 443. 2. SSH uses a username/password authentication process to establish a secure connection, whereas SSL does not consider it. 3. SSH is based on network tunnelling, whereas SSL is based on certificates. 4. SSL is used for securely transmitting critical information like credit cards and banking. Whereas SSH is used for securely executing commands across the Internet. 5. SSL is used for encrypting communication between browser and server. On the other hand, SSH is used for encrypting communication between two computers over the Internet. 6. In SSL, the communication is authenticated via the private-key/public-key pair. Whereas in SSH, the communication is authenticated via private-key/public-key pair or username/password pair. 7. Technically, SSH is for securing computer networks, whereas SSL is for securing online data transfers. 8. SSL generally (except exceptions) uses X.509 digital certificates for server and client authentication processes, whereas SSH does not. 9. Another major difference is that SSH has more built-in functionality than SSL. It helps in enabling users to log in to a server and execute commands remotely, whereas SSL does not have this functionality. To achieve this functionality, you need to pair it with another protocol like HTTP, FTP.

claim: 当食物被高温烹饪至烧焦时，糖与天冬酰胺发生美拉德反应会生成潜在致癌物丙烯酰胺
question_src: 为什么吃燃烧的食物对您有害？
all_claims: 当食物被高温烹饪至烧焦时，糖与天冬酰胺发生美拉德反应会生成潜在致癌物丙烯酰胺[1]。
在烧烤或油炸肉类时，滴落的脂肪与火焰接触会产生多环芳烃，而肉长时间暴露于高温会使氨基酸与糖反应生成杂环胺[3]。
动物实验证实，给予大鼠多种杂环胺可诱发乳腺、结肠和胰腺癌[4]。
同样，动物以很高剂量暴露于丙烯酰胺也出现癌症，联合国粮农组织/世界卫生组织专家委员会已将其列为人类健康关注[2]。
这些化学物质在体内经细胞色素P450等酶激活后能与DNA形成反应性加合物，引发突变并提高癌症风险[4]。
因此，经常食用烧焦或过度烹饪的食物会增加潜在的致癌威胁，减少烹饪时间、避免直接火焰或先微波再烹调可降低有害化合物的生成[3]。
claims_retained: 当食物被高温烹饪至烧焦时，糖与天冬酰胺发生美拉德反应会生成潜在致癌物丙烯酰胺[1]。
动物实验证实，给予大鼠多种杂环胺可诱发乳腺、结肠和胰腺癌[4]。
同样，动物以很高剂量暴露于丙烯酰胺也出现癌症，联合国粮农组织/世界卫生组织专家委员会已将其列为人类健康关注[2]。
这些化学物质在体内经细胞色素P450等酶激活后能与DNA形成反应性加合物，引发突变并提高癌症风险[4]。
因此，经常食用烧焦或过度烹饪的食物会增加潜在的致癌威胁，减少烹饪时间、避免直接火焰或先微波再烹调可降低有害化合物的生成[3]。
prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 丙烯酰胺（www.niehs.nih.gov）
Content: 当某些食物在高温下烹饪时，糖（例如葡萄糖和果糖）可以与游离氨基酸（天冬酰胺）反应形成丙烯酰胺。丙烯酰胺形成是化学反应的一部分，称为Maillard反应，该反应有助于烹饪食物的香气，味道和颜色。丙烯酰胺是在Maillard反应过程中可能形成的数百种化学物质之一。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Acrylamide Questions and Answers (www.fda.gov)
Content: Acrylamide caused cancer in animals in studies where animals were exposed to acrylamide at very high doses. In 2010, the Joint Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) concluded that acrylamide is a human health concern, and suggested additional long-term studies. FDA experts participated in the evaluation and provided data from new research studies on acrylamide risk.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Does Burnt Food Cause Cancer? | Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (blog.dana-farber.org)
Content: When it comes to cooking meat, there are two different chemicals that occur when meat is cooked.


Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are formed when fat and juices drip onto flames while frying, baking, or grilling meat. Heterocyclic amines (HCAs) are generated from reactions between molecules including amino acids and sugars.


[Image]


HCAs form when meat is exposed to high temperatures for a prolonged period of time; the longer the exposure, the more HCAs are formed. Microwaving meat briefly before cooking at a high temperature reduces the time the meat needs to be cooked, and therefore less HCAs are produced. Although some studies how burnt, fried, or barbecued meat is associated with higher risk of certain cancers in lab tests, the connection between charred food and increased cancer risk is not proven for certain.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Heterocyclic Amine - an overview (www.sciencedirect.com)
Content: HCAs form when amino acids and creatine react at high cooking temperatures and are formed in greater quantities when meats are overcooked or blackened. Seventeen different HCAs resulting from the cooking of muscle meats have been identified, which may pose human cancer risk.


HCAs develop a powerful carcinogenic potential when activated by cytochrome P450 1A2-mediated oxidation of the amino group, which is followed by acetylation or sulfation to form direct-acting reactive mutagens that attack key elements in DNA. When fed to rats, several of these HCAs can induce cancer of the mammary glands, colon, and pancreas.

question_src: 为什么吃燃烧的食物对您有害？
all_claims: 当食物被高温烹饪至烧焦时，糖与天冬酰胺发生美拉德反应会生成潜在致癌物丙烯酰胺[1]。
在烧烤或油炸肉类时，滴落的脂肪与火焰接触会产生多环芳烃，而肉长时间暴露于高温会使氨基酸与糖反应生成杂环胺[3]。
动物实验证实，给予大鼠多种杂环胺可诱发乳腺、结肠和胰腺癌[4]。
同样，动物以很高剂量暴露于丙烯酰胺也出现癌症，联合国粮农组织/世界卫生组织专家委员会已将其列为人类健康关注[2]。
这些化学物质在体内经细胞色素P450等酶激活后能与DNA形成反应性加合物，引发突变并提高癌症风险[4]。
因此，经常食用烧焦或过度烹饪的食物会增加潜在的致癌威胁，减少烹饪时间、避免直接火焰或先微波再烹调可降低有害化合物的生成[3]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Acrylamide (www.niehs.nih.gov)
Content: When certain foods are cooked at high temperatures, sugars, such as glucose and fructose, can react with the free amino acid, asparagine, to form acrylamide. Acrylamide forms as part of a chemical reaction, known as the Maillard reaction, which contributes to the aroma, taste, and color of cooked foods. Acrylamide is one of the hundreds of chemicals that can form during the Maillard reaction.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Acrylamide Questions and Answers (www.fda.gov)
Content: Acrylamide caused cancer in animals in studies where animals were exposed to acrylamide at very high doses. In 2010, the Joint Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) concluded that acrylamide is a human health concern, and suggested additional long-term studies. FDA experts participated in the evaluation and provided data from new research studies on acrylamide risk.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: Does Burnt Food Cause Cancer? | Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (blog.dana-farber.org)
Content: When it comes to cooking meat, there are two different chemicals that occur when meat is cooked.


Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are formed when fat and juices drip onto flames while frying, baking, or grilling meat. Heterocyclic amines (HCAs) are generated from reactions between molecules including amino acids and sugars.


[Image]


HCAs form when meat is exposed to high temperatures for a prolonged period of time; the longer the exposure, the more HCAs are formed. Microwaving meat briefly before cooking at a high temperature reduces the time the meat needs to be cooked, and therefore less HCAs are produced. Although some studies how burnt, fried, or barbecued meat is associated with higher risk of certain cancers in lab tests, the connection between charred food and increased cancer risk is not proven for certain.
---
Document ID: 4
Title: 杂环胺 - 概述（www.sciencedirect.com）
Content: 当氨基酸和肌酸在高烹饪温度下反应时形成HCA，并且当肉被过度煮熟或变黑时形成更大的数量。已经确定了肌肉肉烹饪导致的17种不同的HCA，这可能会带来人类癌症的风险。


当通过细胞色素P450 1A2介导的氨基氧化激活时，HCA会产生强大的致癌潜力，然后将乙酰化或硫酸化形成直接作用的反应性诱变，从而攻击DNA中的关键元素。当喂给大鼠时，其中几个HCA可以诱导乳腺，结肠和胰腺的癌症。
---

Title: 丙烯酰胺的问题和答案（www.fda.gov）
Content: 丙烯酰胺在动物以非常高剂量暴露于丙烯酰胺的研究中引起了癌症。 2010年，粮食和农业组织/世界卫生组织食品添加剂专家委员会（JECFA）得出结论，丙烯酰胺是人类健康的关注，并提出了其他长期研究。 FDA专家参与了评估，并提供了有关丙烯酰胺风险的新研究数据。

Title: Does Burnt Food Cause Cancer? | Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (blog.dana-farber.org)
Content: When it comes to cooking meat, there are two different chemicals that occur when meat is cooked.

[Image]

Document ID: 4
Title: Heterocyclic Amine - an overview (www.sciencedirect.com)
Content: HCAs form when amino acids and creatine react at high cooking temperatures and are formed in greater quantities when meats are overcooked or blackened. Seventeen different HCAs resulting from the cooking of muscle meats have been identified, which may pose human cancer risk.


HCAs develop a powerful carcinogenic potential when activated by cytochrome P450 1A2-mediated oxidation of the amino group, which is followed by acetylation or sulfation to form direct-acting reactive mutagens that attack key elements in DNA. When fed to rats, several of these HCAs can induce cancer of the mammary glands, colon, and pancreas.

claim: 今天加拿大举行全国大选（又称联邦大选），选民要为下议院挑选新的议员[1]；全国被划分为338个选区，每区只选出一名议员，流程与美国众议院选举相似
question_src: 解释：（对美国人）：今天的加拿大大选
all_claims: 今天加拿大举行全国大选（又称联邦大选），选民要为下议院挑选新的议员[1]；全国被划分为338个选区，每区只选出一名议员，流程与美国众议院选举相似[3]。
加拿大的另一院——参议院——由总理提名、总督任命，不参与此次投票[4]。
政党若拿到170席或以上即可单独执政；若获169席或更少，只能成立少数派政府并寻求其他党派支持，这在加拿大历史上并不罕见[5]。

Title: Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Content: Why do people send chain letters? There are several known reasons to explain the chain letters' popularity. One reason is that it is a great source for obtaining new e-mail addresses. These addresses may lead to new contacts. This tactic can be considered an example of the "free-rider effect". The "free-rider effect" involves depending on others to collectively complete a task. The original senders may, for some reason, decide that they need to obtain e-mail addresses. In order to find these addresses, the senders will initiate a chain letter and rely on the recipients to pass the letter to others. Each time the letter is sent to someone new, their address will be added to the list of recipients and the original senders will have obtained the addresses they wanted while exerting little effort.

发件人借助每一次转发自动附加的新邮箱，低成本收集大量联系方式，体现了“搭便车效应”[3]；这些地址随后可用于发送垃圾广告、实施网络诈骗或扩充营销数据库，带来直接的数据与经济收益[3]。
另外，一些人把连锁信设计成电子金字塔计划，通过后续汇款或消费链条获利，或借谣言与骚扰达到破坏名誉、取乐等目的[4]。
因此，真正获利者是最初的发起人及其背后的营销或欺诈网络，而普通转发者仅因“自我实现预言”期待好运，实际上并未获得任何可量化的利益[5]。
claims_retained: 这类写着“7小时内转发给10人就会走运”的连锁信通常由无法识别的匿名原始发件人发动，邮件只剩一长串转发地址，几乎找不到真正的源头[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Content: Chain letters are letters that direct the recipient to send out multiple copies so that circulation increases. These letters can be sent via the postal service or by e-mail. The distribution of chain letters through the postal service has neared extinction yet computers have extended the lifespan of this particular type of communication.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Content: They may tell a joke, promise good fortune, threaten you with bad luck, or inform you of another's tragedy or misfortune. These letters often promise the recipients some type of reward if they pass the message on to others. When sent through e-mail, there is usually a long list of previous recipients, but no address or name to identify the original sender. This could possibly be a problem because there is no way to check the authenticity of the letter. Although it is possible for the information to have some truth, chain letters may also contain information that is completely false.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: 连锁信（www.units.miamioh.edu）
Content: 人们为什么要发送连锁信？有几个已知的理由来解释链信的受欢迎程度。原因之一是它是获得新电子邮件地址的好来源。这些地址可能会导致新的联系。这种策略可以被视为“自由骑士效应”的例子。 “自由式效果”涉及取决于其他人以共同完成任务。原始发件人可能由于某种原因决定他们需要获得电子邮件地址。为了找到这些地址，发件人将发起链信件，并依靠收件人将信件传递给他人。每次将信件发送给新人时，他们的地址都会添加到收件人列表中，而原始发​​件人将在付出很少的精力时获得他们想要的地址。
---
Document ID: 4
Title: Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Content: Some people send chain letters simply to see how far it will go or to harass another person. There may be times when someone decided that they want to damage a person's or organization's reputation. This is obviously the case with the Neiman-Marcus Cookie Recipe discussed in the Legend of and on the Internet section. Some people are out to get money, and may be successful, through pyramid schemes distributed through an e-mail chain.
---
Document ID: 5
Title: Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Content: Many times these chain letters make promises to the recipient in exchange of sending the message to other people. The recipients may adhere to the senders' request because they believe that sending the message to others will contribute to their good luck. "This belief is an example of self-fulfilling prophecy. Self-fulfilling prophecy is when an originally false social belief leads to its own fulfillment."
---

claim: 导盲犬并不会自己知道目的地，而是靠与主人的配合才能“知道”要走的路线
question_src: 如何看到眼狗确切地知道主人想要他们去哪里。
all_claims: 导盲犬并不会自己知道目的地，而是靠与主人的配合才能“知道”要走的路线[2]。
行进时，主人通过口头指令如“向前”“左转”“右转”以及牵引带或手势告诉狗下一步方向[1]。
因此，主人必须具备良好的方向感并记住路线地图，以便及时发出正确指令[2]。
当到达路口，主人听取车辆声音判断何时安全过街，再命令导盲犬起步[1]。
如果主人判断失误或前方出现障碍，导盲犬会执行所谓“聪明的不服从”，拒绝前进以保护双方安全[1]。
通过这种“主人决策—狗执行并监控安全”的协作机制，导盲犬就能准确带领主人到达目的地。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: How do Guide Dogs work? (chicagolighthouse.org)
Content: Q: How do dog guides know where to go when traveling?


A: This is a team effort between the dog and its owner. The owner knows where and how he wants to get to a certain place, and he or she is responsible for telling the dog through verbal and hand signals. Directions include forward, left and right. When at a street crossing, the owner is responsible for judging when it is safe to cross based on the sound of the cars, and should then command the dog to begin crossing. Intelligent disobedience is when a dog refuses to cross the street because it is unsafe to do so, even when the owner has commanded it to go forward.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 很高兴知道（www.blindenhundeschule.ch）
Content: 导盲犬不知道视力障碍或盲人想要去哪里。导狗主人通过声音提示进行通信，狗需要遵循哪个方向。因此，指导狗主人需要具有良好的方向感，并记住其路线的地图。
---
Using the above information, the response is the answer to the query or task: "如何看到眼狗确切地知道主人想要他们去哪里。" in a single sentence.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 导犬如何工作？ （chicagolighthouse.org）
Content: 问：狗向导如何知道旅行时要去哪里？


答：这是狗与其主人之间的团队努力。主人知道他想在哪里以及如何到达某个地方，他或她负责通过口头和手势告诉狗。指示包括向前，左右。当在街道交叉处时，所有者负责根据汽车的声音进行安全穿越时进行判断，然后命令狗开始越过。聪明的不服从是在狗拒绝过马路的时候，因为这样做是不安全的，即使主人命令它向前走。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Good to know (www.blindenhundeschule.ch)
Content: Guide dogs don’t know where the visually impaired or blind person wants to go. The guide dog owner communicates via vocal cues which direction the dog needs to follow. Therefore, guide dog owners need to have a good sense of direction and to keep a map of their route in mind.
---

prompt:

Title: Can someone provide me with a summary of the Metal Gear Solid series? (gaming.stackexchange.com)
Content: ## Metal Gear Solid


FOXHOUND rebels and takes over a compound in the Alaska known as Shadow Moses. Once again Solid Snake has to come out of retirement to deal with the bad guys. Luckily this time BIG BOSS is actually dead, but unluckily they have a new METAL GEAR: REX. They also have a couple hostages including Roy Campbell's niece (I never was 100% why all of FOXHOUND except Campbell revolted). You sneak in and save the hostages, fight Revolver Ocelot, who seems to think this is the 1800s, get saved by a creepy Cyborg Ninja, who no one knows and may or may not be a friend and have a short love story with Meryl Silverberg (Campbell's niece).

Document ID: 2
Title: 有人可以为我提供金属齿轮固体系列的摘要吗？ （gaming.stackexchange.com）
Content: ## Metal Gear Solid 3：蛇食者


在MGS2末端的悬崖吊架之后，以真正的金属装备固体方式，MGS3与它无关。相反，MGS3是前传。您是赤裸裸的蛇（看看那是多么艰难），他在老板的训练下受过训练，这是第二次世界大战的英雄，他也陷入了俄罗斯人的叛逃。您渗透了他们的基础，了解一个光明的组织，哲学家可能会或可能不会死，与年轻的左轮手枪，发现老板没有缺陷，只有在执行任务，殴打每个人，拯救世界，秘密地拯救世界（但在秘密），被所有老板配音，大老板：大老板，最终与一只热的小鸡做爱。哦，Ocelot在呼号亚当（Adam）下为中央情报局（CIA）工作...不知道为什么。
---

Title: Can someone provide me with a summary of the Metal Gear Solid series? (gaming.stackexchange.com)
Content: > So apparently after MGS2, when no one decided to do anything about the Patriots they took over the world and made it all about war, either your economy was based on war or your country was in a war. But since it's a modern war its all about the genetic engineered soldiers and nano machines. Controlled, of course, by a system called Sons of the Patriots or SOP (weren't these the guys trying to hide their existance?); and Liquid/Ocelot is out hijack it. So sure enough, Roy Campbell asks Snake to come out of retirement, one more time, and deal with Liquid/Ocelot. Hey, it could be worse. You could be Raiden again...

Title: 有人可以为我提供金属齿轮固体系列的摘要吗？ （gaming.stackexchange.com）
Content: ##金属齿轮固体


狐狸猎犬叛军，接管了阿拉斯加的一个名为“影子摩西”的化合物。坚实的蛇必须退休才能与坏人打交道。幸运的是，这次Big Boss实际上已经死了，但不幸的是，他们有一个新的金属装备：Rex。他们也有几个人质，包括罗伊·坎贝尔（Roy Campbell）的侄女（我从来都不是100％，为什么除了坎贝尔（Campbell）反击外，所有狐狸猎犬都为何）。您偷偷摸摸地拯救了人质，战斗左轮手枪，他似乎认为这是1800年代，被一个令人毛骨悚然的半机械人忍者拯救了，他没有人知道并且可能不是朋友，并且与梅丽尔·西尔弗伯格（Meryl Silverberg）（坎贝尔的侄女）有一个短暂的爱情故事。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Can someone provide me with a summary of the Metal Gear Solid series? (gaming.stackexchange.com)
Content: ## Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater


After the cliff hanger at the end of MGS2, in true Metal Gear Solid fashion, MGS3 has nothing to do with it. Instead, MGS3 is a prequel. You're Naked Snake (see how hard was that) who was trained under The BOSS a hero of WW2 who also defects to the Russians. You infiltrate their base, learn about an Illuminati-esque organization The Philosophers who may or may not be dead, meet a young Revolver Ocelot, find out The BOSS didn't defect and is only on a mission, beat up everybody, save the world (but in secret), get dubbed the boss of all bosses: BIG BOSS, and finally get to have sex with a hot chick. Oh and Ocelot works for the CIA under the call sign ADAM... no clue why.

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 您的大脑有2个时钟（www.scientificamerican.com）
Content: 神经科学家认为，我们有不同的神经系统来处理不同类型的时间，例如维持昼夜节律，以控制精美的身体运动的时机以及有意识地了解时间通道。直到最近，大多数神经科学家都认为，单一的大脑系统支持您在早餐过长的时间徘徊时提醒您的那种暂时性处理。但是，新兴的研究表明，单个神经时钟的模型可能太简单了。加州大学尔湾分校的神经科学家最近发表在《神经科学杂志》上的一项新研究表明，大脑实际上可能有第二种传达经过时间的方法。更重要的是，作者提出，第二个内部时钟不仅与我们的主要神经时钟平行，甚至可能与之竞争。


过去的研究表明，一个称为纹状体的大脑区域位于我们中央内钟的核心，与大脑周围的皮层合作以整合时间信息。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Physics explains why time passes faster as you age (qz.com)
Content: According to Bejan—who reviewed previous studies in a range of fields on time, vision, cognition, and mental processing to reach his conclusion—time as we experience it represents perceived changes in mental stimuli. It’s related to what we see. As physical mental-image processing time and the rapidity of images we take in changes, so does our perception of time. And in some sense, each of us has our own “mind time” unrelated to the passing of hours, days, and years on clocks and calendars, which is affected by the amount of rest we get and other factors.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: A stopwatch on the brain's perception of time (www.theguardian.com)
Content: It has also been shown that the cerebellum plays a key role in motor tasks requiring perception of implicit timing. Other parts of the brain may be involved in implicit-timing estimates: for example, the left parietal cortex, which manages intended movement, and the left premotor cortex, which plans and organises movement. Sometimes the right prefrontal cortex, usually involved in explicit-timing estimates, is activated for implicit estimates, for instance, when an event does not occur as soon as expected: a traffic light stays red for longer than foreseen. The brain updates its time forecasts, once again anticipating the interval.


In addition, "the regions of the brain involved differ depending on the context, particularly if the stimulus only lasts for a very short time, less than 200 milliseconds," says Coull. The visual cortex is activated when we estimate the duration of a visual stimulus. In the same way, the primary motor cortex comes into play when a timing estimate is associated with an action, whereas the auditory cortex has a part in estimating the length of a sound stimulus.


Above all, the brain's perception of time involves processes linked to memory and attention: witness the impression that time is passing more quickly when we are busy, or doing something amusing or exciting. Time flies even when we are in love. In contrast, a watched pot never boils. Minutes drag by when we are bored.
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Your Brain Has 2 Clocks (www.scientificamerican.com)
Content: Neuroscientists believe that we have distinct neural systems for processing different types of time, for example, to maintain a circadian rhythm, to control the timing of fine body movements, and for conscious awareness of time passage. Until recently, most neuroscientists believed that this latter type of temporal processing – the kind that alerts you when you’ve lingered over breakfast for too long – is supported by a single brain system. However, emerging research indicates that the model of a single neural clock might be too simplistic. A new study, recently published in the Journal of Neuroscience by neuroscientists at the University of California, Irvine, reveals that the brain may in fact have a second method for sensing elapsed time. What’s more, the authors propose that this second internal clock not only works in parallel with our primary neural clock, but may even compete with it.


Past research suggested that a brain region called the striatum lies at the heart of our central inner clock, working with the brain’s surrounding cortex to integrate temporal information.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Physics explains why time passes faster as you age (qz.com)
Content: According to Bejan—who reviewed previous studies in a range of fields on time, vision, cognition, and mental processing to reach his conclusion—time as we experience it represents perceived changes in mental stimuli. It’s related to what we see. As physical mental-image processing time and the rapidity of images we take in changes, so does our perception of time. And in some sense, each of us has our own “mind time” unrelated to the passing of hours, days, and years on clocks and calendars, which is affected by the amount of rest we get and other factors.
---
Document ID: 3
Title: 大脑对时间感知的秒表（www.theguardian.com）
Content: 还已经表明，小脑在需要感知隐式时机的运动任务中起关键作用。大脑的其他部分可能参与了隐式定时估计：例如，管理预期运动的左顶壁皮层和计划和组织运动的左前前皮层。有时，通常参与显式定时估计的右前额叶皮层会被激活以进行隐式估计，例如，当事件未预期发生时：交通信号灯比预见的更长。大脑会更新其时间预测，再次预测间隔。


此外，“涉及大脑的区域取决于上下文，特别是如果刺激仅持续很短的时间，小于200毫秒的情况。”当我们估计视觉刺激的持续时间时，可激活视觉皮层。以同样的方式，当定时估计与动作相关时，主电动机皮层发挥作用，而听觉皮层则参与估计声音刺激的长度。


最重要的是，大脑对时间的看法涉及与记忆和注意力相关的过程：见证了当我们忙碌或做有趣或令人兴奋的事情时，时间会更快地过去。时间即使我们恋爱了。相比之下，一个看着的锅永远不会沸腾。我们无聊时拖延。
---

claim: 要想在运动中保持直立，需要两个自稳定机制：①旋转车轮产生的陀螺效应与角动量，速度越快角动量越大，对侧向扭矩的抵抗越强；低速时角动量很小，外力极易改变车轮方向，车辆因而不稳
question_src: 为什么我的自行车静止不动，而在移动时不稳定？
all_claims: 自行车在静止时如果靠脚撑、墙壁或双脚提供第三个支点，就临时拥有“三点支撑”，因此看似稳固；可是一旦离开这些额外支点并开始前进，就只有前后轮两点与地面接触，支撑基底变成一条线，任何侧向扰动都会让重心落到支撑线外而倾倒[2]。
要想在运动中保持直立，需要两个自稳定机制：①旋转车轮产生的陀螺效应与角动量，速度越快角动量越大，对侧向扭矩的抵抗越强；低速时角动量很小，外力极易改变车轮方向，车辆因而不稳[2]。
②前叉“拖曳量”(trail)配合转向，使前轮自动朝倾倒侧偏转，将接触点移到重心下方；如果速度低于某一“临界速度”，或车辆设计的拖曳量过小，这一机制造成的纠正力不足，也会导致不稳[1]。
因此，你在静止时靠外部支撑显得稳，而起步后若速度不足或车辆设置不当，就会缺乏上述两种动态稳定效应，从而容易摇晃甚至摔倒。
claims_retained: 要想在运动中保持直立，需要两个自稳定机制：①旋转车轮产生的陀螺效应与角动量，速度越快角动量越大，对侧向扭矩的抵抗越强；低速时角动量很小，外力极易改变车轮方向，车辆因而不稳[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: Why Does A Moving Bicycle Stay Up? (www.science20.com)
Content: Since the bicycle was invented, s cientists have postulated various reasons as to why a bicycle is self stable above a certain speed. The consensus has been that a bicycle's stability is related to two factors: First, the rotating wheels of the bicycle provide stability through gyroscopic effects; secondly, that the ‘trail’, the distance by which the contact point of the front wheel trails behind the steering axis, plays an important part.

A new study in Science claims to have settled the issue - gyroscopic effects and trail help, says researcher Dr Arend Schwab of the 3mE faculty at TU Delft, but are not necessary above a certain speed . In a 2007 Proceedings of the Royal Society article (doi:10.1098/rspa.2007.1857), a mathematical model with around 25 physical parameters was developed at the time which appeared to predict whether, and at what speeds, a particular design of bicycle would be stable.
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 骑自行车平衡：现象（www.mentalfloss.com）
Content: 另一方面，自行车在静态不稳定上是不稳定的，因为它与地面只有两个接触点（无论前轮和后轮的任何部分碰巧碰到了地面），并且其支撑底座的基础是线段。良好的支持基础至少需要与地面的三个接触点，因此自行车在静止时很难保持直立。但是，自行车在向前移动时动态稳定或稳定，因为转向使骑手可以在重心下方移动自行车的支撑点并保持平衡，并且通常会带有足够小的转向调整，以至于骑手可能甚至没有意识到他们在制造它们。有点像站在一只脚上。如果您不跳一些，而又开始侧面跌落，那么您将无法恢复而跌倒。但是，如果您确实跳跃，则可以移动脚以将重心保持在其上方并保持平衡。


自行车具有两个功能，可以极大地帮助这种动态稳定性：其车轮。旋转的车轮具有角动力，当您坐在自行车上时，您和它的车轮构成了一个系统，遵守了角度动量的保护原则。除非从系统外部施加扭矩或扭曲力以改变车轮的角动量，否则动量和动量的方向保持恒定。简而言之，一旦车轮以某种方式排队，他们希望像这样保持排队。您很容易移动它们，但是外部力量很难做同样的事情，因此自行车很容易保持平衡，但并不容易倾倒。一辆非移动的自行车的车轮没有旋转，角度动量为零，这使得外部扭矩非常容易改变车轮的方向，从而使自行车更难平衡。
---

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 为什么移动的自行车停留？ （www.science20.com）
Content: 由于发明了自行车，因此S Cientists假定了自行车为何自行稳定以上的速度以上的自行车的各种原因。共识是，自行车的稳定性与两个因素有关：首先，自行车的旋转轮通过陀螺效应提供稳定性；其次，“小径”（前轮的接触点在转向轴后面的距离）起着重要的作用。

一项新的科学研究声称已经解决了这个问题 - 陀螺症的影响和TRAIL帮助。在皇家学会文章（DOI：10.1098/rspa.2007.1857）的2007年论文集中，当时开发了一个大约25个物理参数的数学模型，似乎可以预测，以什么速度，特定的自行车设计是稳定的。
---
Document ID: 2
Title: Balancing on a Bicycle: The Phenomena (www.mentalfloss.com)
Content: A bicycle, on the other hand, is statically unstable because it only has two contact points with the ground (whatever portion of the front and back wheels happen to be touching the ground) and its base of support is a line segment. A good base of support needs at least three contact points with the ground, so bikes are hard to keep upright when they're still. Bikes are, however, dynamically stable, or stable when moving forward, because steering allows a rider to move the bike's points of support around under the center of gravity and keep it balanced, often with steering adjustments small enough that the rider may not even realize they're making them. It's sort of like standing on one foot. If you don't hop around a little, and you start falling sideways, you can't recover and you fall over. If you do hop, though, you can move your foot around to keep your center of gravity above it and keep your balance.


A bike has two features that help this dynamic stability immensely: its wheels. Spinning wheels have angular momentum, and when you're sitting on a bike, you and it and its wheels make up a system that obeys the principle of conservation of angular momentum. Unless torque, or twisting force, is applied from outside the system to change the wheels' angular momentum, that momentum and the direction of the momentum remain constant. In a nutshell, once the wheels line up a certain way, they want to stay lined up like that. It's easy for you to move them, but hard for an outside force to do the same, and so the bike is easy to keep balanced but doesn't topple easily. A non-moving bike has wheels that aren't spinning and zero angular momentum, which makes it very easy for external torque to change the wheels' direction, making the bike harder to balance.
---

claim: CRISPR是一种基因编辑技术，全名为“定期间隔短的短质体重复序列”
question_src: CRISPR在实际意义上如何工作？
all_claims: CRISPR是一种基因编辑技术，全名为“定期间隔短的短质体重复序列”[1]。
科学家在2012年至2013年首次描述了CRISPR/Cas9工具，随后各国实验室迅速用它来改变有机体的整个基因组[2]。
它把DNA视作可以“剪切、复制和粘贴”的代码，以此实现精准的遗传材料改写[4]；凭借这一机制，研究人员已能快速且有效地调整任何动植物或动物中的任何基因[3]。
具体应用包括修复动物遗传病、对抗病毒、消毒蚊子，以及为人类移植准备猪器官等[3]。
如今，人们甚至可以在网上以约130美元购买一套CRISPR试剂包自行实验，显示出该技术的低成本和实用性[5]。

question_src: 一年在古希腊
all_claims: 在古希腊，历法因城邦而异；以雅典为例，宗教“节日日历”采用阴阳合历，一年 normally 含 12 个月，月份按“大小月”交替设 29 天与 30 天，并按观测月相不定期校正[1]。
除宗教年外，雅典还有政治年，它把一年划分为若干个 prytany，数量等于公民部族（phylai）的数目：公元前307 年以前为 10 个，此后在 11–13 个之间波动（多为 12 个），因此政治年的长度随时期而变，给现代学者的换算造成难题[1]。
在全希腊范围，历史学家更常用四年一周期的“奥林匹克纪年”来标记年份，同一奥林匹克的第 1 年即举行赛事的那年；按传统，第一奥林匹克第 1 年对应公元前 776 年，从而建立了连续纪年体系[2]。
例如狄奥多鲁斯把一次日食记为第 117 届第 3 年，经现代天文学推算为公元前 310 年 8 月 15 日，进一步确立了奥林匹克纪年与公历的对照[2]。

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: 古希腊日历| polyllabic（www.polysyllabic.com）
Content: 雅典人似乎对他们的日历采取了相当休闲的态度。看来他们既不使用常规公式也不使用连续直接观察来确定月份的长度。他们最有可能遵循交替的月份（29天和30天）的一般规则，但要通过观察周期性进行校正。

除了被称为节日日历的日历外，雅典人还保留了政治年度的第二个日历。这个“使人的”一年将一年分为“ prytanies”，“ phylai”一个，即雅典公民的细分。人类的数量以及prytanies的数量随时间而变化。直到公元前307年，有10个Phylai。

之后，数字在11和13之间变化（通常为12）。更令人困惑的是，虽然在公元前4世纪的和解和节日的年份基本上是相同的长度，但这种情况并非早些时候或晚些时候。因此，Prytany的文件通常很难分配给朱利安日历中的特定等效物
---
Document ID: 2
Title: The Ancient Greek Calendar | Polysyllabic (www.polysyllabic.com)
Content: Ancient historians date by Olympiad by giving both the number of the Olympiad and the year within the cycle, 1-4 (the Olympiad itself was held on year 1). Additionally, lists of Olympic winners were maintained, and the 3rd c. BCE writer Timaios compiled a synchronic list comparing Olympic winners, Athenian archons, Spartan kings, and the priests of Hera from Argos.

Olympiad 1,1 correlates to 776 BCE. We do not actually need to believe an actual festival was held on this date, but when Greek historians are writing in later times, they date their own events using this as the epoch. We can establish a precise correlation to the common era from a variety of different sources, but the most definitive comes from a passage in Diodorus, where he dates the year of a total solar eclipse to the reign of the Athenian archon Hieromnemon, which he also gives as Ol. 117,3. The only astronomically possible date for this event is August 15, 310 BCE, which fixes our epoch

Title: 古希腊日历| polyllabic（www.polysyllabic.com）
Content: 雅典人似乎对他们的日历采取了相当休闲的态度。看来他们既不使用常规公式也不使用连续直接观察来确定月份的长度。他们最有可能遵循交替的月份（29天和30天）的一般规则，但要通过观察周期性进行校正。

除了被称为节日日历的日历外，雅典人还保留了政治年度的第二个日历。这个“使人的”一年将一年分为“ prytanies”，“ phylai”一个，即雅典公民的细分。人类的数量以及prytanies的数量随时间而变化。直到公元前307年，有10个Phylai。

之后，数字在11和13之间变化（通常为12）。更令人困惑的是，虽然在公元前4世纪的和解和节日的年份基本上是相同的长度，但这种情况并非早些时候或晚些时候。因此，Prytany的文件通常很难分配给朱利安日历中的特定等效物

Title: The Ancient Greek Calendar | Polysyllabic (www.polysyllabic.com)
Content: Ancient historians date by Olympiad by giving both the number of the Olympiad and the year within the cycle, 1-4 (the Olympiad itself was held on year 1). Additionally, lists of Olympic winners were maintained, and the 3rd c. BCE writer Timaios compiled a synchronic list comparing Olympic winners, Athenian archons, Spartan kings, and the priests of Hera from Argos.

Olympiad 1,1 correlates to 776 BCE. We do not actually need to believe an actual festival was held on this date, but when Greek historians are writing in later times, they date their own events using this as the epoch. We can establish a precise correlation to the common era from a variety of different sources, but the most definitive comes from a passage in Diodorus, where he dates the year of a total solar eclipse to the reign of the Athenian archon Hieromnemon, which he also gives as Ol. 117,3. The only astronomically possible date for this event is August 15, 310 BCE, which fixes our epoch

prompt:
Information: Document ID: 1
Title: The Ancient Greek Calendar | Polysyllabic (www.polysyllabic.com)
Content: The Athenians seem to have taken a rather casual attitude towards their calendar. It appears they used neither a regular formula nor continuous direct observation to determine the length of the months. Most likely, they followed a general rule of alternating months (29 and 30 days long), subject to periodic correction by observation.

In addition to this calendar, which has been called the festival calendar, Athenians maintained a second calendar for the political year. This "conciliar" year divided the year into "prytanies," one for each of the "phylai," the subdivisions of Athenian citizens. The number of phylai, and hence the number of prytanies, varies over time. Until 307 BCE, there were 10 phylai.

After that the number varies between 11 and 13 (usually 12). Even more confusing, while the conciliar and festival years were basically the same length in the 4th century BCE, such was not regularly the case earlier or later. Thus documents dated by prytany are frequently very difficult to assign to a particular equivalent in the Julian calendar, although we are usually secure in assigning an approximate date
---
Document ID: 2
Title: 古希腊日历| polyllabic（www.polysyllabic.com）
Content: 古代历史学家通过奥林匹克运动会来追溯到奥林匹克运动会的数量和周期内的年度，即1-4（奥林匹克本身在1年级举行）。此外，维持奥林匹克冠军的名单和第3 c。 BCE作家Timaios汇编了一个同步名单，比较了奥林匹克冠军，雅典执政官，斯巴达国王和阿尔戈斯的赫拉神父。

奥林匹亚1,1与公元前776年相关。我们实际上不需要相信在这个日期举行了一个实际的节日，但是当希腊历史学家以后写作时，他们将自己的活动与时代约会。我们可以从各种不同的来源与共同时代建立精确的相关性，但是最明确的词来自狄奥多鲁斯的一段话，在那里他将日食全年与Athenian Archon Hieromnemon的统治时期约会，他也将其作为OL。 117,3。该活动的唯一天文学日期是公元前310年8月15日，它解决了我们的时代
---

Title: The Reason Your Dental Work Isn't Covered by Medical Insurance (www.nbcnews.com)
Content: We may have since greatly evolved in how we regard and understand dentistry, but we haven’t embraced it as a primarily medical issue; if we had, it would be covered under medical insurance, or at least, things like a root canal would be, because if you need a root canal and don’t get one, you could end up with all kinds of lethal problems that lead to hospitalization. It is rumored that Queen Elizabeth died from blood poisoning as a result of an untreated tooth infection. That was a long time ago, but hey, it happens.

Why isn’t a health problem so serious it can be deadly, not considered medical? To an extent, it’s because it’s not that common to end up in the hospital as a result of a tooth or gum problem — not if you’re keeping up with preventative dental care.
---

Title: 健康保险为什么也不涵盖牙科和视力？ （melmagazine.com）
Content: 除此之外，大多数卫生保健计划忽略了我们的眼睛和牙齿的主要原因之一与历史和污名有关。首先，牙科和医学长期以来被认为是截然不同的实践。直到1800年代，理发师在给您一个漂亮，靠近的剃须后，一直担任牙医，拔牙和刺穿脓肿。随着时间的流逝，牙科（和眼科在某种程度上）被认为比医学不那么先进，在1960年代制定公共卫生保险政策时，牙科渗入了国会的脑海。作为那段时间的普遍情绪的一个例子，在1940年，纽约的上诉法院认为牙医不是医生，因此不值得同样的声望。
